😊
 
Be well!

From:
 Chuck Adams <
c.adams@lcwmail.com
> 
Sent:
 Tuesday, October 10, 2023 10:00 AM
To:
 Office <
office@lcwmail.com
>
Subject:
 Staff Announcement
 
Good morning, Team – 
 
I wanted to- share with you that 
Emani Richmond
 and 
Dustin Puehler
 have both tendered their resignations from LCW. Emani’s last day with us will be Oct. 16. Dustin’s will be Oct. 13. We are working with Dustin to reserve some of his time for servicing Diligent and supporting LCW on contract.
 
In the almost 2 ½ years that Emani has been with us, she has proven to be a brilliant contributor to the consulting team. As an AC she could be counted on to consistently provide senior consultants and clients with excellent support. Her advocacy for wellness contributed to policy changes here and she is the most pleasant person you can hope to ever meet. As a consultant she performed her role with competence, grace, and charm. She will be missed around here.
 
Dustin’s 6 ½ year here have seen him expertly fulfill many roles with aplomb. He brought a sophistication and professionalism to our multimedia efforts, managing complex audio/video shoots and building our capabilities in elearning customization. Dustin could always be counted on to give you to guide you to the best solution. His desire to wow our clients by doing the extra step or thinking outside of the box was a value add to LCW.
 
We have been working to transition Emani’s work over the past week. We will communicate Dustin’s arrangement later this week.
 
Join me in wishing the two of them the best on the next chapters of their careers.
 
Chuck
 
 
Chuck Adams
 
(He/Him)
Co-CEO and Managing Principal
LCW

subject: FW: LCW// CHL  2023-2024 DEI Program Deliverables
body:
Hi Emani,
 
I wanted to send a note to let you know I got pulled into another project today and didn’t have time to do the review I planned on our work together. I will plan to get back to you by Tuesday next week.
 
I appreciate the flexibility. Have a nice weekend!
 
Thanks,
Ann
 
From:
 Ann Odens 
Sent:
 Wednesday, October 11, 2023 12:16 PM
To:
 Emani Richmond <e.richmond@lcwmail.com>; Sarah Nodarse <s.nodarse@lcwmail.com>
Subject:
 RE: LCW// CHL 2023-2024 DEI Program Deliverables
 
Hi Emani,
 
Thank you for pulling together details of our planning and sharing the roll-out plan. I will review all materials by Friday afternoon and get back to you with any questions.
 
I’m excited to continue the progress with our staff.
 
Thank you,
Ann
 
 
From:
 Emani Richmond <
e.richmond@lcwmail.com
> 
Sent:
 Wednesday, October 11, 2023 10:10 AM
To:
 Ann Odens <
ann@childrensheartlink.org
>
Cc:
 Sarah Nodarse <
s.nodarse@lcwmail.com
>
Subject:
 LCW// CHL 2023-2024 DEI Program Deliverables
 
Hi Ann, 
 
I hope you are well as the team nears your HUGE fundraising event. After collaborating with the LCW team last week we were able to compile each of the needed Discussion/ Participant guides, eLearning links, and subsequent materials to complete the deliverables for the 2023-2024 DEI programming we have slated for you folks.
 
Please take your time reviewing the materials, my only ask is that you open each link to double check they are exactly what you need and please download and save any file I have sent because the DropBox Transfer links expire after a certain date that I am not able to extend. 
 
This link will direct you to the presentation I walked you through about a week ago. 
https://www.dropbox.com/t/r9yNj289lqigB4Jf
 
The presentation details:
-
        
The DEI Programming we completed last year
-
        
Our deliverables for 2023-2024
-
        
And a rollout schedule
 
Here is the tentative rollout schedule I have organized for CHL. I mention that this timeline is tentative because after you rollout the eLearning internally folks may want a few extra weeks to complete it or continue discussions internally before the next activity is moved forward. 
 
November
Project Kickoff; reminder of DEI activities completed last year (using supporting presentation linked above)
Refresher-Self-Directed eLearning: Introduction to Managing Unconscious Bias (IMUB)
Set Intercultural Competence goals 
as individuals and a staff
December
Toolkit: Leader-Led IMUB Discussion Guide
Link to Dropbox Transfer file so you can access the Discussion Guide
https://www.dropbox.com/t/sZVx9WKyFOlw3elU
Toolkit discussion during Monthly All-Staff
January
Self-Directed eLearning: 
Managing with Intercultural Competence 
(20 minutes)
eLearning module to be completed before next All-Staff
February
Facilitated Workshop: 
Understanding Microaggressions 
Workshop (2 hours) 
We will be in contact with you in December about getting this training date on the calendar
March
Debrief learnings from Understanding Microaggressions Workshop
Toolkit: 
Post IDI- Debrief Accountability Plan
Attached to email named ‘Post IDI- Debrief- Accountability Plan…’
April + Ongoing
Discuss progress made towards the Post IDI- Debrief Accountability Plan
IDI Assessment 
as needed for new staff(30 min)
 
eLearning Links:
 
IMUB- Introduction to Managing Unconscious Bias – 
https://app.cloud.scorm.com/sc/InvitationConfirmEmail?publicInvitationId=dd5f28b9-f9fe-4b63-9fd1-d5c1e02d1967
 
MIC- Managing with Intercultural Competence – 
https://app.cloud.scorm.com/sc/InvitationConfirmEmail?publicInvitationId=d391aab2-1abf-4696-87da-dff7cef7bbff
 
The links are active until March 31
st
 so your staff can retake them as much as they would like between now and then
When logging in participants will be asked to include their 
email address
 and their 
name
, that is how participation is tracked
You have purchased 20 seats to each eLearning, so once 20 unique users log in the links will no longer be active
You can request a status update from us at any time to track the status of completion for the staff
 
I think that sums up the whole kitchen sink! I look forward to CHL receiving this program over the next few months. 
 
Again, please send any questions my way.
 
Best,
 
Emani Richmond
(she/her/hers)
Consultant
LCW

subject: Join SIETAR USA's November 8, 2023 Webinar!
body:
The Art of Icebreakers: How to Engage and Inspire Your Workshop Participants ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌
 
 
View in Web Browser
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
WEBINAR: 
'The Art of Icebreakers: How to Engage and Inspire Your Workshop Participants'
 
 
 
 
 
November 8, 2023 @ 11:30 AM (Eastern)
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Icebreakers are a critical component to any training workshop. When conducted properly, they are able to draw participants in, engage them and excite them for what comes next. Icebreakers also serve to provide reflection and a deeper introduction to the content of the workshops. As the holidays approach with the hustle and bustle of the season, let’s convene for some fun and to learn best practices to conduct and debrief icebreakers, especially in a virtual setting. What works, what doesn’t? Come and learn from experienced professionals and share your seasonal traditions and get energized for the holiday season. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Non-member registration 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Member Registration 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Unsubscribe
 | Sent by SIETAR USA 
PO Box 548 • Wheaton, IL • 60187

Subject:
 [EXT] RE: DEI Spotlight on Indigenous People Graphic
 
Hello Amira,
 
Please see the attached.
 
Course Description:
 
Spotlight on Indigenous People in North America
 
Indigenous societies have flourished for thousands of years in the Americas, and their cultural contributions continue to impact modern life across North America. Today, there are over 560 federally recognized Native American tribes in the U.S. and more than 630 First Nation communities in Canada. This session investigates the complicated relationship between Indigenous communities and the government, explores the rich traditions of Indigenous peoples, and shares insight on some of the social issues Indigenous communities face today, so you can begin to understand the experience of your Indigenous talent, clients, and market.
 
 
Objectives
Describe key experiences that affect your Indigenous people colleagues.
Consider strategies for productively working with your Indigenous people, colleagues and communities.
Apply what we’ve learned in the session to promote inclusion at your workplace and connect more effectively with Indigenous clients and markets.
 
Please let me know if you need anything else. 
 
Best,
 
Emani Richmond
(she/her/hers)
Consultant

Hello Amira,
 
Please see the attached.
 
Course Description:
 
Spotlight on Indigenous People in North America
 
Indigenous societies have flourished for thousands of years in the Americas, and their cultural contributions continue to impact modern life across North America. Today, there are over 560 federally recognized Native American tribes in the U.S. and more than 630 First Nation communities in Canada. This session investigates the complicated relationship between Indigenous communities and the government, explores the rich traditions of Indigenous peoples, and shares insight on some of the social issues Indigenous communities face today, so you can begin to understand the experience of your Indigenous talent, clients, and market.
 
 
Objectives
Describe key experiences that affect your Indigenous people colleagues.
Consider strategies for productively working with your Indigenous people, colleagues and communities.
Apply what we’ve learned in the session to promote inclusion at your workplace and connect more effectively with Indigenous clients and markets.
 
Please let me know if you need anything else.

subject: Can this supplement help you sleep?
body:
TikTok's latest obsession, ashwagandha, is credited with improving sleep and reducing stress.
View this email in your browser.
 
Presented by CVS Health
Does ashwagandha really help with sleep?
October 12, 2023
 
If social media had its way, your medicine cabinet would be overflowing with supplements. TikTok’s latest must-have: ashwagandha. The herb is credited with 
boosting energy and focus
, improving 
sleep
, and reducing stress. Research says it may live up to some of the hype.
 
What is ashwagandha?
A mainstay of Ayurvedic medicine—an ancient Indian holistic healing system—ashwagandha is made from a shrub found in India and Africa that is formulated into teas, powders, and capsules. Ashwagandha is considered an adaptogen—a plant substance that helps regulate cortisol, which, in turn, can reduce the body’s stress response. 
What are the benefits?
The most solid research around ashwagandha shows that it can reduce your body's stress response, help ease anxiety, and 
improve brain function
.
 
Does ashwagandha improve sleep?
Despite how commonly the supplement is used for sleep, there’s not a lot of evidence to show that it helps. A study of just 50 adults found that taking ashwagandha every day for 12 weeks improved sleep. Another 2019 study found that a twice-daily dose of ashwagandha led to a reduction in anxiety and improved sleep. 
If stress or mild anxiety is getting in between you and sleep, ashwagandha could be helpful in reducing anxiety, which may facilitate a better night’s rest—at least according to this limited research.
How much ashwagandha is safe to take?
Up to about 500 milligrams per day is considered safe for most adults, according to the Cleveland Clinic, but the dosage depends on what form you’re taking it in and what you’re taking it for. As with all supplements, it’s best to check with your doctor, who can help you sidestep potential drug interactions, and recommend the right dose or an alternative.
What are the side effects of ashwagandha?
 
Though ashwagandha is generally safe for most adults, according the NIH, it can cause side effects including diarrhea, drowsiness, headache, and upset stomach.
 
Some people can have liver problems when taking ashwagandha, especially if they’re taking it with other medications metabolized in the liver. Women who are pregnant or breastfeeding should avoid taking ashwagandha.
 
Should you take a supplement for sleep?
Dr. Jennifer Martin, a psychologist and immediate past president of the American Academy of Sleep Medicine does not recommend taking ashwagandha or any supplements for sleep issues. Instead, she says, people should get their 
sleep hygiene
 in order. 
Good sleep hygiene means ensuring your bedroom is dark, quiet, and 
cool
; going to bed and waking up around the same time; cutting back on exposure to bright light before bed, and  reducing stress that may be affecting your sleep.
  
Read the full article 
here
.

From robotic boots to synthetic blood,

’s annual list of health innovators highlights contributions from a wide range of fields.

subject: Well+Being: Hope fatigue, a medical mystery and coffee
body:
A simple routine for more youthful skin 
‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  
 
 
 
PUBLISHED BY
READ ONLINE
 | 
SIGN UP
 
Expert advice to help you live well every day. 
 
(Abbey Lossing for The Washington Post)
 
 
Tara Parker-Pope 
Happy Thursday. This week we’re writing about a medical mystery, impostor syndrome and coffee metabolism, and we’ve got our weekly “joy” snack. But before that …
This week’s must-reads:
Was it wedding jitters that were making her sick?
 Read our newest 
Medical Mystery.
Are you suffering from impostor syndrome? 
Here’s advice on
 
overcoming it.
California isn’t banning Skittles.
 But what is known as the “Skittles ban” does target 
four additives.
What’s your coffee metabolism?
 Why some people can drink coffee 
all day long.
Mary Lou Retton has severe pneumonia.
 Here’s what 
to know.
How to cope when there’s so much bad news
Earlier this week, I woke up feeling rested and well, with my dog quietly snoozing beside me. I felt ready to start my day.
ADVERTISEMENT
 
 
 
 
And then, I remembered. The headlines and devastating videos from the war between Israel and Gaza surfaced in my mind. The earthquake in Afghanistan. The war in Ukraine. My momentary lightness disappeared, and the anxiety of it all returned to my gut, welled up in my chest and forced my eyes shut again. I hugged my dog, wishing for a better world.
Psychologist Lesley Alderman says her patients have consistently told her they have grown weary of bad news. They have wanted to feel like life would return to normal after years of pandemic living, only to conclude that “normal” isn’t what it used to be.
Alderman has noticed that her patients are experiencing a “deficit of optimism,” feeling overwhelmed and anxious about important issues far beyond their control. She called it “hope fatigue,” and the symptoms include feeling anxious, a need to tune out or feeling like giving up.
Alderman notes that dwelling on issues that seem unfixable can lead to an “anxious paralysis,” but she says there is hope. She outlines eight steps to help ease your anxiety when world events — or even personal ones — are out of your control.
Take a break from the news. 
“I advise patients who are feeling depressed by the headlines to read the news just once a day, turn off alerts on their phone and, if possible, check social media sparingly.”
Take care of yourself.
 “I tell my patients: You have to be in good fighting shape to cope with the current turbulence.” That means boosting your resilience by sleeping, eating and exercising well and engaging in life-affirming activities.
Focus on the present. 
Get in the habit of anchoring yourself in the here and now. Fretting about the future is not helpful.
Try a breathing exercise.
 Take a few deep breaths. Inhale to the count of five and exhale to the count of five. It will help calm your sympathetic nervous system (the fight-or-flight response) and lower your anxiety.
Think about your victories. 
Remind yourself of what’s working well in your life — whether it’s your job, friendships or something else.
Be your own therapist.
 Ask yourself, “What do I specifically feel hopeless about and why?” Being able to put into words what’s getting you down can help you feel less flooded by emotions and better able to process the information rationally.
Take action. 
Worrying doesn’t help one’s mental health, but taking action does.
Join forces with a friend. 
Pick a cause. There are hundreds of nonprofits dedicated to addressing some of the most tenacious challenges on the planet. Donate money or volunteer.
These steps won’t ease the suffering of others or solve a geopolitical crisis or end a war. But they will help you manage your anxiety, be more present for yourself and others and, hopefully, take action to make your community better.
“Look around your community,” Alderman writes. “Maybe your local playground would benefit from a basketball court, or your church or synagogue could sponsor a refugee family. When people engage in local issues, they have a renewed sense of optimism.”
Read more about hope fatigue and what you can do about it.
 
(Celia Jacobs for The Washington Post)
Advice
 
8 ways to feel less anxious about things beyond your control
How to feel less anxious and hopeless about climate change, the war in Ukraine and other things beyond your control.
By Lesley Alderman, LCSW
Read more
 
 
 
(Abbey Lossing for The Washington Post)
How much sunshine are you getting?
One simple thing we can do for both mental and physical health is spend a little time outdoors in the sunshine. In many places, fall is one of the best seasons for spending time outdoors — there’s plenty of sunshine, mild temperatures and gorgeous fall foliage.
The typical person is outside for far fewer hours in the day than was the case generations ago, said Richard Weller, a professor of dermatology at the University of Edinburgh.
“Until the Industrial Revolution, 150 years ago, we have lived our entire evolutionary history outdoors all day, every day,” he said. “What is abnormal is that we now spend our lives inside and briefly pop outside.”
But exposure to daylight has been shown to help boost the body’s production of vitamin D, mitigate digital eyestrain, regulate a person’s circadian rhythm and increase alertness and mood.
Stepping outside in the morning, within the first few hours after waking up, is the most important signal you can send to your body’s circadian clock. Depending on what time you have to get to work, the timing of a sunny morning walk may not be possible, but there’s always the weekend.
Sunshine has been in the news lately because many Apple watches that count our steps and check our heart rates can now keep track of our sunlight exposure. To learn more, read the full report.
 
(Washington Post Illustration; iStock)
How much sunshine are you getting? Now your watch can keep track.
Daylight exposure has been shown to boost alertness, mood and the body’s production of vitamin D, mitigate eye strain and regulate a person’s circadian rhythm.
By Teddy Amenabar
Read more
 
 
A simple routine for more youthful skin
This week a reader is looking for a simple, affordable prescription that will help keep skin more youthful. Our Ask a Doctor columnist, Trisha S. Pasricha, did a deep dive into the medical research on skin care and came up with a surprising, simple morning and evening routine. You can read about it here.
And use our 
Ask a Doctor form
 to submit a question, and we may answer it in a future column.
 
(Washington Post illustration; iStock)
Advice
 
The simple, science-backed routine for more youthful skin
No matter your age, taking care of your skin doesn’t have to be expensive.
By Trisha Pasricha, MD
Read more
 
 
Find your joy snack!
Here are a few things that brought us joy this week.
We can’t stop thinking about these crispy potatoes with a creamy chimichurri sauce that starts with parsley and cashews. 
Watch this TikTok video
 and then go straight to your kitchen.
The Voraciously team is celebrating National Book Month by 
pairing great books with great food
. There’s key lime pie to enjoy with Nora Ephron’s “Heartburn.” Or enjoy a mint julep while reading “The Great Gatsby.” Call your book club friends and enjoy one of these nine recipes inspired by great literary meals.
This record-setting 2,749 pound pumpkin is 
named Michael Jordan.
It was the year of the sow! The ladies dominated Fat Bear Week this year. 
Meet the winner: Grazer
. She’s got blonde ears, a bodacious bod and a reputation for being a warrior mother, writes our fat-bear expert, Natalie B. Compton. You’ll love Natalie’s report and an accompanying YouTube video of Grazer in action.
And if you haven’t gotten enough fat-bear news, here’s one of my 
favorite Your Move columns
. Gretchen Reynolds explores the science of the beachball-shaped bruins and how understanding their hibernation can help us learn more about diabetes, muscle atrophy and inactivity.
Want to know more about “joy” snacks? Our Brain Matters columnist 
Richard Sima explains.
 
Y
ou can also 
read this story as a comic
.
Please let us know how we are doing. Email me at 
wellbeing@washpost.com
. You can also 
find us on TikTok.

 Emani Richmond <e.richmond@lcwmail.com>
Subject:
 Carta Session
 
Dear Emani
 
I wrote a message directed to you and Leslie. Please let me know if you think we should forward it to her.
 
This session was literally the worst training I have ever delivered because I had prepared the material for a different audience. 
The way to present about cultural differences in a session with mixed audience is comparing cultures, with no focus in any.
 
For me, the worst thing was not the questioning, because if you present about a subject that your audience feels their expertise on the subject equals yours, you should expect questioning.
 
The worst was to feel the audience believed I was offering munition to the American team to attack them. At some point, discussing racism with a high middle class white audience, I was so uncomfortable that I lost what I was saying and repeated myself like crazy. 
 
I would like to send this also to Randall and Rebecca, because I wouldn´t like them to hear about it from somebody else, but first I would like to hear your opinion.
 
Best
Lucy

Corporate Equity center & the museum, develops programming in the historic aspects of the community and that relates to the basis of the programming at the museum creating the through line of the history of slavey and oppression how does that relate to communities and systems now and where are some of these inequities rooted 
And I attended the DEI Summit last year and I learned a lot and I’m excited to be on the planning committee
Sounds like you have a good understanding of what this ask is

nd
 & 10:15 am EST

We love examples that you have w/ case studies it’s an opportunity where you grab people a

Folks love tools they can take away from this experience and we can potentially work long-teem w/ them 
Depending on what role you would like for us to play we can play that role 
 
What would success look like in the conference so we can build our content to support the content
Theme: We are resilient,  
We understand the challenges associated with DEI work how exhausting that can be to defending Equity when people don’t believe it’s necessary, we hope people leave the conference w/ a greater sense of community and have more tools in their toolbelt 
How do we restore ourselves wellness, knowledge and skills what can folks take away w/ them to move forward in the work when there’s so many things working against them 
 
Training before this session: 
The journey to Belonging
What does it mean to belong, and then we come in w/ the tools for how to get to that end state

Us to receive the agenda

TOGETHER WITH MIRO
The Challenge Bowl
  
 
The Challenge Bowl
 is a fun and easy way for team members to answer questions and complete short activities to deepen team bonds.
Pick one item from the Challenge Bowl each day to liven up daily meetings or run through the entire board to engage your team during virtual team lunches or happy hours.
How it Works:
 
🗣️ You'll need a logged-in facilitator to reveal hidden frames
📝 Each team member takes turns selecting a challenge (numbered sticky note from the bowl). 
Tip:
 Use the color key to determine whether you select a silly question, thoughtful question, or a short activity.
✅ The facilitator reveals the challenge and team members must answer a question or complete the activity before moving on to the next item.
Be prepared for some fun, giggles, and even some deep thinking. You can even customize the template to create your own Team Challenge Bowl tailored for your team.
  
🙌

Hello,

A QR code was provided for self directed technical assistance however I was not able to resolve the issue on my own. This matter is extremely URGENT as I cannot even turn my computer on without receiving this message.

Subject:
 [EXT] RE: DEI Spotlight on Indigenous People Graphic
 
Hello Amira,
 
Please see the attached.
 
Course Description:
 
Spotlight on Indigenous People in North America
 
Indigenous societies have flourished for thousands of years in the Americas, and their cultural contributions continue to impact modern life across North America. Today, there are over 560 federally recognized Native American tribes in the U.S. and more than 630 First Nation communities in Canada. This session investigates the complicated relationship between Indigenous communities and the government, explores the rich traditions of Indigenous peoples, and shares insight on some of the social issues Indigenous communities face today, so you can begin to understand the experience of your Indigenous talent, clients, and market.
 
 
Objectives
Describe key experiences that affect your Indigenous people colleagues.
Consider strategies for productively working with your Indigenous people, colleagues and communities.
Apply what we’ve learned in the session to promote inclusion at your workplace and connect more effectively with Indigenous clients and markets.
 
Please let me know if you need anything else. 
 
Best,
 
Emani Richmond
(she/her/hers)

body:

From:
 Emani Richmond <e.richmond@lcwmail.com> 
Sent:
 Tuesday, October 10, 2023 5:49 PM
To:
 Emani Richmond <e.richmond@lcwmail.com>
Subject:
 2023 DEI Summit & LCW- mtg. w/ Ozakh 
 
We can talk about the conference, our background + case studies
 
Audience: 350 people, this is what we are seeing, we are known for our clients, we create all of our trainings in house we can deliver it in any language
Who is attending which companies: broad ( a lot of ATL representation, many different HQs (Insight Global will be hosting them at their HQ)
Higer Ed, folks in non-profits, Tech firms Black Bod, Delta (Sponsor) VA Tech, City representations, Google, North Western Mutual, Ulta and most of them have a leadership role within DEI and their organizations
 
Introductions 
Trying to find ways to engage w/ each other and bring in the lightness fun and innocence with people 
I managed Girls Inc. of Chicago, eliciting that youthfulness and susceptibility for leading
AK- I grew up in Chicago, a lot 
 
We work w/ leaders and managers understand culture and how do we succeed across cultures, being w/ companies as they are going throughout their changes, we have worked with companies that have had success
Our examples can span different parts of the market
This is less than a month away, what day would you like our assistance, we bring our own differences to the conference, we are trying to get Brand Awareness
Mining conference and we hosted panels from that perspective 
 
It’s not only helping companies and it’s also helping people get better understandings of each other
Chicago Chamber of Commerce, I know Chicago so we know she’s here
Family is Pakastani, born in in Dubai, in Memphis TN, works at the National Civil Rights Museum
Was managing program for Girls Inc, presenting at trauma-informed approach to learning and how to work w/ other people and a position came up at the National Civil Rights Museum and will focus on community engagement
 
Corporate Equity center & the museum, develops programming in the historic aspects of the community and that relates to the basis of the programming at the museum creating the through line of the history of slavey and oppression how does that relate to communities and systems now and where are some of these inequities rooted 
And I attended the DEI Summit last year and I learned a lot and I’m excited to be on the planning committee
Sounds like you have a good understanding of what this ask is
 
30-45 min of facilitated time | Nov 2
nd
 & 10:15 am EST
Can talk through case studies and the way we work w/ groups
Data or results from the work that you have done
We are implementing these sessions b/c “can we spend more time learning together “
People are engaging w/ each other and how we can uniquely support them through that challenge
Around culture and how wen can elevate our brand to be an equitable space to work
We love examples that you have w/ case studies it’s an opportunity where you grab people a
SCI model this is why… through the process of having interactions and adding metrics
Case study of learning journeys and their impact in the companies that experienced them… 
How the engagement started 
How the engagement was funded and sustained 
Challenges we encountered …
Examples to use ARCH program, J&J work, Heritage programming 
***What are the 3 top takeaways that will be in the session 
We delivered on the SCI model… 
Last year the summit’s focus was on data and how do we translate data to cultural shifts and we can speak to this and lead folks through this 
Folks love tools they can take away from this experience and we can potentially work long-teem w/ them 
Depending on what role you would like for us to play we can play that role 
 
What would success look like in the conference so we can build our content to support the content
Theme: We are resilient,  
We understand the challenges associated with DEI work how exhausting that can be to defending Equity when people don’t believe it’s necessary, we hope people leave the conference w/ a greater sense of community and have more tools in their toolbelt 
How do we restore ourselves wellness, knowledge and skills what can folks take away w/ them to move forward in the work when there’s so many things working against them 
 
Training before this session: 
The journey to Belonging
What does it mean to belong, and then we come in w/ the tools for how to get to that end state 
 
Action Items:
Us to receive the agenda 
Send Lori an outline of what the presentation will look like
Can send cell in the chat and I feel like what you deliver will be phenomenal …
Will send the form for speakers to complete (for , room for headshot + bios will ask that you share some takeaways like walk up music
Will allow us to se hotels that are blocks at (Hyatt Place $129/ night)

ica@infolink.com.br
 <
ica@infolink.com.br
> 
Sent:
 Tuesday, October 10, 2023 2:16 PM
To:
 Emani Richmond <
e.richmond@lcwmail.com
>
Subject:
 Feedback
 
Hello Emani
 
I would like to approach what just happened today and share with you my perspective.
 
We prepared this training with some questions listed by Carta and others that focus on cultural differences between Americans and Brazilians, mainly the ones where the problems come from. An intercultural training aims to uncover what is hidden, making it easier to understand.
 
I didn´t know it was a mixed session, with Brazilians and Americans, and already at the training, I didn´t know most of the audience was made of Brazilians. 
 
The Brazilians there were sensitive to be the subject of the session, feeling they were observed and judged. If there are problems in this relationship, a training designed for Americans to understand cultural differences, pointing at questions that are usually reported as “problems”, must have felt as giving Americans munition against Brazilians. 
 
The slide about CLT and At Will uncovered a difficult question as it states that there is no solution, as the law guarantees the rights of Brazilian workers. The example of the copying machine was not good for the Brazilian audience because it is a reality, it´s like putting the finger on the wound.  
 
The word “jeitinho” is an old expression, meaning to find a way to go around a problem.  It´s at anthropological studies about the Brazilian culture meaning flexibility, with its good and dark sides.
At this session it represented unspoken questions. It revealed problems that were not related to the training, and it became a way to for the Brazilians to represent their dissatisfaction with the situation. 
 
I have had many sessions for mixed audiences, but if there is tension involved, in has to be prepared in another way. 
 
Is it possible that you send me the comments at the chat? Let´s sleep on what happened and talk again.
 
Kisses
Lucy

subject: Accepted: Advancing inclusion HR- Cohorte 3 // CCMP Kick-Off
War in the workplace
body:
Uber's ex-diversity chief shares lessons from the Israel-Palestine conflict in 2021.
View this email in your browser.
   
Uber’s response to the 2021 Israel-Palestine conflict is a master class for companies taking a stand on the war
October 11, 2023
 
Good afternoon.
It’s been said time and time again that, more recently, employees expect their senior leadership to speak up about high-profile and political issues. The escalating war in Israel is the latest geopolitical conflict to find its way into corporate America.
 
JPMorgan Chase CEO Jamie Dimon and Goldman Sachs’s David Solomon are among the chief executives who’ve 
condemned the attacks
 against Israel, expressing their 
solidarity with the country
, and many employers have circulated internal memos to staffers addressing the matter.
“All of us at Goldman Sachs are thinking of you and your families in the face of this shocking aggression directed at the people of Israel,” Solomon told employees in a Sunday memo obtained by CNN.
At 
Fortune
’s Most Powerful Women Summit this week, I spoke to countless Fortune 500 chief diversity and human resources officers who confirmed their companies had shared statements supporting Jewish colleagues. However, public statements appear muted as companies find themselves, yet again, navigating a relatively new terrain in which they feel moved but ill-equipped to react to all current events and human tragedy.
Communicating clearly and ingenuously can be challenging for leaders, who fear alienating or offending their employees and consumers if they get it wrong. But remaining silent can be read as insensitive and overly cautious, 
Fortune
’s Lila MacLellan writes in a piece that offers guidance from communications experts on how businesses should respond to the humanitarian crisis in the Middle East. “Be sure to acknowledge innocent lives lost and hardship on both sides,” Randall Peterson, a professor of organizational behavior at London Business School, told 
Fortune
 in an email. Additional guidance: Avoid sending such messages on platforms like Slack, where employees may unwittingly or intentionally foment conversation that stirs tension.
Uber’s former chief diversity, equity, and inclusion officer, Bo Young Lee, shared her insight Tuesday in 
a LinkedIn post
 that I think is worth sharing in full.
In it, Lee recounted the 2021 escalation of violence between Israel and Palestine, stating, “About half the messages I received demanded that the company support the BDS (Boycott, Divest, Sanction) movement, while the other half demanded we stand with Israel. Interestingly, our employees who lived in the region of conflict were remarkably quiet. It was a tough situation to be in with very little space to navigate without pissing someone off.”
She acknowledged that the dynamics in the Middle East are long-standing conflicts that even the most knowledgeable historians and peace negotiators find difficult to decipher. “I wasn’t arrogant to think we knew better than experts in the field.” 
At the time, the company took four steps:
1.
 It asked employees why they shared their concerns with the DEI function and the reactions they sought.
2.
 It held listening sessions with employees to help them process their emotions.
3.
 Her team contacted external experts specializing in religion in the workplace to glean what they were hearing.
4.
 Uber created a rubric to help the company determine next steps. Core rubric questions included: Do the events affect Uber’s business, employees, or partners? Will taking a stance help Uber serve its customers, earners, employees, or community stakeholders? Is this an area in which Uber has expertise? Are the suggested actions consistent with Uber’s values? Can Uber’s voice make a material impact on the event’s outcome?
Ultimately, she said, the company decided to host educational sessions for employees through its interfaith ERG to help folks gain context and understanding.
This certainly won’t be the last geopolitical conflict employees expect their organizations to lend their voice to, so I’m curious to hear from diversity practitioners: While the ongoing devastation is markedly different from that of 2021, how are you addressing the war internally? Shoot me an email at ruth.umoh@fortune.com.
Ruth Umoh
@ruthumohnews
ruth.umoh@fortune.com
What’s Trending
 
Talk it out
. It’s tempting to avoid any discussion of violence in the Middle East, a complex topic about which people have strong feelings, but 
it’s imperative that leaders do so
, says Richard Edelman, CEO of global communications firm Edelman Associates. 
Fortune
Redefining the top
. A stale definition of leadership plagues corporate America, said Coqual CEO Lanaya Irvin at the 2023 Most Powerful Women conference. One area it shows up is in board recruitment, where companies solely tap members with CEO and CFO experience, narrowing the field to mostly white men. 
Fortune
Political football. 
Companies are increasingly wary of wading into hairy issues that could get customers and lawmakers riled up ahead of the 2024 elections. Per Axios, 66% of Americans last year approved of corporations’ involvement in ending racial discrimination. Their support dropped to 57% this year. 
Axios
 
How will generative AI affect you?
 
Fortune Brainstorm AI convenes on Dec. 11-12
Join Fortune for the third annual Brainstorm AI conference to delve into the hype and hysteria. Explore AI's potential to mimic human behavior and the far-reaching implications as it advances. 
 
Click here to learn more
 
The Big Think 
 
Companies that speak candidly about their struggles promoting racial diversity are viewed as more trustworthy and committed to equity than those that remain silent, 
according to research
 published by the American Psychological Association. Contrary to popular belief, such actions are perceived as gesticulation that companies are transparent and genuinely care about DEI.
 
 
Thanks for reading.

this email
, pay it forward. Share it with someone you know:
 
Did someone share this with you? 
Sign up here
. For previous editions, 
click here
.
To view all of 
Fortune
's newsletters on the latest in business, 
go here
. 
Subscribe
 
This email was sent to e.richmond@lcwmail.com 
 
Manage subscriptions or 
unsubscribe here
 
Fortune Media (USA) Corporation
40 Fulton Street New York, NY. 10038

body:

From:
 ica@infolink.com.br <ica@infolink.com.br> 
Sent:
 Tuesday, October 10, 2023 2:16 PM
To:
 Emani Richmond <e.richmond@lcwmail.com>
Subject:
 Feedback
 
Hello Emani
 
I would like to approach what just happened today and share with you my perspective.
 
We prepared this training with some questions listed by Carta and others that focus on cultural differences between Americans and Brazilians, mainly the ones where the problems come from. An intercultural training aims to uncover what is hidden, making it easier to understand.
 
I didn´t know it was a mixed session, with Brazilians and Americans, and already at the training, I didn´t know most of the audience was made of Brazilians. 
 
The Brazilians there were sensitive to be the subject of the session, feeling they were observed and judged. If there are problems in this relationship, a training designed for Americans to understand cultural differences, pointing at questions that are usually reported as “problems”, must have felt as giving Americans munition against Brazilians. 
 
The slide about CLT and At Will uncovered a difficult question as it states that there is no solution, as the law guarantees the rights of Brazilian workers. The example of the copying machine was not good for the Brazilian audience because it is a reality, it´s like putting the finger on the wound.  
 
The word “jeitinho” is an old expression, meaning to find a way to go around a problem.  It´s at anthropological studies about the Brazilian culture meaning flexibility, with its good and dark sides.
At this session it represented unspoken questions. It revealed problems that were not related to the training, and it became a way to for the Brazilians to represent their dissatisfaction with the situation. 
 
I have had many sessions for mixed audiences, but if there is tension involved, in has to be prepared in another way. 
 
Is it possible that you send me the comments at the chat? Let´s sleep on what happened and talk again.
 
Kisses
Lucy

subject: LCW// CHL  2023-2024 DEI Program Deliverables
body:
Hi Ann, 
 
I hope you are well as the team nears your HUGE fundraising event. After collaborating with the LCW team last week we were able to compile each of the needed Discussion/ Participant guides, eLearning links, and subsequent materials to complete the deliverables for the 2023-2024 DEI programming we have slated for you folks.
 
Please take your time reviewing the materials, my only ask is that you open each link to double check they are exactly what you need and please download and save any file I have sent because the DropBox Transfer links expire after a certain date that I am not able to extend. 
 
This link will direct you to the presentation I walked you through about a week ago. 
https://www.dropbox.com/t/r9yNj289lqigB4Jf
 
The presentation details:
-
        
The DEI Programming we completed last year
-
        
Our deliverables for 2023-2024
-
        
And a rollout schedule
 
Here is the tentative rollout schedule I have organized for CHL. I mention that this timeline is tentative because after you rollout the eLearning internally folks may want a few extra weeks to complete it or continue discussions internally before the next activity is moved forward. 
 
November
Project Kickoff; reminder of DEI activities completed last year (using supporting presentation linked above)
Refresher-Self-Directed eLearning: Introduction to Managing Unconscious Bias (IMUB)
Set Intercultural Competence goals 
as individuals and a staff
December
Toolkit: Leader-Led IMUB Discussion Guide
Link to Dropbox Transfer file so you can access the Discussion Guide
https://www.dropbox.com/t/sZVx9WKyFOlw3elU
Toolkit discussion during Monthly All-Staff
January
Self-Directed eLearning: 
Managing with Intercultural Competence 
(20 minutes)
eLearning module to be completed before next All-Staff
February
Facilitated Workshop: 
Understanding Microaggressions 
Workshop (2 hours) 
We will be in contact with you in December about getting this training date on the calendar
March
Debrief learnings from Understanding Microaggressions Workshop
Toolkit: 
Post IDI- Debrief Accountability Plan
Attached to email named ‘Post IDI- Debrief- Accountability Plan…’
April + Ongoing
Discuss progress made towards the Post IDI- Debrief Accountability Plan
IDI Assessment 
as needed for new staff(30 min)
 
eLearning Links:
 
IMUB- Introduction to Managing Unconscious Bias – 
https://app.cloud.scorm.com/sc/InvitationConfirmEmail?publicInvitationId=dd5f28b9-f9fe-4b63-9fd1-d5c1e02d1967
 
MIC- Managing with Intercultural Competence – 
https://app.cloud.scorm.com/sc/InvitationConfirmEmail?publicInvitationId=d391aab2-1abf-4696-87da-dff7cef7bbff
 
The links are active until March 31
st
 so your staff can retake them as much as they would like between now and then
When logging in participants will be asked to include their 
email address
 and their 
name
, that is how participation is tracked
You have purchased 20 seats to each eLearning, so once 20 unique users log in the links will no longer be active
You can request a status update from us at any time to track the status of completion for the staff
 
I think that sums up the whole kitchen sink! I look forward to CHL receiving this program over the next few months. 
 
Again, please send any questions my way.
 
Best,
 
Emani Richmond

subject: Why Anti-Racism Activists Need Screenshots
body:
Another day, another form of emotional labour  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌
Forwarded this email? 
Subscribe here
 for more
Thank you for joining the Sharon’s Anti-Racism Newsletter community. A gentle reminder that a 
paid subscription
 supports the work of writing and publishing. Alternatively, you can make a one-off contribution to newsletter running costs via my 
Ko-Fi page
. 
Why Anti-Racism Activists Need Screenshots
Another day, another form of emotional labour
Sharon Hurley Hall
Oct 11
 
READ IN APP
 
Hello friends,
Today I’m going to talk about one of the unseen bits of the labour that lived experience activists do - screenshotting those who leave bigoted, racist and harmful comments on our social media posts.
I know many of my fellow activists do it as a matter of course, every time they create a post and for most of the comments on it. I don’t do it as often as I should, but I’ve had cause to be grateful for the diligence of others many times over.
Why is this necessary? There are a few reasons. 
Refer a friend
Toxicity, Targeting and “Dirty Deleting”
First, because when we talk about racism, bigotry and discrimination we are often gaslit by people who don’t understand all the nuances. They’ll look at something we post, jump to the wrong conclusion about our motivation, and weigh in with ill-informed and harmful replies. Inevitably, once the first person does that, others will pile on, quickly creating a toxic and harmful space for the original creator. 
If they get challenged, rather than be accountable, the offenders will often “dirty delete” their comment or post, so the harm they did can’t be easily found. That leaves subsequent commenters wondering wtf is going on, and it’s where screenshots help to provide the original context. 
Second, because in that same situation, people who face isms are often targeted by those who hate them, and might end up with their content hidden or suppressed. Having the screenshots gives them an option to take it to the “jury of LinkedIn” so to speak - their network - and have those folx help to get the content reinstated. And having that evidence can also help others fight your corner is multiple bad-faith reports result in your account being restricted, temporarily suspended or permanently banned.
Upgrade to paid
That also applies in the case of algorithmic bias, because if LinkedIn’s human reviewers can’t spot a dog whistle, you’d better believe their automated review system can’t. That often leaves the original poster having to have long discussions to get content restored, or to get harmful content banned - having screenshots is a useful tool there, too. 
Screenshots are also helpful in identifying repeat offenders targeting people who face isms. I’ve lost count of the number of times someone’s shared a screenshot in a chat, only to be told that the same person had been stirring up trouble on multiple people’s profiles. 
Surely, There’s A Better Way?
While I see the usefulness of screenshotting, it’s another task which takes time and emotional labour - constantly having to trawl through screenshots of people saying nasty things, being racist, being bigoted, or just being mean. And you usually experience some gaslighting as well on the posts where you have to take the screenshots.
I’d love to see platforms have better ways to handle this - to be able to pick up on dog whistles and more subtle forms of racism and bigotry, and to understand that in most cases when we report racism it exists, even if your human and AI reviewers can’t see it. Maybe one day we won’t need to screenshot every racist or bigot who crosses our digital path.
Take Action
How can you take action today? Learn more about how algorithmic bias affects Global Majority people. Netflix has a documentary titled 
Coded Bias
, and you can also follow and support the 
Algorithmic Justice League
 which pays attention to how inequality is perpetrated and perpetuated online. 
Thanks for reading
Sharon

body:
nourish your mind, sync your body with your cycle, support LGBTQ+ communities, and bond with coworkers over childhood teddy bears.
 
Issue #41 October 11, 2023 
Read in browser
 
          
TOGETHER WITH
 
    
Was this email forwarded to you by someone awesome?
You need your own — 
subscribe here for free
.
 
 
"I can accept failure, but I can't accept not trying." – Michael Jordan
FOR THE MIND
Taking Care of Your Noggin'
October 10th was World Mental Health Day
, which aims to raise awareness and have open conversations around this critical topic.
Over 1 billion people globally are affected by mental illness, so it's clear we need to keep the dialogue going to #BreakTheStigma.
Here are some ways you can honor World Mental Health Day and make caring for your mental health a regular priority:
Check in on loved ones
 and ask how they're really doing. Lend a listening ear without judgment.
Educate yourself on common conditions
 like anxiety, depression, OCD and resources available. Knowledge is power.
Do an act of kindness
 - volunteering and helping others benefits mental health.
Take time to move your body
, fuel properly, and give your mind a break from technology. Don't underestimate self-care.
Express yourself creatively
 through art, music, writing. Find healthy outlets for stress.
If you're struggling, reach out to a counselor or doctor
. Seeking help takes courage.
Practice mindfulness
 through meditation, deep breathing, yoga. Be present.
Keep a gratitude journal and focus on the positive.
Set boundaries
 and learn to say no to protect your mental energy.
Spend time outdoors
 connecting with nature.
Get adequate sleep
 for emotional regulation.
Join a support group
 to find community.
TOGETHER WITH FIGMA

FOR THE BODY
Cruising Through Your Cycle
Ladies, have you ever felt like a rollercoaster ride of emotions and energy levels throughout your menstrual cycle? Welcome to being a hormonal human!
Cycle syncing
 is matching your lifestyle to your monthly fluctuations — pretty genius, right?
Here's how it works:
In week 1 after your period
, estrogen rises up giving you vibrant energy. Maximize this time by crushing your toughest workouts and projects.
Around ovulation in week 2
, estrogen peaks leaving you feeling zen and tender. Ease up on the HIIT classes and treat yourself to restorative yoga, gentle movement, and nourishing your body with healthy fats and proteins. Did someone say avocado toast?
After ovulation in weeks 3 & 4
, progesterone relaxes those muscles to prep for menstruation. Stick to lighter workouts like walking, stretching, and prenatal yoga. Pamper yourself before your period because you deserve it!
Syncing your cycle helps minimize PMS mood swings, cramps, and hormonal chaos.
Track your cycle
 and find what works for you.
TOGETHER WITH RITUAL
Essential for Women 18+ Multivitamin
  
 
Feeling off your A-game?
Our friends at 
Ritual
 have the daily supplement to bring your health into focus.
Essential for Women 18+
 is a clinical-backed multivitamin specially formulated with 9 key nutrients to help fill gaps in women's diets
.
Its delayed-release capsules are designed to dissolve in the ideal absorption spot. Backed by science, Essential for Women 18+ increased vitamin D and omega-3 DHA levels by 43% and 41% respectively in a clinical trial.
Obsessive about quality, it's 
vegan, non-GMO, gluten-free and allergen-free
.
With our exclusive TA discount, 
you can enjoy 30% off your first month
 with code THEASSIST. 
Step up your health game with Ritual
FOR THE RELATIONSHIPS
National Coming Out Day
October 11th is National Coming Out Day
, an annual LGBTQ awareness celebrationhonoring when people come out as lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender, or another identity.
Coming out is a profoundly personal experience that can be difficult, exciting, scary, and liberating all at once.
If Someone Comes Out To You...
Thank them for their trust and reassure them you care about them no matter what.
Ask how you can best support them during this process.
Keep their identity private and let them decide when to tell others.
Educate yourself on LGBTQ+ experiences, but don't put the burden solely on them.
Challenge your own biases; be respectful even if you don't fully understand.
Celebrate them living as their true, authentic self.
If You're Coming Out...
Move at your own pace, and come out when you feel safe and comfortable.
Surround yourself with positive influences who support you.
Connect with LGBTQ+ community groups 
for resources
 and guidance.
Remember millions share this journey — you are not alone.
Living openly can be rewarding despite challenges. Stay strong!
FOR YOUR TEAM
A Twist on Bring Your Teddy Bear to School/Work Day
You could bring your 
teddy bear to work
, or you can try the below instead.
🧸 A fun icebreaker for your team:
Write down your favorite childhood teddy bear or toy
Put it all in a hat (or bowl)
Pick one out and start guessing who it belongs to

subject: Lowering your Medicare costs
body:
Open enrollment starts next week.
View this email in your browser.
 
Presented by CVS Health
How to lower your Medicare costs during open enrollment for 2024
October 10, 2023
 
Medicare open enrollment season is approaching—Oct. 15 to Dec. 7—when you can join, switch, or drop a 
Medicare Part D prescription drug plan
 or a private insurer’s 
Medicare Advantage
 plan for 2024. Experts say it’s vitally important to explore your options carefully.
 
 
“Every survey I’ve seen finds that year-to-year [Medicare Part D and Medicare Advantage] plan changes may offer improved coverage, lower costs, or both, to people who take the time to research next year’s plan offerings,” Phil Moeller noted in his Get What’s Yours newsletter on Medicare, Social Security, and health care.
How to compare Part D and Medicare Advantage Plans
If you’ll enroll in a Part D or Medicare Advantage plan for the first time in 2024 or might switch plans, you’ll want to do some comparison shopping.
You could do it online, either by calling Medicare (800-MEDICARE) or through 
Medicare’s Plan Finder
 tool. It lets you compare costs and coverage of various Part D and Medicare Advantage plans available where you live. 
Alternatively, you could speak with someone at your state’s 
SHIP plan
. The State Health Insurance Assistance Programs have free, unbiased advisors who can answer open enrollment questions.
Or you might 
hire a Medicare agent or broker
 who can suggest possible Part D and Part C plans and get paid by insurers. But be careful. The Centers for Medicare and Medicaid has reported a big rise in complaints about the marketing of Medicare Advantage and Part D plans, often due to their brokers.
“It’s a good idea to understand from that agent or broker whether they work with, or represent, all of the plans available in your area or only a subset,” says Schwarz. “In some situations, you won’t be presented with all the options that are available if you go through a broker.”
 
When sizing up Medicare Advantage plans to see which health care providers are in their networks, Schwarz advised doing it in this order: 
First, see if your primary care doctors and the specialists see regularly are in them. 
Then, see if your hospital of choice is in network.
Finally, look into skilled nursing facilities or long-term care rehab facilities.
 
If you’ll be comparing the cost of Medicare Advantage plans, don’t look only at their premiums. Check too at how they differ regarding copayments, co-insurance, and annual out-of-pocket maximum.
 
Read the full article 
here
.

This is less than a month away, what day would you like our assistance, we bring our own differences to the conference, we are trying to get Brand Awareness
Mining conference and we hosted panels from that perspective 
 
It’s not only helping companies and it’s also helping people get better understandings of each other
Chicago Chamber of Commerce, I know Chicago so we know she’s here
Family is Pakastani, born in in Dubai, in Memphis TN, works at the National Civil Rights Museum
Was managing program for Girls Inc, presenting at trauma-informed approach to learning and how to work w/ other people and a position came up at the National Civil Rights Museum and will focus on community engagement
 
Corporate Equity center & the museum, develops programming in the historic aspects of the community and that relates to the basis of the programming at the museum creating the through line of the history of slavey and oppression how does that relate to communities and systems now and where are some of these inequities rooted 
And I attended the DEI Summit last year and I learned a lot and I’m excited to be on the planning committee
Sounds like you have a good understanding of what this ask is
 
30-45 min of facilitated time | Nov 2
nd
 & 10:15 am EST
Can talk through case studies and the way we work w/ groups
Data or results from the work that you have done
We are implementing these sessions b/c “can we spend more time learning together “
People are engaging w/ each other and how we can uniquely support them through that challenge
Around culture and how wen can elevate our brand to be an equitable space to work
We love examples that you have w/ case studies it’s an opportunity where you grab people a
SCI model this is why… through the process of having interactions and adding metrics
Case study of learning journeys and their impact in the companies that experienced them… 
How the engagement started 
How the engagement was funded and sustained 
Challenges we encountered …
Examples to use ARCH program, J&J work, Heritage programming 
***What are the 3 top takeaways that will be in the session 
We delivered on the SCI model… 
Last year the summit’s focus was on data and how do we translate data to cultural shifts and we can speak to this and lead folks through this 
Folks love tools they can take away from this experience and we can potentially work long-teem w/ them 
Depending on what role you would like for us to play we can play that role 
 
What would success look like in the conference so we can build our content to support the content
Theme: We are resilient,  
We understand the challenges associated with DEI work how exhausting that can be to defending Equity when people don’t believe it’s necessary, we hope people leave the conference w/ a greater sense of community and have more tools in their toolbelt 
How do we restore ourselves wellness, knowledge and skills what can folks take away w/ them to move forward in the work when there’s so many things working against them 
 
Training before this session: 
The journey to Belonging
What does it mean to belong, and then we come in w/ the tools for how to get to that end state 
 
Action Items:
Us to receive the agenda 
Send Lori an outline of what the presentation will look like
Can send cell in the chat and I feel like what you deliver will be phenomenal …
Will send the form for speakers to complete (for , room for headshot + bios will ask that you share some takeaways like walk up music
Will allow us to se hotels that are blocks at (Hyatt Place $129/ night)

e.richmond@lcwmail.com
> wrote:
Hey Leslie,
 
Thank you for sending over your internal action steps. My last day with LCW will be this coming Friday. I see you requested to meet next Thursday. 
 
I can have the consultant that will be owning the relationship managing between LCW and Carta be present at that requested meeting time next Thursday. 
 
Thank you for sharing the recording of the training we hope to use it as a learning experience internally. 
 
Please let me know if you have the space to meet this coming Thursday from 12-2 pm ET?
 
Thank you,
 
Emani Richmond

 Leslie Stevens <

> 
Sent:
 Tuesday, October 10, 2023 4:05 PM
To:
 Emani Richmond <
e.richmond@lcwmail.com
>
Subject:
 Session Follow Up
 
Hi Emani - 
 
I hope you are doing well. I wanted to follow up from today's session to connect on plans for review and reflection. I know you noticed that our intention for the session and impact of the content were misaligned. The recording from today's session is included below for review and should also give you access to the transcript.
 
Internally, we are recirculating the LCW course evaluation link specifically to those in Brazil who attended the session. We are also hosting a live community safe space with the Brazil attendees next Thursday morning to process the impact of the session and to share feedback. We will pause on sharing the recording and follow up resources until we've had the time to review and process feedback and responses. 
 
Let me know what your availability looks like after Thursday to connect and process as a team. 
 
Recording
https://carta.zoom.us/rec/share/7vXQ3hOiWu6QmyDHryeZAouDy3elZk1wt4opo790JHVrwOyGtyByadfw2j-FEgg.ZmSNrXC0WUHF1beH
Passcode: &=7HcS!9
 
 
All the best,
Leslie
Leslie Stevens (she/they)
Senior DEI Manager 
Carta
New York City
 
Let's 
find time to connect
!

subject: IBI Research Review: Job satisfaction, sleep habits, mental health, and more
body:
Monthly newsletter that pulls together the latest peer-reviewed research on workforce health and productivity
 
Increased Mortality Associated with Disability Among Workers' Compensation Claimants with Upper Extremity Neuropathy
This study of workers' compensation claimants found that among claimants diagnosed with upper extremity neuropathy, increased mortality was mainly due to unintentional injuries, suicide, and cardiometabolic conditions, especially among those with more severe neuropathy and multiple limb involvement. The findings suggest upper extremity neuropathy is an independent risk factor for premature death in this injured worker population that warrants greater clinical attention and prevention efforts to mitigate this mortality risk.
The Role of Discrete Emotions in Job Satisfaction
This meta-analysis of 235 studies (N = 99,883) found that negative emotions attributing blame to the situation like depression and anxiety had the strongest negative links to overall job satisfaction, while positive emotions attributing credit to the situation like happiness and optimism had the strongest positive links. The relationships were consistent across moderators. This nuanced understanding of how distinct work-related emotions relate to overall job satisfaction evaluations highlights the importance of contextual factors in shaping employees' attitudinal reactions.
The Relationship Between Stress and Sleep Sufficiency in the Context of Varied Workplace Social Support
A survey of 2000 full-time employees found that higher stress was associated with insufficient sleep, and that the relationship between stress and sleep is moderated by supervisor and coworker support. Insufficient sleep may link stress to poor health, but the findings of this study suggest that strong workplace social support may buffer these negative impacts by promoting better sleep. Overall, the study highlights the importance of managing work stress and building supportive workplace relationships to ensure employees obtain adequate sleep.
Recognition During the Return-to-Work Process in Workers with Common Mental Disorders
A study of workers with common mental disorders found recognition by supervisors and coworkers was critical during the return-to-work process. Interviews and focus groups revealed social support and recognition facilitated recovery and reintegration, while lack of recognition or negative responses created barriers. Recognition was found to be tied to stakeholders' behaviors and attitudes and is influenced by work, health, insurance, and social systems that make them feel appreciated, valued, and respected. The research highlights the vital role recognition plays in enabling successful return to work after mental health-related absence. Training supervisors and fostering a supportive return-to-work environment are recommended.
 
+
Supporting mental health in the workplace
: To help employers better understand and support the mental health needs of their employees, IBI conducted an 
analysis 
of the impact of the pandemic on mental health. According to IBI’s analysis, fully remote (40%) and hybrid work (38%) is associated with an increased likelihood of anxiety and depression symptoms compared to in-person (35%).  
Racial Differences in Perceptions of Genetic Wellness Programs
A qualitative study of Black, White, and Asian employees found nearly all respondents saw potential benefits in workplace genetic wellness programs. However, Black respondents had profound concerns about privacy, discrimination and ethics that deterred their participation, unlike White and Asian respondents. The findings suggest genetic wellness programs could further racial health disparities unless designed to address concerns voiced by minority groups. Including diverse perspectives is key to building trust and participation in voluntary workplace genetic testing initiatives.
The Workplace Masking Experiences of Autistic, Non-autistic Neurodivergent and Neurotypical Adults in the UK
In a UK survey of autistic, non-autistic neurodivergent, and neurotypical adults, workplace masking - concealing natural behaviors to fit societal norms - was common but most prevalent among autistic adults. Key drivers included appearing professional and capable, managing interactions, and avoiding negative judgment or discrimination. Masking was linked to stress, fatigue, and poor mental wellbeing, especially for autistic people. Findings highlight the need for more open professional conduct to prevent marginalization of neurodivergent groups, better accommodations, fostering acceptance, educating colleagues, and enabling authentic self-expression.
 
 
 
 
Integrated Benefits Institute, 1901 Harrison Street, Suite 1100, Oakland, California 94612

body:
Hi Leslie, 
 
My last day at LCW will be this coming Friday. Do you have space for us to debrief sometime this week?
 
I am most available on this Thursday from 12-2:30pm ET.

subject: Feedback
body:
Hello Emani
 
I would like to approach what just happened today and share with you my perspective.
 
We prepared this training with some questions listed by Carta and others that focus on cultural differences between Americans and Brazilians, mainly the ones where the problems come from. An intercultural training aims to uncover what is hidden, making it easier to understand.
 
I didn´t know it was a mixed session, with Brazilians and Americans, and already at the training, I didn´t know most of the audience was made of Brazilians. 
 
The Brazilians there were sensitive to be the subject of the session, feeling they were observed and judged. If there are problems in this relationship, a training designed for Americans to understand cultural differences, pointing at questions that are usually reported as “problems”, must have felt as giving Americans munition against Brazilians. 
 
The slide about CLT and At Will uncovered a difficult question as it states that there is no solution, as the law guarantees the rights of Brazilian workers. The example of the copying machine was not good for the Brazilian audience because it is a reality, it´s like putting the finger on the wound.  
 
The word “jeitinho” is an old expression, meaning to find a way to go around a problem.  It´s at anthropological studies about the Brazilian culture meaning flexibility, with its good and dark sides.
At this session it represented unspoken questions. It revealed problems that were not related to the training, and it became a way to for the Brazilians to represent their dissatisfaction with the situation. 
 
I have had many sessions for mixed audiences, but if there is tension involved, in has to be prepared in another way. 
 
Is it possible that you send me the comments at the chat? Let´s sleep on what happened and talk again.
 
Kisses
Lucy

subject: 💡 stephen hawking's productivity secret
body:
start meditating while you cook, maintain your system, try being a little less busy, and read a short and sweet essay on leadership.
 
Issue #159 October 10, 2023 
Read in browser
 
          
TOGETHER WITH
 
    
Was this email forwarded to you by someone awesome?
You need your own — 
subscribe here for free
.
 
Start your morning with this affirmation:
 
 
Today’s checklist: 
Start meditating while you cook, maintain your system, try being a little less busy, and read a short and sweet essay on leadership.
LEVEL UP
A delicious approach to multi-tasking
  
You might not have time to meditate, but you’ve gotta eat, right? Even if you favor take-out on most days, chances are you cook every once in a while. 
Next time you do, try something we’d usually recommend against: Multitasking. 
Meditate while you cook.
 
Here’s a 
5-minute mindful cooking exercise from Headspace >
 
Here’s a 
15-minute mindful cooking meditation from Lasta Fasting >
TOGETHER WITH GROUPTOGETHER
Don't Forget About National Boss's Day
  
 
🗓️ Boss's Day is coming up on Oct 16th (next Monday)!
I'm sure you're already dreading having to hassle your coworkers for contributions, card signatures, and coming up with the perfect gift.
🛑 HOLD ON! 
There’s a way better way.
If you haven’t used 
GroupTogether
, it's the easiest way to collect money for a gift and create a gorgeous group card all-in-one 😍.
Just share a link and everyone can chip in and sign the card online. Then choose from 150+ eGift Cards including Amazon, Target, and more, or give the AnyCard to let the recipient choose.
It's a seamless and 
FREE
 process—
no sign-ups or downloads required
.
Elevate your boss's day effortlessly. 
👉 
Try GroupTogether Today
YOU DO YOU
Systems within systems   
In her book, 
Thinking in Systems: A Primer
, Donella H. Meadows explains systems of all kinds. You might even call it the ultimate book about systems. She discusses them in fascinating, yet complex, detail. 
We’ve skimmed the concepts to bring you some translatable tips. 
What is a system?
 
In the most broad terms, a system is a group of things that interact to achieve a unified function or purpose. 
Are YOU a system?
 
The word “system” may have cold connotations, conjuring images of computers and robots. But what if you just think of an assortment of complex factors that interplay to shape your personality, lifestyle, and goals? 
In that sense, yes; you can certainly call yourself a system. 
 
Continue reading
TOGETHER WITH FIGMA
Remedy a tough situation with this proven problem solving method
  
 
Fishbone diagrams
 are the best way to list out all of the potential 
causes and effects
 
of a specific event
.
While it's commonly used at work for process improvement and troubleshooting, you can adapt the concept of a fishbone diagram to everyday life situations, too! 
A few ways you can use it for work purposes:
Analyze 
customer complaints
 to uncover underlying issues
Investigate causes of 
project delays
Seek out factors that contribute to 
low employee productivity
Find out what's causing 
employee conflicts
Identify reasons for 
sales declines
A few ways you can use it for personal reasons:
Determine the causes of 
poor time management
Get to the root of 
financial difficulties
Learn what's behind your 
career stagnation 
(skill gaps, lack of networking, etc.)
Understand contributing factors to 
relationship issues
👉 
Try The Fishbone Diagramming Template
🔥 Pro-Tip: 
Use your 
business email
 to access hundreds of templates and invite collaborators for free! 
﻿
GET MORE SH*T DONE
Mindset: Less busy and more awesome 
In some fields, it could pay to emulate physicist Stephen Hawking’s philosophy on busyness. 
Prolific in intellectual output and world-changing discoveries, 
Hawking famously
 eschewed the sometimes false virtue of 24/7 productivity. 
He opted instead to reserve his energy and brain power for occasions when a major insight or discovery inspired work marathons. He knew that if working non-stop was his rule instead of his exception, that he wouldn’t have enough to offer those beautiful moments of discovery, which abided by no predictable schedule. 
Food for thought:
 Are there any areas of your work or life that could benefit from this mindset? If you had complete autonomy over how you spend your time, what activities would you save your best “brain time” for?
WATERCOOLER TALK
Want to better understand leadership? Read this essay 
Kanni Wignaraja, United Nations Assistant Secretary-General, wrote this 
thought piece on leadership
 after the COVID-19 pandemic, which inspired people around the globe to think about leadership less prescriptively and more adaptively. 
3 Wise Gems to Take Away:
 
Be driven by purpose instead of plans.
 Plans may be cut short or forcefully shifted by external factors. Purposes provide more lasting guidance. 
Have big ideas to make things better, but more importantly, act on them.
 Anyone can have good ideas. True leaders turn them into new realities. 
Never avoid unpleasant truths.
 When faced by them, find the hope and solutions others may be too blinded by negativity to see. 
Read the full piece on the 
United Nations Development Programme blog >
PARTNER PICKS 
Our awesome partners help keep our content free 🥰

these fun and free icebreakers
.

 offers affordable online therapy on your schedule.
Restore your inner radiance with this 
best-selling collagen

subject: RE: [Content Review] Spotlight on Persons with Disabilities
body:
Hi Ariadne,
 
Please see the updated content:
https://www.dropbox.com/scl/fi/g4jvq7tfabybn9mikxez2/05_SPOTLIGHT-Persons-with-Disabilities-Europe.pptx?rlkey=b1q4uf4yyve1m4x7cczhth3pl&dl=0
 
Some notes:
I couldn’t find the alt text you added, but I used the file you send as the basis for the edits, so it should still be there. Can you tell me how to find it? I am not sure if or how this will be shared with participants.
I did as many graphic changes as I could. Unfortunately, we didn’t have time for a full graphic refresh, but I will take your comments to heart for the next version
 
Please let me know if anything stands out as needing to change, and we will make those changes.
 
Also, please let us know if you need anything else before the session.
 
Best,
Dan

On Sun, Sep 24, 2023 at 3:05 PM Ariadne Ferro <
ariadne@thezunzun.com
> wrote:
Hello, Daniel and Emani. Thank you so much for this. I'll be sure to take a look asap.
Thank you again!
Ariadne
 
 
On Fri, Sep 22, 2023 at 8:35 PM Daniel Gough <
d.gough@lcwmail.com
> wrote:
Hi Ariadne,
 
Great to connect with you yesterday, and I’m looking forward to working with you. I’ve copied in Emani, the Consultant who is supporting me on this project.
 
You should be able to download the content here. If not, please let me know.
https://www.dropbox.com/scl/fi/xd01fex07dywe4qtdjmxh/SPOTLIGHT-Persons-w-Disabilities-Europe.pptx?rlkey=coqcy3mhx5ei9ibxq8bqlehfa&dl=0
 
A couple of things to keep in mind:
LCW decks and notes tend to be dense. I’ve removed some pages and notes already, and feel free to edit the speaker notes further during your prep. (This also means that the timings won’t line up exactly, as indicated in the notes)
TPOTS
 means “The Point of the Slide,” identifies the main narrative element to be emphasized if speaker notes are skipped over
I have tried to take out most of the US references in the notes, but I am certain I have missed certain elements
 
Things to look for in the review:
Imagery that seems out-of-place and/or very US-centric
Language that seems out-of-place and/or very US-centric
Fact and figures that refer only to the US
Opportunities (if any) to add Europe content
 
We will take your comments and make revisions. As I mentioned, this content was originally developed for a US audience by an interculturalist based in the US who identifies as neurodivergent. Please feel free to be as harsh as you feel is necessary with the content. 
 
Slides with regional facts (highlighted because there may be residual errors in the notes,etc.):
p. 2
 Updated
p. 5 
Updated
p. 6
 UN definition, updated (changed from ADA definition)
p. 11 
Disability history (in progress, partially updated)
 
Please let me know if you have any questions, and I will be in touch with the PA (the contract for the service) early next week.
 
 
Thank you, and have a great weekend!
 
Best,
Dan
 
 
Daniel Gough, PhD
(he/him)

Thank you Kelly for jumping in to respond.
 
To close the loop on slide 6 the questions after the facts are shared this is the prompting that will be used:
Using the chat feature: 
Share the number of facts that DID and DID NOT surprise you
.
 
Also Dani, to take the facilitation burden away from you (because again I realize that is not what you originally expected from this engagement) we will be soliciting the help of one of our internal colleagues Larry Baker to serve as the second facilitator so that you can lean more into your personal story and experiences rather than sticking to our facilitator script. 
 
Therefore, we will be calling you into the training on:
Slide 3 (for an introduction sharing which area you are within the Tech space and your intersecting identities will be salient points to mention)
Slide 13 (to share about your experiences as a young professional)
Slide 18 (to share an additional action item for ending ageism and sexism in the workplace).
 
I truly appreciate your flexibility and this shift was made to ease the preparation and work you would need to put into prepping for this course. 
 
Let me know if this works for you?
