Hi Dani - 
I can respond…and, of course all the facilitator notes are subject to edits based on your style of presentation…often times they are there as a reference or reminders…and sometimes facilitators edit a slide based on what they may be familiar with (of course related to research). 
 
Slide 6: “Next, share how many you thought would have changed since you first heard it.”
 
Some of the stats one may have heard a few years ago or a while back…they seems almost like, ‘duh.’ But, since we heard them (maybe a few years ago), how many would have thought that times would have changed or that something would have been done differently to facilitate change. 
 
SOLUTION for both stat lists: 
Eliminate the middle question and just use: (1) share the number of facts you felt like you knew, and (2) which of those listed surprised you the most?
 
Slide 14 is attached.
 I am not sure I see what you are referencing. Is this the slide you are referring to? Can you help me identify where your question is?
 
Please let me know if I am missing something on that slide. 
Best!!
 
From:
 Fava, Dani <Dani.Fava@envestnet.com> 
Sent:
 Tuesday, November 15, 2022 1:00 PM
To:
 Emani Richmond <e.richmond@lcwmail.com>
Cc:
 Kelly Salek <k.salek@lcwmail.com>
Subject:
 RE: Final Ageism & Sexism Content (11/17)
 
Hi Emani, 
 
I’ve had a chance to go through the slides and notes in detail. 
I’m comfortable with the ones you’ve assigned to me except for Slide 19 (Breaking Habits, Changing Behaviors). I think RP would do a much better job driving this one home than I would. I have a few outstanding questions on some others… 
 
On Slide 6, there is an unresolved comment from RP (that I agree with) in the chat section. Can you suggest alternate language here, or let me know if we can take it out?
 
Using the chat feature: 
 - First, share the number of facts you felt like you knew. 
 - Next, share how many you thought would have changed since you first heard it. 
(RP: what does this mean?) 
 - Finally, which of those listed surprised you the most?
 
On Slide 14, what is meant by “Made to pay when taking parenthood leave”? Do you mean that the employer assumes they’ll have to pay parenthood leave? Or that the female presenting person will be made to pay because they took parenthood leave?
 
Based on the 
motherhood penalty bias
, there are assumptions made about time commitments to large projects, traveling, and time off—these are unfair assumptions.
Made to pay when taking parenthood leave
When say ‘no’, looked at negatively. When men say ‘no’, their reason is accepted.

EXTERNAL MAIL: USE CAUTION BEFORE CLICKING LINKS OR OPENING ATTACHMENTS. ALWAYS VERIFY THE SOURCE OF MESSAGES.
Good morning Dani,
 
My suggestion is more to reach out and see if there are particular slides that you feel your lived experiences are more aligned with and that you might be more comfortable facilitating or providing examples for—I can’t help to feel that perhaps the expectations were not shared with you 100% and that assigning slides might not be the right way to break up this session. 
 
I would like to arrange a time for you and Rebecca to review the slides again as soon as possible, might you have any open time today or tomorrow to review the flow and how to break up the content by person?

I’m not clear on what you’re asking. Are you suggesting that we give all facilitation fully to RP and instead transition my role to more “commentary and examples”?
 
I’ll happily oblige to whatever you think is best. Please let me know what the decision is so I can move forward with my prep.

https://www.dropbox.com/t/god5k7kHVMxNxnZw
 
As you review the slides I think it is best for you to focus on how you will introduce yourself specifically calling on aspects of your identity and why ageism and sexism are topics that you find interesting based on your worldviews or based on your profession. 
 
And when looking through the content if you could find the slides you might have a few additional comments for that way instead of you carrying a larger facilitation role such as Rebecca we might be better positioned to call you in for a few key slides that you can add some insight towards. I don’t want you to feel overwhelmed about the facilitator content but rather lean into the expertise you bring into this space and that is your lived experiences. 
 
Let me know your thoughts. 
 
Thank you for partnering with us for this project and LCW in general!

Hey Rebecca, 
 
I am happy to get on a call and answer any questions that I am able to answer. In terms of setting a timeline associated with these changes, Carta has purchased this product for February of 2023. I think that as a team if we target having a standardized version and content updates being completed by the first week in January that sets me up well for the content to be prepared for client delivery and facilitator prep. 
 
Thank you RP and Jeffrey for prioritizing this content and getting it streamlined and client ready. 
 
Best!!

From:
 Rebecca Parrilla <r.parrilla@lcwmail.com> 
Sent:
 Tuesday, September 20, 2022 3:07 PM
To:
 Tamara Thorpe <t.thorpe@lcwmail.com>; Emani Richmond <e.richmond@lcwmail.com>; Nicole Barile <n.barile@lcwmail.com>
Cc:
 Jeffrey Cookson <j.cookson@lcwmail.com>
Subject:
 RE: Carta Black Allyship Potential Product
 
Helloooooooooooo, team! Thanks for your patience as I find time to get back to you on this. 
 
So yes, earlier this year Tamara suggested to me that this session would fit well as a SPOTLIGHT on the Black Experience (since we didn’t have a Spotlight about the Black community). At that time I did review it and had comments/questions that I sent out – but we were all too busy with other client priorities and it got stuck. It has been sitting in TRAINING\2-Classroom Programs\5-MINIWORKSHOPS\IDENTITY BASED\SPOTLIGHT on Black Experience_INPROCESS and it is here.
 
Fast forward. In speaking with Melissa and Jake last week about the next ‘bundles’ promotion around Black History Month, I brought this up. They were both quite excited about the prospect of including a Spotlight about the Black Experience. I solicited Jeffrey’s help in “LCW-izing” the session, and getting it ready for full rollout for any client (reason I’m copying him on this message). LCW-izing includes: updating it where necessary (e.g, headlines), deciding if we want to make it U.S. centered like our other Spotlights or not (and if not, we’d need to either rename it or add content from other countries), looking at it from an instructional design POV, making sure it minimizes content overlap with other programs, making sure the notes are thorough/complete, making sure the graphic design is done, etc. etc.
 
A few comments and questions that perhaps can be answered by Emani in a Teams meeting:
The Carta session was about the Black Experience in ‘the Americas’ – though it focused only on the US, Canada, and Brazil. (The headlines slide contained headlines from the U.S., Canada, one about Brazil, one about the UN, and one about racism by Latinos in the U.S.)
Some of the slides contained speaker notes and transitions that are not aligned with the slide content
The “56 Black Men Project” in the UK in the timeline needs to be replaced (not ‘the Americas’)
I had suggested removing the microinequities slides (because they appear in a few of our other programs) and just go with the “How would you respond” (HWYR) - present the first HWYR question, have them think but then we give them suggested answers (to model), then we elicit answers from them for the other two HWYR scenarios. Or we could add a slide about microaggressions. 
I had a couple of additional questions in the comments. 
I see that the version in the Miniworkshops folder, which is the version I reviewed earlier this year, is a bit different than the one Emani points to below – for example:
Slide 9, “The Impact of Stereotype Threat” with Larry’s photo, is new to me. 
In the version I looked at earlier this year, there was a slide with a table that listed stereotypes and corresponding Facts & Implications that I don’t see in the version Emani points to below.
In the version I looked at earlier this year, there were a couple of slides on microinequities that don’t exist in the version Emani points to below. 
The “how to be an ally” slide has changed, and the P&H video was not in the version I looked at.
The HWYR scenarios do not exist in the version Emani points to below.
 
In the meantime, Jeffrey and I talked about prioritizing a Spotlight about the Black Experience in the U.S., and then also doing a version about the Black Experience in North America since we have a lot of good Canada content in there too. 
 
Welcome your reactions and thoughts!
RP
 
-
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Rebecca M. Parrilla (she/her)
Director of Content & Research, LCW
 
From:
 Tamara Thorpe <t.thorpe@lcwmail.com> 
Sent:
 Monday, September 19, 2022 8:28 PM
To:

Subject:
 RE: Carta Black Allyship Potential Product
 
Hello everyone!
 
Last year when this session was created, I let RP know that my recommendation was to offer it as a Spotlight. I’m not sure what happened after that so we may want to follow up with RP.
 
Tamara
 
From:
 Emani Richmond <e.richmond@lcwmail.com> 
Sent:
 Monday, September 19, 2022 12:50 PM
To:
 Nicole Barile <n.barile@lcwmail.com>; Rebecca Parrilla <r.parrilla@lcwmail.com>; Tamara Thorpe <t.thorpe@lcwmail.com>
Subject:
 Carta Black Allyship Potential Product
 
Hey Nicole, 
 
I think it makes sense to loop in Tamara here as she would have the best purview on the distinctions between these courses and if they should be marketed separately.  
 
Hey @Tamara Thorpe should we offer the ‘Being an Ally to your Black Colleagues’ (course developed for Carta) as a standalone new product in LCW, or should it be included as an offering for our product ‘Upskilling your Ally Voice’?
 
Nicole wants to avoid adding too many different products to Compass that aren’t necessary, and I want to ensure that folks are aware of this product in case they want to sell it. 
 
Thank you for weighing in…
 
-

Emani Richmond

 RE: Carta program question
 
Thanks, Emani!
When RP gives me to go-ahead, I can add it as a new product. 
I’m wondering if we would want to add this to our catalog as something new or if we wouldn’t just try to sell “Upskilling your Ally Voice”? (although I know they are not exactly the same). Will leave that up to y’all 😊.
 
Thanks again!
 
Nicole Barile

Thank you both.

Hi Rebecca,
 
Emani alerted me to a new program specifically for Carta – 
How to Be an Ally to our Black Colleagues
.
I just entered this into Compass as a Carta-specific training for now, but I wanted to share with you in case you were not aware of it. Not sure if it’s something we should make widely available….?
 
@Emani – Is this a 1-hour session? How many facilitators? Cost?
 
I have not looked at the content yet, but I’m wondering how this is different from other content we have. Asking because my goal is to not have too many programs in Compass… so if this content is super close to something else, I’d rather use that product in Compass.
 
Hope that makes sense! 😊
(But @Emani – for now you can use the new product I entered in Compass. You should find it when you type “Carta” in).
 
Thank you!

subject: “from city girl to country girl":in convo with Dominique Webb,CEO of Cult Creative Agency & Cult Farms
body:
Dominique Webb isn't your average CEO.  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌

“from city girl to country girl":in convo with Dominique Webb,CEO of Cult Creative Agency & Cult Farms
Dominique Webb isn't your average CEO. 
let's try softer
Oct 9
 
READ IN APP
 
Dominique Webb
 isn't your average CEO. from her colorful and impeccable feed to her weekly musings, she’s the definition of 
that girl
, especially if you’re in the creative field yourself. you may already know her as @
fairybrandmuva_
 and CEO of 
@cultcreativeagency_
 a remote brand design agency and marketing consultancy for WOC-owned brands. Cult Creative Agency has in impressive roster, including many well-known brands such as Fenty Corporation by Rihanna, Issa Rae, SKIMS, Netflix and HBO Max 💅🏾✨in addition to her work at 
@cultcreativeagency_
, Dominique is also one of 13,000 Black women farmers and uses her spare time to revitalize and expand her farm in Tennessee, 
@cultfarms
. 
this week on 
the podcast
, we had the pleasure of chatting with the mogul on what her journey into being a boss has taught her, as well as what keeps her inspired and motivated along the way. in this episode, we share:
Dominique’s nonlinear, nontraditional journey into building 
@cultcreativeagency_
, one of the most coveted digital brand agencies from scratch 👩🏽‍💻💖
how rejection became redirection and why starting over is a blessing in disguise 🪐
what it’s like running a digital brand agency AND a farm, while navigating womanhood in your 30s 👩🏽‍🌾🫶🏾✨

subject: Extension Granted – Women MAKE Award Nominations Extended to Oct. 13
body:
Emani:
You asked. We listened.  
After many requests, we have extended the deadline for the 
2024 Women MAKE Award nominations
 to 
Friday, October 13
. In the spirit of good luck, I encourage you to get your nominations in ahead of spookiest date of the season and 
submit today
! 
Submit a Nomination
A few things to remember as you send in your best and final nominations: 
The Women MAKE Awards Nominations Guide
 is still live and will serve as your best practice blueprint on criteria, timeline, sample essays, and process for collecting nominations internally. 
Companies can submit a combination of Emerging Leaders and Honorees for a total of up to 10 nominations. 
An 
Honoree
 should be currently employed in manufacturing at any level of the company, from the factory floor to the C-suite. A maximum of two Honorees from a single company may be selected for this award.  
An 
Emerging Leader
 should be a rising star currently employed in the manufacturing industry that has made significant contributions and excelled early in their career. 
An Emerging Leader nominee must be between 
18 and 30 years of age
 as of December 31, 2023. A maximum of one Emerging Leader from a single company may be selected for this award.  
Winners will be alerted in January 2024 and the Awards gala will take place on April 18, 2024. To learn more about the event 
click here
. To inquire about sponsorship opportunities please 
click here
 or contact our team at 
WomenMAKE@nam.org
.  
Good luck & Happy Nominating! 
Isabelle
Isabelle Powell  
National Director, Women’s Engagement  
The Manufacturing Institute  
Connect with Us
Questions or Comments?
Contact the Women Connect team at 
WomenMAKE@nam.org
.

subject: Dear Friend Who Supported Me
body:
A thank-you to someone who provided a lifeline at a time of crisis  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌
Forwarded this email? 
Subscribe here
 for more
Thank you for joining the Sharon’s Anti-Racism Newsletter community. A gentle reminder that a 
paid subscription
 supports the work of writing and publishing. Alternatively, you can make a one-off contribution to newsletter running costs via my 
Ko-Fi page
. 
Dear Friend Who Supported Me
A thank-you to someone who provided a lifeline at a time of crisis
Sharon Hurley Hall
Oct 9
 
READ IN APP
 
Hello friends,
I couldn’t publish this at the time, but I wrote it after an experience of racism from a white leader at my last company. It shows both how racism can affect people AND how important support is. 
Dear friend who supported me,
You didn’t know it at the time, but you provided a necessary lifeline at a point where I thought I might drown from the pain of the racism I’d faced. It had been a hard few days. After the original incident I began to wonder if I was right to see it that way. After all, taken on its own, it didn’t look so bad. But those who knew the backstory and the culture reassured me that my initial reaction was right.
What I did not anticipate - how could I have - was that this particular incident would take me back to a time in my childhood where I felt less than safe. 
A time that was turbulent, unsettled. 
A time where we’d left the place I called home and moved to somewhere new where I didn’t feel I fitted in. 
A time when I could not be open about my home life, and where I never knew what chaos would await me. 
Though I shut away many of the feelings related to that, I know now that it was traumatic, and that the incident of racism reawakened some of that trauma.
In the moment where I had to confront the person who had harmed me, I didn’t recognise myself. I was perspiring, nauseous and found it hard to speak. I learned later that this was also a trauma response, brought on by the annihilation of the safe space I thought I’d been in.
It was a hard thing to realise that one person could shatter that sense of security. But I was grateful for the support of all those who listened, helped me process, suggested coping mechanisms. These things allowed me to rediscover some balance. And although the scab is thin, it is now there. 
As things have turned out, I won’t have to work with that person again. But it’s reminded me, as if I didn’t know, just how harmful racism can be, and how essential it is to eradicate it. Because it’s not just about what happens in the here and now, it’s about all the layers of trauma during the past decades. 
Nobody should have to go through this. No person who faces isms should have to be traumatised. A world where that no longer happens, where everyone belongs and is truly equal, will finally put that behind us. 
By supporting me, friend, you gave me hope that we can get there. And you also provided the certainty that I would survive that experience no matter how unlikely it seemed in the moment. 
If you never knew how much I appreciated that and, more importantly, you, I hope you know now.
Hugs,
Sharon
As I said, it took a while to be able to publish this. For a long time, the experience was too close and too raw (and that feeling can still sneak up on my sometimes), but that support was - and remains steadfast. 
Allies and advocates, sometimes this is what we need, so think about how you can support those around you who might be having a similar experience. 
Leave a comment
Thanks for reading,
Sharon

subject: Time to stop scrolling
body:
Three ways to rethink your screen time.
View this email in your browser.
 
Presented by CVS Health
Tired of mindlessly scrolling on your phone? Here’s how to stop
October 8, 2023
 
We know screen time doesn’t always serve us, and yet we still scroll our phones for hours when we should be sleeping, working, or unwinding. Being online today also revolves around checking a growing list of social media feeds. Excess time on these platforms has been shown to exacerbate mental health issues and is associated with low self-esteem.
And adults may struggle with low productivity or weakened social ties due to screen time, says Dr. Carl Marci, a psychiatrist at Massachusetts General Hospital and author of 
Rewired: Protecting Your Brain in the Digital Age. 
It’s not too late to reassess your screen time and create “tech-life balance,” Marci says. Here’s how.
1. Prioritize your connections 
“We’ve lost the art of interpersonal communication,” Jennifer Kelman, a licensed social worker and mental health expert with JustAnswer, tells Fortune. We can get it back by making plans with friends and family who energize us. Make eye contact. Keep your phone in your pocket. Listen. Even small activities that can 
instill joy
 can help replace the satisfaction of the screen.  
2. Take stock of your social media use  
Assess how you feel when scrolling through other people’s lives on 
social media
. Are there platforms that give you energy and leave you feeling downright bad after you engage? The latter may signal that certain content does not serve you. 
To combat this, consider limiting time spent on social apps to a particular time of day. For example, avoid looking at a certain platform after 7 p.m. Make flexible rules. Don’t berate yourself if you break them. Remind yourself that 
habits are hard to break
, but you would rather be uplifted than depleted. 
3. Don’t respond right away
When seeing a text pop up during work, it can be tempting to reply right away. Yes, there are times when matters are urgent, but often, waiting until we have a moment to breathe and be more attentive to these messages can help improve our relationship with our phones. Besides, 
multitasking
 hampers productivity, and screen time is often the culprit. 
 
Read Alexa Mikhail’s full article 
here
.

d.gough@lcwmail.com

Hi Ariadne,
 
Great to connect with you yesterday, and I’m looking forward to working with you. I’ve copied in Emani, the Consultant who is supporting me on this project.
 
You should be able to download the content here. If not, please let me know.
https://www.dropbox.com/scl/fi/xd01fex07dywe4qtdjmxh/SPOTLIGHT-Persons-w-Disabilities-Europe.pptx?rlkey=coqcy3mhx5ei9ibxq8bqlehfa&dl=0
 
A couple of things to keep in mind:
LCW decks and notes tend to be dense. I’ve removed some pages and notes already, and feel free to edit the speaker notes further during your prep. (This also means that the timings won’t line up exactly, as indicated in the notes)
TPOTS
 means “The Point of the Slide,” identifies the main narrative element to be emphasized if speaker notes are skipped over
I have tried to take out most of the US references in the notes, but I am certain I have missed certain elements
 
Things to look for in the review:
Imagery that seems out-of-place and/or very US-centric
Language that seems out-of-place and/or very US-centric
Fact and figures that refer only to the US
Opportunities (if any) to add Europe content
 
We will take your comments and make revisions. As I mentioned, this content was originally developed for a US audience by an interculturalist based in the US who identifies as neurodivergent. Please feel free to be as harsh as you feel is necessary with the content. 
 
Slides with regional facts (highlighted because there may be residual errors in the notes,etc.):
p. 2
 Updated
p. 5 
Updated
p. 6
 UN definition, updated (changed from ADA definition)
p. 11 
Disability history (in progress, partially updated)
 
Please let me know if you have any questions, and I will be in touch with the PA (the contract for the service) early next week.
 
 
Thank you, and have a great weekend!
 
Best,
Dan

subject: Building an empowered workforce with gen AI
body:
Plus, raising the bar for sustainable and inclusive growth ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌

Monthly Highlights, October 2023
Gen AI may be in its nascent stages of development, but the technology is only going to get more intelligent. How can organizations do more than just “keep up”? What strategies, structures, and talent management approaches will business leaders need to adopt to prepare their organizations for a gen-AI-driven future? In this month’s first featured story, McKinsey’s Sandra Durth, 
Bryan Hancock
, 
Dana Maor
, and 
Alex Sukharevsky
 explain that gen AI can be a powerful tool for employee empowerment if business leaders think broadly about how gen AI could affect their organizations—and people—day to day. In our second featured story, 
Kweilin Ellingrud
 and 
Saurabh Sanghvi
 discuss the importance of upskilling, reskilling, and training to empower the global workforce with the rise of gen AI. Other highlights in this month’s issue include the following topics:
•
what it would take to raise minimum living standards 
and
 get on a net-zero path 
•
the six worker archetypes present in every organization﻿
•
how companies can play offense in the net-zero transition despite uncertainty
•
the unprecedented mental health issues facing today’s teens
Editor’s choice
The organization of the future: Enabled by gen AI, driven by people
Generative AI can empower people—but only if leaders take a broad view of its capabilities and deeply consider its implications for the organization.﻿
Empower your people
 
Generative AI: How will it affect future jobs and workflows?﻿
Gen AI and other recent trends affecting the labor market point to the importance of upskilling, reskilling, and training to empower the global workforce.
﻿Build new skills
 
THIS MONTH’s HIGHLIGHTS
 
From poverty to empowerment: Raising the bar for sustainable and inclusive growth
What would it take to raise minimum living standards and get on a net-zero path in this decade? Our research explores twin ambitions for people and the planet.
Advance the continuum of progress
 
Some employees are destroying value. Others are building it. Do you know the difference?
More than half of employees report being relatively unproductive at work. New research into six types of employees shows how companies can re-engage workers while amplifying the impact of star performers.
Address the challenge
 
Full throttle on net zero: Creating value in the face of uncertainty
To thrive amid shocks to the net-zero economy, leaders are shifting strategies to position themselves to win when the skies clear up.
Make bold moves
 
Getting to the bottom of the teen mental health crisis
From identifying the effects of social media and the COVID-19 pandemic, to overcoming stigma and expanding accessibility to care, there’s lots to unpack around teen mental health. How do we help tomorrow’s workforce today?
Think creatively
 
Gen AI in high gear: Mercedes-Benz leverages the power of ChatGPT
Philipp Skogstad, CEO of Mercedes-Benz R&D North America, shares the story of bringing generative AI to 900,000 beta testers and discusses the vision, impact, challenges, and path forward for generative AI applications in the automotive sector.
Drive change
 
On the cusp of the next payments era: Future opportunities for banks
The 2023 McKinsey Global Payments Report shines a light on a changing industry and explains how banks and others can capitalize on new dynamics.
Make better decisions
ALSO New
﻿The data dividend: Fueling generative AI
Stimulus funding deadlines loom: How are K–12 schools adjusting their priorities?
Turning consumer and retail companies into software-driven innovators
﻿Asia on the cusp of a new era
The missing billion: Lack of disability data impedes healthcare equity
Author Talks: How you can future-proof your business for sustainable, long-term growth
﻿Five Fifty: Employee development: A skills-based approach
﻿Forward Thinking on funding a clean world with Ann Mettler
﻿The role of natural gas in the move to cleaner, more reliable power
﻿Author Talks: How to speak confidently when you’re put on the spot
﻿European machinery companies: Achieving balance through innovation
﻿Gearing up for mobility’s future with quantum computing

TOGETHER WITH RITUAL
Essential for Women 18+ Multivitamin
  
 
Feeling off your A-game?
Our friends at 
Ritual
 have the daily supplement to bring your health into focus.
Essential for Women 18+
 is a clinical-backed multivitamin specially formulated with 9 key nutrients to help fill gaps in women's diets
.
Its delayed-release capsules are designed to dissolve in the ideal absorption spot. Backed by science, Essential for Women 18+ increased vitamin D and omega-3 DHA levels by 43% and 41% respectively in a clinical trial.
Obsessive about quality, it's 
vegan, non-GMO, gluten-free and allergen-free
.
With our exclusive TA discount, 
you can enjoy 30% off your first month
 with code THEASSIST. 
 
Step up your health game with Ritual
FROM DO5IVE
Seasonal living
Perfectionism and capitalism have taught us that when we wake up in the morning, we should feel exactly the same every day. In fact, the expectation is to produce a little bit more each and every single day. Forever. Until the day we die. When it’s laid out like that, it’s so much easier to see the ridiculousness of that sentiment. Instead of being a machine that always feels the same and continues to produce more each day, we are human’s being. 
We are of nature
, which means we live cyclically, just like Mother Nature does. Here’s how you can tune into cyclical living:
Turn to nature:
 When we forget we’re nature and not a machine, there’s a simple solution. And it’s right outside your window. Tune into nature. My favorite ritual is to regularly visit my favorite tree. I watch how the tree changes and grows over the seasons. In winter, it’s bare, but during the early summer it flourishes.
Accept that we are cyclical:
 During the winter, the soil rests and replenishes. If it didn’t, it wouldn’t be able to grow a crop the next spring. Just as the earth rests, so must we. Our rest is equally important as our production.
Do something kind, gentle, and cozy for yourself:
 One of my favorite ways to support myself is to ask this question: how can I make this 10% easier? When we need rest, but can’t necessarily take the day off, we can support ourselves by finding ways to make the task easier, gentler, or more cozy.
Is it a microwave or stovetop kind of day:
 My favorite snack is popcorn. The best popcorn is made on the stovetop. But sometimes, you need a snack and don’t have the time to pop it on the stove, melt the butter, and do the dishes. Those days are microwave popcorn days. Both end in popcorn. How we get there isn’t always as important as the end result.
Talk to yourself like you would your pet:
 We celebrate our pets for everything. Being cute, rolling over, sleeping in the middle of the day, finishing their food, having a round, adorable belly. Why can’t we also talk to ourselves that way? We can.
TOGETHER WITH MIRO
How well do you know your team?
  
 
1 truth 2 lies
 is a simple icebreaker to do and creates healthy banter.
Here's how to play: 
Team members populate a total of three sticky notes with 2 lies and 1 truth.
Once completed, everyone uses dots to vote for the one they think is the truth.
Do a round-robin where each person gets to share verbally what the correct "truth" sticky was.
This icebreaker
 is really easy, quick and fun, and is a great way to energize your team before starting a meeting.
  
Swipe the template and play with your team

Team:
 
Another amazing session today!!  I noted more than 460 participants today – Betsy will share the official attendance record shortly.  We received a ton of great feedback, and once again a great job by Betsy and our LCW experts, Emani and Conner!  Special thanks to Jermisha and Lindsay for helping with the break-out sessions – you made it seamless even with more than 460 participants!

body:
Hello team, 
 
542 UL colleagues joined today! Amazing work everyone! It was a pleasure seeing everyone so engaged and happy with the sessions. 
 
Best regards, 
Betsy 
 
From:
 Cornejo Garcia, Stephen R. <Stephen.CornejoGarcia@ul.com> 
Sent:
 Friday, October 6, 2023 3:01 PM
To:
 Guerrero, Betsy <Betsy.Guerrero@ul.com>; Poonacha, Rohini <Rohini.Poonacha@ul.com>; Muehlmann, Lisa <Lisa.Muehlmann@ul.com>; Dodson, Jermisha Y. <Jermisha.Dodson@ul.com>; Lindsay Buchanan <lbuchanan@meetings-incentives.com>; Buchanan, Lindsay <Lindsay.Buchanan@ul.com>; Daniel Gough <d.gough@lcwmail.com>; Emani Richmond <e.richmond@lcwmail.com>; c.williams@lcwmail.com; Blake, Sally <Sally.Blake@ul.com>; Guerin, Gabriella <Gabriella.Guerin@ul.com>
Cc:
 Storey, Kristen <Kristen.Storey@ul.com>; l.baker@lcwmail.com
Subject:
 Global Inclusion Forum Americas Day 2 is a wrap!
 
Team:
 
Another amazing session today!!  I noted more than 460 participants today – Betsy will share the official attendance record shortly.  We received a ton of great feedback, and once again a great job by Betsy and our LCW experts, Emani and Conner!  Special thanks to Jermisha and Lindsay for helping with the break-out sessions – you made it seamless even with more than 460 participants!
 
Here are couple of appreciations from today’s audience:
“Great work putting that together! Fabulous speakers and super enlightening messages. Pretty life changing if you ask me!”
“I  wanted to let you know what an amazing job you did in pulling this together, it was truly a fantastic 2-days, the presenters energy, their knowledge was amazing, the participation, etc. you… should be extremely proud!”
I must say, these DEI forum session are a breath of fresh air.  I hope majority of the… members had a chance to join yesterday or is in attendance in today’s session. even if you can join for an hour, would love to see ya”
“… to be honest out of all the DE&I sessions I have attended, this was the most impactful and engaging.  Excellent job and THANK YOU!!”
 
And now we head to Europe and APMEA.  I know they are going to be successful as well.
 
Excellent job everyone!
 
Have a great weekend!
 
Stephen

We received a ton of positive feedback from participants that numbered more than 470 by my count

“This was one of the BEST DEI sessions I've ever been to.”

Looking forward to Day 2!
 
Thanks everyone.
 
Stephen

subject: RE: LCW Branded Understanding Brazilian Work Culture Presentation
body:
Dropbox wants me to open an account with them before I´m able to send material you from there, because my free trial expired.
 
Here is a second link if the first doesn´t open.
 
https://www.dropbox.com/scl/fi/2kharws95qs0c8nbea17j/LCWCarta-Final.pptx?rlkey=eu48dx3yj9y3lsp8xvavh48ky&dl=0
 
 
From:
 Emani Richmond <e.richmond@lcwmail.com> 
Sent:
 Thursday, October 5, 2023 11:26 PM
To:
 ica@infolink.com.br
Subject:
 LCW Branded Understanding Brazilian Work Culture Presentation
 
Hey Lucy,
 
I just received the branded file from our design team.
 
https://www.dropbox.com/scl/fi/ecj2l8chiujlh3y4snzhq/Carta_Understanding_Brazilian_Work_Culture_2023_KL.pptx?rlkey=6mv2myfftmvqsnxgqvepjo6zi&dl=0
 
I was not able to send over the slides with the corrected spelling. Could you find the text with the spelling errors and make the connections on your end? 
 
Also, given that my client is in the tech space they mainly have people in younger generations there is WAY too much text on the slides. Please move any text that is not necessary for the reader to see into the speaker notes so it will be sure to be covered there. I began to try and shorten and simplify the text on the slides but without fully understanding the major talking points you want to bring up I didn’t want to remove text that was essential for the slide. 
 
I will be working on Monday so we will have one final day to wrap up edits and speaking assignments before we chat. I assume any slides you create you will deliver, and the LCW slides that remain in the presentation I will deliver those. Feel free to send me a voice note on WhatsApp tomorrow if further clarification is needed. 
 
Essentially:
Please make the information on slides shorter bullet points
Also are there any relevant images of Brazil that we can include in the presentation?
If you send me images I can put them in the presentation
We can connect again on Monday to wrap up final notes before we deliver the training
 
Thank you for your expertise on this content, I’m excited to see the final product. 
 
Emani Richmond
(she/her/hers)
Consultant
LCW

subject: to build a future where kids can access fully-funded public education
body:
it’s going to take all of us, together 
Click here
 to view this message in a browser window. 
Dear Emani
, 
By now, you’ve heard a lot about our HEAL Together initiative, 
an expanding movement in school districts across the United States that is being led by courageous individuals who want to safeguard honest, equitable, fully-funded public education. 
We’re asking for your support
 in our efforts to provide training, resources, tools and strategies to organizers across the country who are fighting to preserve the gains of the civil rights movement. These organizers are teachers, school board members, parents, and students - not to mention community members like you and me.
 “A great friend of mine once told me that often times we grow to become who we once needed. And, during my public school experience, I needed someone who would advocate for my peers and I.” 
Myla Williams, speaking at Race Forward's Facing Race Conference, November 2022
As a student in southwest Atlanta, Myla has personal experience with the lack of resources and opportunities afforded to students in specific zip codes. As the Chief of Staff for the 
Georgia Youth Justice Coalition
, a HEAL Together partner, she’s helped implement significant initiatives to give students access to everything from mental health resources to recreational partnerships. 
Using HEAL Together tools and support, Myla and her peers are fighting for public schools that will provide all young people with the resources they need to thrive. And 
they’re winning
 - restoring millions of dollars in public education funding, securing representative maps, protecting LGBTQ+ youth, and so much more.
Your support is needed and important to help Myla and so many other HEAL Together partners like her.
 It is going to take all of us, together, to protect the most vulnerable among us and build a future where young people can access the promise of an equitable, quality public education for all.
Join us
 in making this vision a reality. 
En solidaridad,
Marina Muñoz de Martínez
Director of Development & Partnerships
P.S. To learn more, 
RSVP to attend
 the next virtual Coffee Chat on 10/24, where you’ll get to meet the HEAL Together team, hear firsthand accounts from youth organizers, and learn more about the direct impact of the initiative. 
 
SHARE THIS EMAIL
 
DONATE
 
 
 
 
CONNECT 
You're receiving this because you have requested communication from 
Race Forward
.

, or 
unsubscribe from all Race Forward emails
.

Subject:
 [EXT] Latin American Spotlight: Content Walk through follow-up
 
Hi Rashida,
 
Thank you for the discussion on the content for the Spotlight on Latin community today
 
See below for the video links and polls included in the training:
 
Video Links:
https://www.nbcnews.com/nightly-news/video/the-new-Latino-landscape-new-hampshire-s-population-boom-120968773794
Clip from TED Talk from Daisy Auger-Dominguez
SOURCE: 
https://youtu.be/u-VMr51yiVc
 
Poll 1
: 
How much do you know about Latinx? (choose one answer per question) 
(multi-question poll, single answer)
 
People whose cultural background or heritage is Latin American prefer to identify as: Latino/a  / (b) Hispanic / (c) Latinx / (d) Chicano / (e ) Their country of origin (e.g., Dominican-American or Guatemalan) / 
(f) Any of the above
 
Hispanics are projected to account for x% of net new workers between 2020 and 2030. 
10%
55%
78%
100%
 
True
/False 80% of new U.S. businesses over the last decade were created by Hispanics.
 
What percent of the U.S. population identifies as Latino/Hispanic?
1.1% 
6.0% 
10.2% 
12.4% 
18.7% 
 
True/
False
: In the past ten years, the state with the fastest growth rate of Latino residents was California.
 
Poll 2: 
Prioritizing Latinx Challenges (single answer)
What do you see or experience most frequently within your team or organization? (choose one)
Perceived as underperforming.
Judged more rigorously than their white peers.
Perceived as lacking confidence, competence, or presence due to lack of “assertiveness.”
Perceived as lacking initiative or ambition.
Perceived as having lower communication skills.
See few Latinx represented in leadership.
Poll 3
: Call to Action (multiple answer)
In this poll, choose ALL the actions you can take to be an even more inclusive leader or colleague in teams that include Hispanic/Latin colleagues:
Appreciate the diversity within the community. Remember that Latinx colleagues have different national, linguistic, and cultural backgrounds. 
Resist immediately under-evaluating your Latinx team members when they exhibit a work or communication approach that you're not used to.
Explicitly and regularly discuss the “unwritten rules” of success at your organization with everyone. Don't assume people know or "should know." 
 Advocate for cultural diversity with regard to voices, skills, and approaches. Help ensure your Latinx colleagues aren’t asked to do all the stretching. 
 Continue to educate yourself actively on the experiences of the Latinx community.
 
We will need to work in slide 12 (of the images of the famous leaders from the community) into the post session handout and will need 1-2 business days to make that addition. 
 
We have released the November dates for the BCI, and will await final word from you folks about dates to hold for December.
 
Best,
 
Emani Richmond
(she/her/hers)
Consultant
LCW

subject: Extension Granted – 2024 Women MAKE Awards Nominations Accepted through Oct. 13
body:
Emani:
You asked and we listened! The deadline for 2024 Women MAKE Awards nominations has been 
extended through Friday, October 13
. 
Nominate
 your favorite manufacturing woman today so we can celebrate and honor her at the 12th annual Women MAKE Awards conference, gala and awards ceremony on April 18th in Washington, D.C. 
The 
Women MAKE Awards Nominations Guide
 is your exclusive source for how to submit your application(s) for the following categories: 
Honoree
: Nominee is currently employed in manufacturing at any level of the company, from the factory floor to the C-suite. A maximum of two Honorees from a single company may be selected for this award. 
Emerging Leader
: Nominee is a rising star currently employed in the manufacturing industry that has made significant contributions and excelled early in their career.
 An Emerging Leader nominee must be between 
18 and 30 years of age
 as of December 31, 2023. A maximum of one Emerging Leader from a single company may be selected for this award. 
Click here to submit a nomination!
 
To learn more about the Women MAKE America Initiative 
click here
 or email 
WomenMAKE@nam.org
 
 
Happy Nominating! 
Isabelle
Isabelle Powell  
National Director, Women’s Engagement  
The Manufacturing Institute  
Connect with Us
Questions or Comments?
Contact the Women Connect team at 
WomenMAKE@nam.org
.
To unsubscribe from future Women Connect emails, 
click here
Looking for solutions to your workforce challenges? 
Join the Manufacturing Institute on Oct. 16-18 in Atlanta, GA for our annual 
Workforce Summit
 
– the ultimate convening where manufacturers, thought leaders, educators, business association leaders, human resource and workforce development professionals will come together to explore and source innovative solutions for skills, people and processes that will drive success in our industry. 
Register here
.
 
Copyright © 2023, All rights reserved.
733 10th St. NW, Suite 700, Washington, DC 20001
To unsubscribe from future Manufacturing Institute emails, 
click here
.

subject: Help Us Improve the QA Account Experience
body:
Please complete a brief IDI QA survey to help us improve the IDI Assessment website experience.
 
Help us improve your QA account experience!
We’re asking all IDI Qualified Administrators to complete the survey below to share your experiences with using the IDI assessment website (https://idiassessment.com/). We want to know what is important to you, what is working, and what isn’t. The results of this survey will inform our decisions about what to focus on with the IDI QA account experience as we approach 2024.
This survey will take approximately five (5) minutes to complete. Thank you.
Complete the IDI Qualified Administrator User Experience Survey
Copyright (C) 2023 IDI, LLC. All rights reserved.
You are receiving this email because you are listed within the IDI, LLC database as an IDI Qualified Administrator or are attending an upcoming IDI Qualifying Seminar. These are only meant for important updates, so please do not unsubscribe. 
Want to change how you receive these emails?

subject: RE: LCW Branded Understanding Brazilian Work Culture Presentation
body:
Hi Emani
 
Do we have 60 or 30 minutes together? You had told me 60, if it´s 30 it´s a completely different thing.
 
 
 
From:
 Emani Richmond <e.richmond@lcwmail.com> 
Sent:
 Thursday, October 5, 2023 11:26 PM
To:
 ica@infolink.com.br
Subject:
 LCW Branded Understanding Brazilian Work Culture Presentation
 
Hey Lucy,
 
I just received the branded file from our design team.
 
https://www.dropbox.com/scl/fi/ecj2l8chiujlh3y4snzhq/Carta_Understanding_Brazilian_Work_Culture_2023_KL.pptx?rlkey=6mv2myfftmvqsnxgqvepjo6zi&dl=0
 
I was not able to send over the slides with the corrected spelling. Could you find the text with the spelling errors and make the connections on your end? 
 
Also, given that my client is in the tech space they mainly have people in younger generations there is WAY too much text on the slides. Please move any text that is not necessary for the reader to see into the speaker notes so it will be sure to be covered there. I began to try and shorten and simplify the text on the slides but without fully understanding the major talking points you want to bring up I didn’t want to remove text that was essential for the slide. 
 
I will be working on Monday so we will have one final day to wrap up edits and speaking assignments before we chat. I assume any slides you create you will deliver, and the LCW slides that remain in the presentation I will deliver those. Feel free to send me a voice note on WhatsApp tomorrow if further clarification is needed. 
 
Essentially:
Please make the information on slides shorter bullet points
Also are there any relevant images of Brazil that we can include in the presentation?
If you send me images I can put them in the presentation
We can connect again on Monday to wrap up final notes before we deliver the training
 
Thank you for your expertise on this content, I’m excited to see the final product. 
 
Emani Richmond
(she/her/hers)
Consultant
LCW

Subject:
 Global Inclusion Forum Americas Day 1 is a wrap!
 
Team:
 
What an amazing start to the Global Inclusion Forum!
 
While we’re just getting started wanted to take a moment to acknowledge everyone’s hard work, commitment, and talent in creating this amazing experience for our UL Solutions colleagues.
 
We received a ton of positive feedback from participants that numbered more than 470 by my count 
😊
.  Here’s a quick sharing of feedback I received:
 
“This was one of the BEST DEI sessions I've ever been to.”
“
Such a great session - very interactive & informative”
“
Amani should be on our team...she pumped me up”
“For those in the session, we need to hire Larry!! 
 
Overall a very smooth delivery, even with some technology challenges.
 
A special thanks to Betsy for her poise and grace under pressure to ensure the program continued seamlessly, and to Larry, Emani and Conner for amazing instruction and creating a rich space for learning.
 
Looking forward to Day 2!
 
Thanks everyone.
 
Stephen

subject: LCW Branded Understanding Brazilian Work Culture Presentation
body:
Hey Lucy,
 
I just received the branded file from our design team.
 
https://www.dropbox.com/scl/fi/ecj2l8chiujlh3y4snzhq/Carta_Understanding_Brazilian_Work_Culture_2023_KL.pptx?rlkey=6mv2myfftmvqsnxgqvepjo6zi&dl=0
 
I was not able to send over the slides with the corrected spelling. Could you find the text with the spelling errors and make the connections on your end? 
 
Also, given that my client is in the tech space they mainly have people in younger generations there is WAY too much text on the slides. Please move any text that is not necessary for the reader to see into the speaker notes so it will be sure to be covered there. I began to try and shorten and simplify the text on the slides but without fully understanding the major talking points you want to bring up I didn’t want to remove text that was essential for the slide. 
 
I will be working on Monday so we will have one final day to wrap up edits and speaking assignments before we chat. I assume any slides you create you will deliver, and the LCW slides that remain in the presentation I will deliver those. Feel free to send me a voice note on WhatsApp tomorrow if further clarification is needed. 
 
Essentially:
Please make the information on slides shorter bullet points
Also are there any relevant images of Brazil that we can include in the presentation?
If you send me images I can put them in the presentation
We can connect again on Monday to wrap up final notes before we deliver the training
 
Thank you for your expertise on this content, I’m excited to see the final product. 
 
Emani Richmond
(she/her/hers)
Consultant
LCW

subject: Well+Being: Longevity, anger and sober October
body:
Are hand tremors a bad sign? 
‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  
 
 
 
PUBLISHED BY
READ ONLINE
 | 
SIGN UP
 
Expert advice to help you live well every day. 
 
(Abbey Lossing for The Washington Post)
 
 
Tara Parker-Pope 
Happy October! This week we’re writing about declining longevity, sober living and hand tremors. Plus we’ve got our weekly “joy” snacks. But before that …
This week’s must-reads:
Paying for childbirth.
 The price varies dramatically depending on 
whom you call.
Is anger overwhelming your brain?
 Here’s how to bring it 
back online.
Are you eating your meals in the best order?
 How food 
“sequencing
”
 can improve your health.
The Post spent a year examining life expectancy
The United States is failing at a fundamental mission — keeping people alive, according to a startling new report from The Washington Post’s health team.
ADVERTISEMENT
 
 
 
 
A year-long Post examination reveals that after decades of progress, life expectancy has drifted downward. This erosion in life spans is deeper and broader than widely recognized, afflicting
 
a far-reaching swath of the country. Here’s the full report.
 
(Jahi Chikwendiu/The Washington Post)
America’s epidemic of chronic illness is killing us too soon
Among people under 65, chronic illnesses erase more than twice as many years as overdoses, homicides, suicides and car accidents combined, a Post examination found.
By Joel Achenbach, Dan Keating, Laurie McGinley, Akilah Johnson and Jahi Chikwendiu
Read more
 
 
Compare your life expectancy with others around the world
Plug your age and gender into our life expectancy calculator to compare yourself with peers overseas. Find out why so many do better than in the United States.
By Frances Stead Sellers, Adam Taylor, Dan Keating, Leslie Shapiro and Carson TerBush
Read more
 
 
Fatty liver was a disease of the old. Then kids started getting sick.
The condition is now estimated to be as common as asthma in children. Our diet and lifestyle are the suspected culprits.
By Ariana Eunjung Cha
Read more
 
 
How red-state politics are shaving years off American lives
Along Lake Erie, three states show how Republican lawmakers’ decisions over decades on cigarettes and seat belts are shortening life spans. 
By Lauren Weber, Dan Diamond and Dan Keating
Read more
 
 
Sober October
For some, October is a month for sobriety. The “sober October” movement has joined “dry January” as a time to be mindful about alcohol consumption and focus on better health.
Studies show that people who participate in these month-long sobriety challenges frequently experience lasting benefits. Often, they drink less in the long run and make other sustained changes to their drinking habits that lead to striking improvements in their health and well-being.
Why does it work?
A month of sobriety, while it can sound daunting, is not so long that it seems impossible.
A month is long enough that it provides opportunities to form new habits — such as turning down alcohol in social settings, which in the long term can be empowering.
Taking a break from alcohol can trigger immediate health benefits such as weight loss, better sleep and a boost to your mood and energy levels, which can reinforce the new habit.
If you’re embarking on a sober October, we’ve got tips for living alcohol-free. Check out our 
Living Alcohol-Free page
.
 
(Linnea Bullion for The Washington Post)
Do mocktails really help you drink less alcohol? 
Nonalcoholic drinks may help those taking part in Dry January, but could be a trigger for anyone with alcohol use disorder.
By Teddy Amenabar
Read more
 
 
 
(Celia Jacobs for The Washington Post)
Advice
 
How cutting back on alcohol can help depression and anxiety
People taking part in Dry January may notice they have an improved mood, clearer thinking and better sleep.
By Richard A. Friedman MD
Read more
 
 
 
(Abbey Lossing for The Washington Post)
Winter SAD is real. Here’s your fall checklist to prepare.
Fall is the best time for those who suffer from winter seasonal affective disorder (SAD) to check in and prepare. An estimated 5 percent of Americans are susceptible and are probably already feeling the effects of winter SAD, including lower moods, lethargy and excessive sleep.
Our Brain Matters columnist Richard Sima notes that it’s far easier to prepare for and prevent winter SAD than to dig oneself out of depression.
Winter SAD probably is caused by reduced daylight, which knocks our circadian rhythms out of sync and can affect brain circuits involved with mood. (Summer SAD, in contrast, is thought to be precipitated by heat, humidity and allergies.)
To learn more about what you can do to boost your mental health as the seasons change, read the full story.
 
(George Wylesol for The Washington Post)
Fall is the best time to prepare for winter seasonal depression
Light therapy, physician support and routines that empower mental health can help you manage winter seasonal affective disorder.
By Richard Sima
Read more
 
 
Are hand tremors a bad sign?
This week a reader asks about whether hand tremors are a normal part of aging. To find out — and to learn a nifty trick for detecting your own “background” hand tremor — read the full report from our columnist Trisha S. Pasricha, a physician at Massachusetts General Hospital and an instructor in medicine at Harvard Medical School.
And she’s ready to answer your questions! Use our 
Ask a Doctor form
 to submit a question, and we may answer it in a future column.
 
(Chelsea Conrad/The Washington Post; iStock)
Advice
 
Are hand tremors a bad sign? Here’s what the science says. 
If hand tremors don’t interfere with your daily life, they may not be anything to worry about.
By Trisha Pasricha, MD
Read more
 
 
Find your joy snack!
Here are a few things that brought us joy this week.
Enjoy some of this week’s 
best photographs
 from The Post. Our favorite: Simone Biles flying high. 
These cool tools can help aging, fatigued or disabled bodies 
enjoy gardening
. 
Meet Skelly,
 
the 12-foot star of Halloween.
Love 
the Duttons
? The Yellowstone family is fake, but the tourism is real. 
Want to know more about “joy” snacks? Our Brain Matters columnist 
Richard Sima explains.
 
Y
ou can also 
read this story as a comic
.
Please let us know how we are doing. Email me at 
wellbeing@washpost.com
. You can also 
find us on TikTok.
 
 
Manage my email newsletters and alerts
Unsubscribe from Well+Being
 | 
Privacy Policy
 | 
Help
You received this email because you signed up for Well+Being or because it is included in your subscription.
©2023 The Washington Post
1301 K St NW, Washington DC 20071

subject: Boosting your energy and focus at work
body:
Five workday snacks to try.
View this email in your browser.
 
Presented by CVS Health
5 snacks that boost energy and focus during your workday
October 5, 2023
 
Americans are snacking more than ever: On average U.S. adults eat between one and three snacks a day, and they account for nearly a quarter of their daily calories. 
 
Nutritionists say you should snack wisely, as certain choices may either boost energy and productivity or bring on the 
midday slump
. 
 
Carbohydrates alone, for example, are digested quickly and may provide short-lived bursts of energy, says Angela Blackstone, a registered dietitian at the Ohio State University Wexner Medical Center. For more sustained energy, she recommends pairing carbohydrates with foods rich in fiber and protein and avoiding 
ultra-processed
, sugary, pro-
inflammatory foods that contribute to sugar crashes, and raise your risk for chronic diseases. 
 
 
Here are five workday snacks to try:
 
1. Plain Greek yogurt 
 
A cup of greek yogurt is high in protein and low in sugar, packed with calcium, probiotics, and stress-fighting B12. It may also help improve bone health. 
 
2. Mixed nuts 
 
Nuts are an easy-to-pack snack that are rich in protein and “heart-healthy fats,” according to Dr. Linda Anegawa, an internal and obesity medicine physician and medical director at PlushCare, which offers primary care and mental health services.
 
3. Hard-boiled eggs
 
Hard-boiled eggs are packed with protein and antioxidants. “Add a cheese stick in for extra satisfaction,” Anegawa says. “If saturated fat is something you are aiming to reduce, go for a part-skim version.” 
 
4. Raw vegetables and hummus 
 
Raw vegetables have fiber and antioxidants like vitamins A, K, and folate, which can help you feel full and maintain energy. Consider a serving of hummus with one cup of carrots, cucumbers, and bell peppers, Blackstone says.
 
5. Chickpeas 
 
Chickpeas are another easy-access snack that contain high levels of fiber and protein. Consider roasting them with spices to add flavor. 
Read Alexa Mikhail’s full article 
here
.
 
5 things you can do to reduce the risk of dementia
Dementia impacts 55 million people globally. While there is no cure, you can adopt some lifestyle changes to reduce the risk of developing the disease.
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 CONTENT FROM CVS HEALTH 
 
A Reboot for Preventive Care
 
Learn more about the historical context and current shortfalls in preventive care and take a deep dive into two promising solutions: Retail health care as an enabler of primary care services and a widening scope for pharmacists as access points for testing, vaccines and even treatment.
 
Read the report
 
 
More from Fortune Well:
Why are Teddy Grahams and Lunchables so addictive? 
It could be Big Tobacco’s fault.
The psychology behind men’s obsession with the Roman Empire
Brain experts weigh in.
 
Read more at Fortune Well
 
 
 
 
 
 
Leadership Next podcast
 
Laxman Narasimhan on Starbucks' plans for growth
 
This week, Alan Murray and Michal Lev-Ram speak with Starbucks CEO Laxman Narasimhan about why this is the right time to open thousands of new stores and how Chinese and Western relations are affecting the business.
 
Listen now
 
 
 
 
This email was sent to e.richmond@lcwmail.com

unsubscribe here

40 Fulton Street New York, NY. 10038

subject: RE: DEI Spotlight on Indigenous People Graphic
body:
Hello Amira,
 
Please see the attached.
 
Course Description:
 
Spotlight on Indigenous People in North America
 
Indigenous societies have flourished for thousands of years in the Americas, and their cultural contributions continue to impact modern life across North America. Today, there are over 560 federally recognized Native American tribes in the U.S. and more than 630 First Nation communities in Canada. This session investigates the complicated relationship between Indigenous communities and the government, explores the rich traditions of Indigenous peoples, and shares insight on some of the social issues Indigenous communities face today, so you can begin to understand the experience of your Indigenous talent, clients, and market.
 
 
Objectives
Describe key experiences that affect your Indigenous people colleagues.
Consider strategies for productively working with your Indigenous people, colleagues and communities.
Apply what we’ve learned in the session to promote inclusion at your workplace and connect more effectively with Indigenous clients and markets.
 
Please let me know if you need anything else. 
 
Best,
 
Emani Richmond
(she/her/hers)

Subject:
 Global Inclusion Forum Americas Day 1 is a wrap!
 
Team:
 
What an amazing start to the Global Inclusion Forum!
 
While we’re just getting started wanted to take a moment to acknowledge everyone’s hard work, commitment, and talent in creating this amazing experience for our UL Solutions colleagues.
 
We received a ton of positive feedback from participants that numbered more than 470 by my count 
😊
.  Here’s a quick sharing of feedback I received:
 
“This was one of the BEST DEI sessions I've ever been to.”
“
Such a great session - very interactive & informative”
“
Amani should be on our team...she pumped me up”
“For those in the session, we need to hire Larry!! 
 
Overall a very smooth delivery, even with some technology challenges.
 
A special thanks to Betsy for her poise and grace under pressure to ensure the program continued seamlessly, and to Larry, Emani and Conner for amazing instruction and creating a rich space for learning.
 
Looking forward to Day 2!
 
Thanks everyone.
 
Stephen

subject: LCW Facilitation Request: People w/ Disability
body:
Hello Ariadne,
 
My name is Emani Richmond and I am a consultant with LCW. We are hosting a 
Spotlight on People with Disabilities
 in December for Disability Pride Month and I wanted to inquire about your availability to facilitate this 60 minute training during the month of December.
 
Generally, we host the training on Thursday afternoons at 1pm EST. 
 
Therefore, the dates we are planning to potentially host the session are:
December 7
th
 1-2 pm ET
December 14
th
 1-2 pm ET
 
Please let me know if you are interested!
 
Best,
 
Emani Richmond

subject: Celebrating Hispanic Heritage Month and more
body:
Race Forward is proud to celebrate Hispanic Heritage Month and the Latino/a/x/e diaspora’s contributions to our efforts towards a multiracial society. 
Click here
 to view this message in a browser window.
 
Dear Emani, 
Race Forward is proud to celebrate Hispanic Heritage Month and the Latino/a/x/e diaspora’s contributions to our efforts towards a multiracial society. The concept of Hispanic Heritage Month was originally a weeklong celebration that was expanded to a month-long recognition in 1988. The month-long celebration coincides with the Independence Day celebrations of Costa Rica, Guatemala, Honduras, El Salvador, and Nicaragu
a.
 
Here's What's New!
Hispanic Heritage Month x International Podcast Day
Podcasters of Color are set to be the global majority in the future. 
In our latest episode of Momentum: A Race Forward Podcast, 
Hendel Leiva, Manager of Podcasts and Audio Initiatives interviews the co-founders of BIPOC Podcast Creators Tangia Al-awaji Estrada and Maribel Quezada-Smith. Tangia and Maribel share their stories of how they became podcasters, the challenges they experienced as women of color in podcasting, and how a Facebook group was the catalyst for founding and launching the BIPOC Podcast Creators in 2021. They also talk about the exponential growth of the BIPOC Podcast Creators community, and the wins in representation, access, and partnerships generated across the industry for its members.
Listen on Apple
Listen on Spotify
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Watch it Here
In the new video from Colorlines, “Courage Is Contagious” 
Alejandra Gomez, Executive Director of Living United for Change in Arizona (LUCHA), speaks about how the courage to exercise one’s voice against injustice can encourage others to enact theirs around a shared purpose, which over time can catalyze movement-building momentum that sustains for the long run. Reflecting on the ten years of organizing against deportations and laws such as the infamous SB1070 law in Arizona, she talks about the resilience to continue fighting for human dignity and “voicing our vote at the ballot box."
Revisiting Reflections
The 
current iteration of the immigration crisis
 has renewed calls for comprehensive reform. Our podcast mini-series Reflections – recorded in partnership 
with the 
National Partnership For New Americans (NPNA)
 – 
brings you exclusive interviews with leaders within the immigrant rights movement. The conversations emphasize the urgency of the moment across the movement that have been exacerbated the invisibility of communities, anti-Blackness in policy, the federal government's pace in addressing priorities, and maintaining motivation within the movement.
Listen on Apple
Listen on Spotify
 
 
 
What's YOUR identity?
The terms "Hispanic", "Latino/a", "Latinx", and “Latine” are often used interchangeably; however, they are VERY different.
If you belong to this diaspora, tell us which of these terms speak to you the most.
Hispanic
Latino/a
Latinx
Latine
Click To Respond
After responding, if you need to make a change, 
click here
. 
 
Services for Organizations
Race Forward is committed to transformational, sustainable change for racial justice. We provide services to help organizations develop and advance racially equitable policies and practices.
Our services are developed and delivered by a multiracial and multigenerational team of experts with extensive knowledge and experience in various areas, including policy and program development, leadership development and strategic coaching, community organizing, and racial equity.
Trainings
A practice of racial equity requires ongoing learning and self-reflection.
Race Forward offers comprehensive, interactive training to individuals, groups, organizations, and government agencies committed to taking action for racial justice and a multiracial democracy. 
Learn More
 
 
Organization Development & 
Capacity Building
Organizational change and development are critical to achieving racial justice.
Through training, coaching, assessments, and other processes, we help organizations normalize, operationalize, organize, and visualize racial justice.
Sign Up Now
 
 
Coaching & Technical Assistance
Our consulting and strategic coaching offerings assists organizations with problem-solving, goal-setting, and strategic planning that meets them where they are in their racial justice journey.
We also reimagine learning by developing unique and specialized educational materials (e.g., toolkits, flyers, fact sheets) for organizations and issue campaigns.
Sign Up Now
 
 
Speakers Bureau
Presentations and addresses can connect people and inspire change that advances racial justice. As such, the Race Forward team creates and delivers highly engaging, impactful presentations. Our team members have been featured as speakers, presenters, and keynoters at thousands of conferences and events.
Sign Up Now
 
 
Racial Equity Assessment
A Racial Equity Assessment is a useful tool for assessing the actual or anticipated effects—positive and negative—of decisions on different racial and ethnic groups within your organization and your constituency. The tool will also help assess your team’s readiness for adopting racially equitable practices.
Learn More
 
 
 
ICYMI: Save the Date
Facing Race is coming to The Gateway City! 2024 will mark our first fully in-person conference in six years. 
Stay tuned for more updates coming soon!
 
We hope your October is one of celebration and progress.
In solidarity,
Team Race Forward

DONATE
 
 
 
CONNECT

Race Forward
.

, or 
unsubscribe from all Race Forward emails
.

subject: Global Inclusion Forum Americas Day 1 is a wrap!
body:
Team:
 
What an amazing start to the Global Inclusion Forum!
 
While we’re just getting started wanted to take a moment to acknowledge everyone’s hard work, commitment, and talent in creating this amazing experience for our UL Solutions colleagues.
 
We received a ton of positive feedback from participants that numbered more than 470 by my count 
😊
.  Here’s a quick sharing of feedback I received:
 
“This was one of the BEST DEI sessions I've ever been to.”
“
Such a great session - very interactive & informative”
“
Amani should be on our team...she pumped me up”
“For those in the session, we need to hire Larry!! 
 
Overall a very smooth delivery, even with some technology challenges.
 
A special thanks to Betsy for her poise and grace under pressure to ensure the program continued seamlessly, and to Larry, Emani and Conner for amazing instruction and creating a rich space for learning.
 
Looking forward to Day 2!
 
Thanks everyone.
 
Stephen

subject: Meeting notes from UL Solutions post meeting
body:
Stephen has a list of feedback to share:
 
Stephen said excellent job, this is one of the best sessions they have attended, not surprised and really happy to have you folks join us
I loved your energy and I felt very supported
477 attendance #’s not sure what the actual attendance numbers were, we were at a full 360 in the last ½ hour of the session
There are some technical things I will go through w/ Betsy at the end
I want to be added to the group chat with the presenters and I want to talk to the whole group
The chat worked well and you folks were great about monitoring that; thanks for holding that
w/ the polls I know we had some clunkiness w/ that and it is taking a while for the polls to get in, and is that normal and we wait to see for that, 
Larry- we have that mental clock going on in our head, it’s really probably a min or 2, I would never take that out if you take out the engagement it becomes a lecture, and we are in the conversation with them, I want the to connect w/ the presentation 
Betsy, polling, I noticed there were people going in and creating their own polls and launching them
We use Mentimeter, and put the link in the chat and take over the screen to take over the questions on the screen, and if the link gets lost in the chat, and do you think that would be less confusing 
Make sure the poll is multi selection vs single selection; LB: I like to control it and have a single selection
We had an issue w/ the break b/c the machine was rebooting, Lindsay was supposed to get the shot clock for tomorrow, it will be a bar that progressively goes down, and we will be back soon for the next session
House cleaning slide will we share that at the beginning?
We have BRGs- instead of ERGs… 
On the intersectionality we didn’t get the sound for the video, when I shared the 2
nd
 deck and I reshared it and I missed it… 
I cannot do a breakout group after 300 people that’s why they didn’t work 
I know we talked about the photo in one slide, and it was supposed to be updated by our brand team, and I tried to advocate for the brand team and I said let’s talk about the guidelines, and we will talk about that in our teams and change out the image
I pulled the 2
nd
 break and I wasn’t sure how timing considerations was happening… 
 
 
Ultimately Stephen was anxious about everything but we did excellent. 
 
Emani Richmond
(she/her/hers)
Consultant
LCW

Subject:
 [EXT] Latin American Spotlight: Content Walk through follow-up
 
Hi Rashida,
 
Thank you for the discussion on the content for the Spotlight on Latin community today
 
See below for the video links and polls included in the training:
 
Video Links:
https://www.nbcnews.com/nightly-news/video/the-new-Latino-landscape-new-hampshire-s-population-boom-120968773794
Clip from TED Talk from Daisy Auger-Dominguez
SOURCE: 
https://youtu.be/u-VMr51yiVc
 
Poll 1
: 
How much do you know about Latinx? (choose one answer per question) 
(multi-question poll, single answer)
 
People whose cultural background or heritage is Latin American prefer to identify as: Latino/a  / (b) Hispanic / (c) Latinx / (d) Chicano / (e ) Their country of origin (e.g., Dominican-American or Guatemalan) / 
(f) Any of the above
 
Hispanics are projected to account for x% of net new workers between 2020 and 2030. 
10%
55%
78%
100%
 
True
/False 80% of new U.S. businesses over the last decade were created by Hispanics.
 
What percent of the U.S. population identifies as Latino/Hispanic?
1.1% 
6.0% 
10.2% 
12.4% 
18.7% 
 
True/
False
: In the past ten years, the state with the fastest growth rate of Latino residents was California.
 
Poll 2: 
Prioritizing Latinx Challenges (single answer)
What do you see or experience most frequently within your team or organization? (choose one)
Perceived as underperforming.
Judged more rigorously than their white peers.
Perceived as lacking confidence, competence, or presence due to lack of “assertiveness.”
Perceived as lacking initiative or ambition.
Perceived as having lower communication skills.
See few Latinx represented in leadership.
Poll 3
: Call to Action (multiple answer)
In this poll, choose ALL the actions you can take to be an even more inclusive leader or colleague in teams that include Hispanic/Latin colleagues:
Appreciate the diversity within the community. Remember that Latinx colleagues have different national, linguistic, and cultural backgrounds. 
Resist immediately under-evaluating your Latinx team members when they exhibit a work or communication approach that you're not used to.
Explicitly and regularly discuss the “unwritten rules” of success at your organization with everyone. Don't assume people know or "should know." 
 Advocate for cultural diversity with regard to voices, skills, and approaches. Help ensure your Latinx colleagues aren’t asked to do all the stretching. 
 Continue to educate yourself actively on the experiences of the Latinx community.
 
We will need to work in slide 12 (of the images of the famous leaders from the community) into the post session handout and will need 1-2 business days to make that addition. 
 
We have released the November dates for the BCI, and will await final word from you folks about dates to hold for December.
 
Best,
 
Emani Richmond
(she/her/hers)
Consultant
LCW

Subject:
 [EXT] Latin American Spotlight: Content Walk through follow-up
 
Hi Rashida,
 
Thank you for the discussion on the content for the Spotlight on Latin community today
 
See below for the video links and polls included in the training:
 
Video Links:
https://www.nbcnews.com/nightly-news/video/the-new-Latino-landscape-new-hampshire-s-population-boom-120968773794
Clip from TED Talk from Daisy Auger-Dominguez
SOURCE: 
https://youtu.be/u-VMr51yiVc
 
Poll 1
: 
How much do you know about Latinx? (choose one answer per question) 
(multi-question poll, single answer)
 
People whose cultural background or heritage is Latin American prefer to identify as: Latino/a  / (b) Hispanic / (c) Latinx / (d) Chicano / (e ) Their country of origin (e.g., Dominican-American or Guatemalan) / 
(f) Any of the above
 
Hispanics are projected to account for x% of net new workers between 2020 and 2030. 
10%
55%
78%
100%
 
True
/False 80% of new U.S. businesses over the last decade were created by Hispanics.
 
What percent of the U.S. population identifies as Latino/Hispanic?
1.1% 
6.0% 
10.2% 
12.4% 
18.7% 
 
True/
False
: In the past ten years, the state with the fastest growth rate of Latino residents was California.
 
Poll 2: 
Prioritizing Latinx Challenges (single answer)
What do you see or experience most frequently within your team or organization? (choose one)
Perceived as underperforming.
Judged more rigorously than their white peers.
Perceived as lacking confidence, competence, or presence due to lack of “assertiveness.”
Perceived as lacking initiative or ambition.
Perceived as having lower communication skills.
See few Latinx represented in leadership.
Poll 3
: Call to Action (multiple answer)
In this poll, choose ALL the actions you can take to be an even more inclusive leader or colleague in teams that include Hispanic/Latin colleagues:
Appreciate the diversity within the community. Remember that Latinx colleagues have different national, linguistic, and cultural backgrounds. 
Resist immediately under-evaluating your Latinx team members when they exhibit a work or communication approach that you're not used to.
Explicitly and regularly discuss the “unwritten rules” of success at your organization with everyone. Don't assume people know or "should know." 
 Advocate for cultural diversity with regard to voices, skills, and approaches. Help ensure your Latinx colleagues aren’t asked to do all the stretching. 
 Continue to educate yourself actively on the experiences of the Latinx community.
 
We will need to work in slide 12 (of the images of the famous leaders from the community) into the post session handout and will need 1-2 business days to make that addition. 
 
We have released the November dates for the BCI, and will await final word from you folks about dates to hold for December.
 
Best,
 
Emani Richmond
(she/her/hers)
Consultant
LCW

subject: LAST CALL – 3 Days Left to Submit Your 2024 Women MAKE Award Nominations
body:
Emani:
 
The time has come, the end is near, so let us make this very clear: 
You have 3 DAYS to 
submit
 your nominations for the 2024 Women MAKE Awards. We’ve made it easy by creating the 
Women MAKE Awards Nominations Guide
 
and designing a simple, straightforward nominations process you can 
access here
. 
Remember to consider women in two (2) categories: 
Honoree
: Nominee is currently employed in manufacturing at any level of the company, from the factory floor to the C-suite. A maximum of two Honorees from a single company may be selected for this award. 
Emerging Leader
: Nominee is a rising star currently employed in the manufacturing industry that has made significant contributions and excelled early in their career. 
An Emerging Leader nominee must be between 
18 and 30 years of age 
as of December 31, 2023. A maximum of one Emerging Leader from a single company may be selected for this award
. 
Click here to submit a nomination!
 
To learn more about the Women MAKE America Initiative 
click here
 or email 
WomenMAKE@nam.org
Happy Nominating!
Isabelle
