subject: Trolling corporate America
body:
Inside the business world's diversity dissonance and the potential consequence.
View this email in your browser.
   
Inside corporate America’s diversity dissonance—and the resulting consequence
October 4, 2023
 
Good afternoon.
Corporate America’s 2020 rallying cries for racial equity and social justice have since turned into a bleating whimper. Netflix, Disney, and Warner Bros. Discovery are among the spate of companies that 
have parted ways with
 high-level diversity, equity, and inclusion executives. And as 
Bloomberg 
noted
 last month, talk of DEI has fallen precipitously in the wake of the Supreme Court’s reversal of affirmative action, in what some fear might be the coup de grace to what was once a zealous championing of corporate diversity efforts.
Alas, it begs the question: Did corporate America have courage in its socially conscious convictions in the first place?
It’s a perceptive query my colleague Maria Aspan poses in an enthralling and 
thought-provoking piece
 published this week, exploring the business world’s volant retreat from ESG-related matters.
“Companies find themselves stumbling down a rapidly narrowing path between the razor-wire fences of heightened consumer expectations and well-organized political trolling,” she writes, pointing to recent implosions of socially conscious branding, corporate skirmishes with lawmakers over “woke” ideology, and an ever-expanding wave of 
legal challenges
 to companies and investors over their diversity, equity, and inclusion policies.
But wait. There’s more. The 2024 election cycle is fast approaching, and if it’s anything like its predecessor, it will be a grueling fight that turns seemingly innocuous efforts to ameliorate historical wrongs into a hyper-partisan ploy for votes. Corporations will almost certainly be caught in the crosshairs.
Admittedly—cue the world’s tiniest violin—this isn’t easy terrain for leaders, whether CEOs or chief diversity heads, to traverse. But companies that offer shallow, disingenuous commitments to societal betterment can expect to be pilloried by both the right and the left—along with their consumers, employees, and the public at large.
Acting with conviction will become all the more crucial, requiring that leaders prepare for how to respond to pushback, lest they be lambasted as weak-spined and underhanded. That has already come to fruition, Aspan notes, and it’s no surprise that terms like “‘pinkwashing,’ ‘rainbow washing,’ and ‘performative allyship’ have entered the corporate lexicon.
So where does that leave companies? Well, they must first reckon upfront with the financial costs of executing their big stakeholder capitalist ideas, Paul Washington, head of the ESG Center for the Conference Board, tells Aspan. 
While few for-profit firms will follow the lead of a Patagonia or a Ben & Jerry’s—or on the other side of the bipartisan coin, an X, formerly known as Twitter—they can create stronger, more coherent guidelines on when and how to engage in vocal corporate activism. Or, as Aspan writes, “shut up about their so-called values.”
Check out her compulsory reading on the 
trolling of corporate America here
.
Ruth Umoh
@ruthumohnews
ruth.umoh@fortune.com
What’s Trending
 
See something, say something. 
CEOs don’t want to enter the political fray, ex-Merck CEO Ken Frazier, one of the few Black Fortune 500 chief executives, told attendees at 
Fortune
’s CEO Initiative on Tuesday. But they have a responsibility as the “most influential citizens” to speak up when elected politicians aren’t upholding the country’s democratic ideals and principles. 
Fortune
Mixed bag. 
Good news: Boards are turning less to CEOs for director seats, a practice that has excluded women and those from underrepresented groups. The bad: They’ve withdrawn from a previous increase in appointing women and racial minorities to openings. 
WSJ
Unauthorized immigration
. U.S. employers benefit from a broken migration system. Migrants today are employed in nearly every blue-collar industry, performing jobs like packing Cheerios, washing hotel sheets, and sanitizing chicken-processing plants. 
NYT
 
The Emerging CFO: Future Finance Leaders
 
Finance and IT as co-innovation partners
Join Fortune and Workday on Wednesday, Oct. 25, at 11 a.m. ET. We'll be joined by CFOs from Kickstarter, McKinsey, and Workday. 
 
Register now
 
The Big Think 
 
At what point should 
age preclude a CEO
 from sitting atop a company? It’s both a challenging and awkward question to answer, says 
Fortune
 senior writer Lila MacLellan. There’s the famed activist investor Carl Icahn, who, at age 87, still runs his Icahn Enterprises. Michael Bloomberg, the 81-year-old founder of his namesake financial information and media giant. And Blackstone CEO and cofounder Stephen Schwarzman, 76. While some aging leaders have named successors, many have been accused of “being unable or unwilling to make space for a new, more diverse generation of leaders.” 
 
 
Thanks for reading.

Stephen

Subject:
 [EXT] Latin American Spotlight: Content Walk through follow-up
 
Hi Rashida,
 
Thank you for the discussion on the content for the Spotlight on Latin community today
 
See below for the video links and polls included in the training:
 
Video Links:
https://www.nbcnews.com/nightly-news/video/the-new-Latino-landscape-new-hampshire-s-population-boom-120968773794
Clip from TED Talk from Daisy Auger-Dominguez
SOURCE: 
https://youtu.be/u-VMr51yiVc
 
Poll 1
: 
How much do you know about Latinx? (choose one answer per question) 
(multi-question poll, single answer)
 
People whose cultural background or heritage is Latin American prefer to identify as: Latino/a  / (b) Hispanic / (c) Latinx / (d) Chicano / (e ) Their country of origin (e.g., Dominican-American or Guatemalan) / 
(f) Any of the above
 
Hispanics are projected to account for x% of net new workers between 2020 and 2030. 
10%
55%
78%
100%
 
True
/False 80% of new U.S. businesses over the last decade were created by Hispanics.
 
What percent of the U.S. population identifies as Latino/Hispanic?
1.1% 
6.0% 
10.2% 
12.4% 
18.7% 
 
True/
False
: In the past ten years, the state with the fastest growth rate of Latino residents was California.
 
Poll 2: 
Prioritizing Latinx Challenges (single answer)
What do you see or experience most frequently within your team or organization? (choose one)
Perceived as underperforming.
Judged more rigorously than their white peers.
Perceived as lacking confidence, competence, or presence due to lack of “assertiveness.”
Perceived as lacking initiative or ambition.
Perceived as having lower communication skills.
See few Latinx represented in leadership.
Poll 3
: Call to Action (multiple answer)
In this poll, choose ALL the actions you can take to be an even more inclusive leader or colleague in teams that include Hispanic/Latin colleagues:
Appreciate the diversity within the community. Remember that Latinx colleagues have different national, linguistic, and cultural backgrounds. 
Resist immediately under-evaluating your Latinx team members when they exhibit a work or communication approach that you're not used to.
Explicitly and regularly discuss the “unwritten rules” of success at your organization with everyone. Don't assume people know or "should know." 
 Advocate for cultural diversity with regard to voices, skills, and approaches. Help ensure your Latinx colleagues aren’t asked to do all the stretching. 
 Continue to educate yourself actively on the experiences of the Latinx community.
 
We will need to work in slide 12 (of the images of the famous leaders from the community) into the post session handout and will need 1-2 business days to make that addition. 
 
We have released the November dates for the BCI, and will await final word from you folks about dates to hold for December.
 
Best,
 
Emani Richmond

Subject:
 [EXT] Latin American Spotlight: Content Walk through follow-up
 
Hi Rashida,
 
Thank you for the discussion on the content for the Spotlight on Latin community today
 
See below for the video links and polls included in the training:
 
Video Links:
https://www.nbcnews.com/nightly-news/video/the-new-Latino-landscape-new-hampshire-s-population-boom-120968773794
Clip from TED Talk from Daisy Auger-Dominguez
SOURCE: 
https://youtu.be/u-VMr51yiVc
 
Poll 1
: 
How much do you know about Latinx? (choose one answer per question) 
(multi-question poll, single answer)
 
People whose cultural background or heritage is Latin American prefer to identify as: Latino/a  / (b) Hispanic / (c) Latinx / (d) Chicano / (e ) Their country of origin (e.g., Dominican-American or Guatemalan) / 
(f) Any of the above
 
Hispanics are projected to account for x% of net new workers between 2020 and 2030. 
10%
55%
78%
100%
 
True
/False 80% of new U.S. businesses over the last decade were created by Hispanics.
 
What percent of the U.S. population identifies as Latino/Hispanic?
1.1% 
6.0% 
10.2% 
12.4% 
18.7% 
 
True/
False
: In the past ten years, the state with the fastest growth rate of Latino residents was California.
 
Poll 2: 
Prioritizing Latinx Challenges (single answer)
What do you see or experience most frequently within your team or organization? (choose one)
Perceived as underperforming.
Judged more rigorously than their white peers.
Perceived as lacking confidence, competence, or presence due to lack of “assertiveness.”
Perceived as lacking initiative or ambition.
Perceived as having lower communication skills.
See few Latinx represented in leadership.
Poll 3
: Call to Action (multiple answer)
In this poll, choose ALL the actions you can take to be an even more inclusive leader or colleague in teams that include Hispanic/Latin colleagues:
Appreciate the diversity within the community. Remember that Latinx colleagues have different national, linguistic, and cultural backgrounds. 
Resist immediately under-evaluating your Latinx team members when they exhibit a work or communication approach that you're not used to.
Explicitly and regularly discuss the “unwritten rules” of success at your organization with everyone. Don't assume people know or "should know." 
 Advocate for cultural diversity with regard to voices, skills, and approaches. Help ensure your Latinx colleagues aren’t asked to do all the stretching. 
 Continue to educate yourself actively on the experiences of the Latinx community.
 
We will need to work in slide 12 (of the images of the famous leaders from the community) into the post session handout and will need 1-2 business days to make that addition. 
 
We have released the November dates for the BCI, and will await final word from you folks about dates to hold for December.
 
Best,
 
Emani Richmond
(she/her/hers)
Consultant
LCW

Poll 1
: 
How much do you know about Latinx? (choose one answer per question) 
(multi-question poll, single answer)
 
People whose cultural background or heritage is Latin American prefer to identify as: Latino/a  / (b) Hispanic / (c) Latinx / (d) Chicano / (e ) Their country of origin (e.g., Dominican-American or Guatemalan) / 
(f) Any of the above

/False 80% of new U.S. businesses over the last decade were created by Hispanics.

: In the past ten years, the state with the fastest growth rate of Latino residents was California.
 
Poll 2: 
Prioritizing Latinx Challenges (single answer)
What do you see or experience most frequently within your team or organization? (choose one)
Perceived as underperforming.
Judged more rigorously than their white peers.
Perceived as lacking confidence, competence, or presence due to lack of “assertiveness.”
Perceived as lacking initiative or ambition.
Perceived as having lower communication skills.

Poll 3
: Call to Action (multiple answer)
In this poll, choose ALL the actions you can take to be an even more inclusive leader or colleague in teams that include Hispanic/Latin colleagues:
Appreciate the diversity within the community. Remember that Latinx colleagues have different national, linguistic, and cultural backgrounds. 
Resist immediately under-evaluating your Latinx team members when they exhibit a work or communication approach that you're not used to.
Explicitly and regularly discuss the “unwritten rules” of success at your organization with everyone. Don't assume people know or "should know." 
 Advocate for cultural diversity with regard to voices, skills, and approaches. Help ensure your Latinx colleagues aren’t asked to do all the stretching. 
 Continue to educate yourself actively on the experiences of the Latinx community.

subject: Bigotry Is Not OK
body:
No matter who you are  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌
Forwarded this email? 
Subscribe here
 for more
Thank you for joining the Sharon’s Anti-Racism Newsletter community. A gentle reminder that a 
paid subscription
 supports the work of writing and publishing. Alternatively, you can make a one-off contribution to newsletter running costs via my 
Ko-Fi page
. 
Bigotry Is Not OK
No matter who you are
Sharon Hurley Hall
Oct 4
 
READ IN APP
 
Hello friends,
The title says it all. Bigotry is not ok. 
As I posted on LinkedIn some time back:
I am for equality and against bigotry. That means I am against: 
racism 
anti-Blackness 
anti-LGBTQIA2S+ sentiments 
antisemitism 
ableism 
xenophobia 
and other types of bigotry 
So, why am I bringing this up now? Because I recently came across a Black man (who had been introduced to me as a key supporter of an important anti-racism mission) implying that there was something wrong with being gay. That’s homophobia, and I know it caused harm to some people in the room, even if they had not revealed they were gay. That was not ok.
I raised it with the person who made the introduction, and I plan to have a more detailed conversation with them soon. It is not ok to let it slide.
Share
That leads me to another point. As my grandparents used to say, two wrongs don’t make a right. 
Just because we have been discriminated against, it doesn’t mean we should discriminate against others in turn. 
I decided a long time ago that I did not want to make anyone feel the way the racists made me feel when I lived in France. For me that means, being against all those types of bigotry I listed at the start. 
And it means that even if there is anti-Blackness in other communities - and we know there is - that doesn’t make it right for me, as a Black woman, to be bigoted against those communities.
I’m not saying I always get it right. I mess up. In fact, that LinkedIn post was made after I inadvertently liked a post with sentiments that didn’t match my values and was called in for it. 
When I mess up
, I follow the advice I give you: I accept responsibility, apologise, do what I can to repair any harm, and avoid making the same mistake again. I don’t look for cookies either. 
That’s what I did then, and that’s what I’ll continue to do. 
But the important thing here is that I actively set out to avoid discriminating against others - as an anti-racist, how can I do any less?
What do you think?
Leave a comment
Thanks for reading,
Sharon

subject: 🤔 unveil your attachment style
body:
take this quiz to figure out your attachment style, prioritize your breast health, and the latest on student loan repayments.
 
Issue #40 October 4, 2023 
Read in browser
 
          
TOGETHER WITH
 
   
Was this email forwarded to you by someone awesome?
You need your own — 
subscribe here for free
.
 
 
"Good health and good sense are two of life's greatest blessings." 
— Publilius Syrus
FOR YOUR RELATIONSHIPS
Attachment Styles
Ever find yourself freaking out when your partner doesn’t text back immediately? Or you’re totally chill when you don’t hear from them for days?
Our attachment styles likely explain these ingrained relationship tendencies. 
Attachment theory
 says the bond with our primary caregivers shapes how we connect as adults.
There are four styles:
Secure:
 You feel worthy of love and can healthily depend on others. As a child, your needs were consistently met with love.
Avoidant:
 You avoid intimacy and are very independent. You distrust others and don’t like feeling close. Your childhood caregivers may have been distant or punishing when you expressed needs.
Anxious:
 You desperately seek intimacy but constantly fear rejection. You need a lot of reassurance from your partner because your childhood bond was inconsistent.
Disorganized:
 You have extreme difficulty trusting others and behave unpredictably in relationships. Your childhood caregivers themselves were sources of fear.
Continue reading
TOGETHER WITH 
MONDAY.COM
A task management software that doesn't suck
  
Save time and get rid of all those mundane tasks, by letting 
monday.com's
 clever automations do them for you. 
It's an intuitive and fully customizable project management software where workflows become effortless, and team collaboration can finally thrive.
Ditch working harder for working smarter, and see why 180,000+ customers love it.
  
Try it free today
FOR THE BODY
Breast Cancer Awareness
October is Breast Cancer Awareness Month, so let’s talk about why staying on top of breast health is vital.
Breast cancer is the most common cancer among American women, except for skin cancers. About 1 in 8 women will develop invasive breast cancer over their lifetime.
The good news?
 Death rates have been steadily dropping thanks to earlier detection and better treatments. But early diagnosis before symptoms emerge is key.
What can you do?
Know your risk factors
 like family history, reproductive history, weight, alcohol use, and breast density. Talk to your doctor about when to start screenings.
Do monthly self breast exams
 to familiarize yourself with your breast landscape. Report any changes to your doctor promptly.
Get routine mammograms.
 Yearly mammograms are recommended starting at age 45 for average risk women. Earlier if you have risk factors.
Limit alcohol.
 The more you drink, the higher your risk. Stick to no more than 1 drink per day.
Continue reading
TOGETHER WITH MIRO
The Challenge Bowl
  
 
The Challenge Bowl
 is a fun and easy way for team members to answer questions and complete short activities to deepen team bonds.
Pick one item from the Challenge Bowl each day to liven up daily meetings or run through the entire board to engage your team during virtual team lunches or happy hours.
How it Works:
 
🗣️ You'll need a logged-in facilitator to reveal hidden frames
📝 Each team member takes turns selecting a challenge (numbered sticky note from the bowl). 
Tip:
 Use the color key to determine whether you select a silly question, thoughtful question, or a short activity.
✅ The facilitator reveals the challenge and team members must answer a question or complete the activity before moving on to the next item.
Be prepared for some fun, giggles, and even some deep thinking. You can even customize the template to create your own Team Challenge Bowl tailored for your team.
  
🙌 
Get the free Challenge Bowl Template
FOR THE WALLET
Student Loans Are Back
Student loan payments officially resume on Sunday after being paused for over three years during the pandemic.
Despite pushback from advocates, the Biden administration is restarting payments for over 28 million borrowers. Some borrowers plan to strike and not repay their loans in protest.
President Biden released a new income-driven repayment plan to ease the transition (SAVE), but interest will still accrue and credit scores may take a hit.
Biden's broad student debt forgiveness plan remains blocked in court. Meanwhile, a government shutdown could disrupt the repayment restart.
The administration is also working on more targeted relief through a lengthy regulatory process. With repayments restarting right before the 2024 election, student debt will remain a major political issue.
Sooo, what does that mean?

subject: Are you getting enough protein?
body:
Protein is the only way to get the nine essential amino acids your body needs.
View this email in your browser.
 
Presented by CVS Health
Are you getting enough protein? How to figure out the right amount for you
October 3, 2023
 
Protein, one of three types of macronutrients, helps our bodies repair the muscles, bones, and cells vital to keeping our bodies structurally intact. Protein is made up of chains of amino acids, and because the nine essential amino acids are not made by the body, we must get protein from food. 
 
But how much protein do you 
actually
 need every day? 
 
The general recommendation is that most healthy adults need about 0.8 grams of protein per kilogram of body weight. You can also multiply your weight in pounds by 0.36 to calculate the rounded ideal number of grams. For example, a person who weighs 170 pounds would need around 62 grams of protein per day.
 
Rather than getting caught up in complicated calculations, some experts say to just focus on eating protein-rich foods throughout the day, along with a balance of fruits, vegetables, grains, and dairy. 
 
Do you need more protein as you age?
 
Studies have shown a correlation between increased protein intake for older adults and improved cognitive function and physical health. Since muscle mass begins to shrink starting in your thirties, some experts recommend increasing protein intake to 1–1.2 grams of protein per kilogram of body weight beginning at age 40. 
 
How much protein do you need if you exercise regularly? 
 
For those regularly active, consider upping protein intake to 1.2 to 2 grams per kilogram of body weight. This protein should be spaced out during the day. 
 
What’s the best type of protein? 
 
Don’t just think about eating more meat. Consider proteins that are not high in saturated fats and not highly processed.
 
Protein-rich foods:
Salmon: 27 grams of protein for a 5-oz. salmon
Lean chicken breast: 54 grams of protein for a 6-oz. lean chicken breast 
Whitefish: 38 grams of protein for one filet of whitefish
Turkey breast: 29 grams of protein for 3½ oz. of turkey breast 
 
Vegetarian protein-rich foods:   
Lentils: 12 grams of protein for ½ cup of lentils 
Greek yogurt: 15–20 grams of protein for a 6-oz. cup of yogurt
Eggs: 6–8 grams of protein in one egg 
Chickpeas (garbanzo beans): 14.5 grams of protein for one cup of chickpeas

here
.

subject: 10/3/2023 - All Staff Recap
body:
Good afternoon LCW,
 
Below are a few next steps and resources t
hat will help us make some progress
 towards our revenue goal:
 
Reach out to
 your personal and professional network to secure (3) referrals for BD.
Call and engage our current clients to gain insights into their current priorities and inform them about the ways in which we are assisting other clients.
If you need assistance with a project, feel free to post it in the Help Wanted Teams channel. If you find yourself with some available time, 
consider browsing the Help Wanted section to offer assistance to your colleagues.
 
 
Our Q3 Review will take place on November 13
th 
and we’ll circle back on the progress of these next steps at our next All-Staff in a couple of weeks. 
 
Thanks,
 
Briza Cardenas  
(she/her)

subject: RE: Client Notes: Brazil Session (Oct 10th)
body:
I´ve sent you the file using WeTransfer.
 
20 slides + Thank you
 
From:
 Emani Richmond <e.richmond@lcwmail.com> 
Sent:
 Monday, October 2, 2023 11:34 PM
To:
 ica@infolink.com.br
Subject:
 Re: Client Notes: Brazil Session (Oct 10th)
 
Hello Lucy,
 
Thank you for sending these slides over. We try to have images on screen be easier for participants to read and digest, so I would encourage you to limit the text on screen only to what is most helpful for people to read during the session, and then have the rest of the text go into the speaker notes that you will read during the session.
 
Here is a link to the version of the Cultural program we put together for the client last year. Within these slides you will find the LCW definition of Culture, also key slides we share for steps people can take to become an ally to our focus group which are Brazilian colleagues at this time.
 
https://www.dropbox.com/scl/fi/flelphitqougu4vthnfw3/Carta_Understanding_Brazilian_Work_Culture-2023.pptx?rlkey=03fioaykxsp8h0verq2lxsiyn&dl=0
Carta_Understanding_Brazilian_Work_Culture-2023.pptx
Shared with Dropbox
www.dropbox.com
 
 
Please let me know if you have any trouble accessing the link above. I will review the slides you sent me tomorrow afternoon but I think they should be sufficient to cover the general conversation the client wants to bring into their organization. 
 
Best,
 
Emani Richmond
(she/her/hers)
Consultant
LCW

Hi Emani
 
I was writing about cultural questions when I realized that LCW probably has its own way to present it. Could you please send me a presentation on Working with abc cultures? It doesn´t matter which, I just want to check on the models. I´m at risk of rewriting something that LCW has already done.

Thank you!

 Monday, October 2, 2023 9:46 AM

Here it goes
 
From:
 Emani Richmond <
e.richmond@lcwmail.com
> 
Sent:
 Thursday, September 28, 2023 12:55 PM
To:
 
ica@infolink.com.br
Subject:
 Client Notes: Brazil Session (Oct 10th)
 
Hi Lucy,
 
It was BEYOND a pleasure to meet you and connect over the course we will be delivering on October 10
th
. 
 
**Could you please send me your head shot you would like to use in the training?
 
Client: 
Carta
 (Link to website)
~1,200 employees, average session attendance 30-70 people
Audience: All staff
Major offices located in: NYC, Rio, San Diego
 
As mentioned on the call here’s our aggressive content timeline:
Lucy to create and send a presentation by Monday or sooner if possible
I will send the content to our design team by Tuesday
I will try to get it back by Thursday from the design team so you can review the final slides on Friday
 
Client notes on expectations for the training:
Hi Emani - Wanted to provide some general themes and expectations for this training: 
Distinction between Latine, Hispanic, and Brazilian identities
 (I'm hoping there will be some 
graphic
 representation to pair with this)
calling out 
US perspective
 in language 
addressing 
evolving terms
 (Latina/o, Latinx, Latine) 
Spotlight 
differences between Brazil and US
 
(include a nod to employment law differences, cultural context, and political relationships)
reasoning - Carta has a large Brazilian population, Carta's first international office (#3), 2nd or 3rd largest office
Unpacking stereotypes
 that might be made about these identity groups - this might be the space to hear from the culture native or where you point to the historical timeline that impacts those stereotypes
layer with 
data on why it matters 
or how it impacts workplace dynamics 
Tips/Strategies on interrupting bias 
against Latine, Hispanic and/or Brazilian identities in the workplace. Here are few examples of things that have come up
accents (underscoring the cognitive power that it takes to translate from native language to English)
asking too many questions (to bridge understanding between US and Brazilian culture)
microaggressions on time differences and seasons (reminding folks of time differences, opposite season from the northern hemisphere)
access to equitable resources (barriers traveling to the US, working on US holidays, etc) 
 
I look forward to connecting with you again once the content is finalized.
 
Hugs and kisses!
 
Emani Richmond
(she/her/hers)
Consultant
LCW

subject: Reminder to Register Now for Snapchat’s DEI Innovation Summit
body:
Register today to attend!
 
Thursday, October 26, 2023
9 AM PT | 12 PM ET | 5 PM GMT
REGISTER NOW!
 
 
 
Writer, Comedian, Actor
 
Actor
 
Vice President, Diversity, Equity & Inclusion, Snap Inc.
We noticed that you haven’t registered yet to attend Snapchat’s 2023 DEI Innovation Summit. We hope you’ll join us for this free, virtual event that brings together thought leaders and DEI experts for a day of courageous conversations to drive bold action. You'll hear from Sabrina Wu, the writer, actor, and comedian most recently seen in Joy Ride, and Ismael Cruz Córdova, the actor most recently appearing in The Lord of the Rings: The Rings of Power, along with Oona King, Vice President of Diversity, Equity & Inclusion at Snap Inc. and 20+ leaders in tech, as they spark candid conversations about how to drive equity in the industry using tools from 
The Action to Catalyze Tech (ACT) Report.
 
Best practices and strategies for:
 Inclusive leadership • Operationalizing DEI • Product inclusion • Sharing DEI data, metrics, goals • Pathways for underrepresented talent Whether you’re a DEI champion or just starting, register today to be a part of the solution.
REGISTER NOW!
 
Live captioning and American Sign Language interpretation will be available during this event.
Should you require any other accommodations or services to fully participate, please email 
accessibility@snap.com
.
You are receiving this email because you are invited to the DEI Innovation Summit. If you wish to unsubscribe, please click link below.
Unsubscribe

Subject:
 Post session handout: Hispanic Spotlight (next Thursday)
 
Hey Kelly, 
 
We have a spotlight for Richemont coming up next Thursday. For their learning series we have provided them with post session handouts. Could you please use the following slides and turn them into an interactive handout, similar to the ones previously provided?
 
Content Location: 
 
Please use the following slides:
 
12 (please include the image of each of these leaders long with a short description of who they are), 17-22, 25,
 
Descriptions to accompany images used on slide 12:
 
(1 – Cosmonaut Arnaldo Tamayo 
Méndez
) Was the first Black person in space.
 
(
2- 
Physicist
 Dr. Jessica Esquivel
, Mexican American physicist of Fermilabs, a U.S. Dept of Energy national laboratory specializing in h-energy particle physics)  The focus of this person’s research was on uncovering as yet undiscovered subatomic particles
 
(3 – 
Harry Shum Jr.) 
Was born in Costa Rica and speaks 3 languages, is a Costa Rican-born Chinese American actor, dancer, and choreographer who speaks English, Spanish and Chinese.
 
(4- 
Danny Peña
, better known as "Godfree”, Founder & Host of Gamertag Radio) This is the first Hispanic person inducted into the Podcast Hall of Fame
 
(
5- Adelina “Nina” Otero-Warren 
was an activist who fought for women’s voting rights) Their face appears on the U.S. quarter as of August 2022.
 
(6-
Jonathan Garcia - 
Founder, Simmitri – solar energy company) Is a second-generation CEO and solar power entrepreneur.
 
(
7 – Dora Herrera
, James Beard Winner and restauranteur) Studied at Stanford and partners with Goldman Sachs
 
(8-Chemist 
Luis Miramontes synthesized
 the active ingredient used to create the first effective and safe oral contraceptive—making “the pill” possible and accessible to revolutionize healthcare) Was the first Mexican person in the USA Inventors Hall of Fame 
 
(9-
Carolina Contreras, 
CEO of two salons and the 
Miss 
Rizos
 Foundation
 — which aims to change the world one curl at a time and embrace natural hair — while maintaining her incredible social media presence on 
Instagram
.) Is a CEO and a Social Impact Entrepreneur
 
(#
10-Mike Krieger
) A Brazilian American co-founded Instagram with Kevin Systrom and was born in Sao Paulo Brazil (moved to CA in 2004 to attend Stanford).
 
If you have any questions please message me, I hope you disconnect and don’t see this message till Monday AM!
 
Emani Richmond

 the active ingredient used to create the first effective and safe oral contraceptive—making “the pill” possible and accessible to revolutionize healthcare) Was the first Mexican person in the USA Inventors Hall of Fame 
 
(9-
Carolina Contreras, 
CEO of two salons and the 
Miss 
Rizos
 Foundation
 — which aims to change the world one curl at a time and embrace natural hair — while maintaining her incredible social media presence on 
Instagram
.) Is a CEO and a Social Impact Entrepreneur
 
(#
10-Mike Krieger
) A Brazilian American co-founded Instagram with Kevin Systrom and was born in Sao Paulo Brazil (moved to CA in 2004 to attend Stanford).
 
If you have any questions please message me, I hope you disconnect and don’t see this message till Monday AM!
 
Emani Richmond

body:
Here is a download link for you. Look in the bottom right corner to see the download icon and you can choose the file size that works best for you. Let me know if you need anything else!
 
https://vimeo.com/870729852/e903da04c6?share=copy
 
 
From:
 Emani Richmond <e.richmond@lcwmail.com> 
Sent:
 Tuesday, October 3, 2023 7:42 AM
To:
 Dustin Puehler <d.puehler@lcwmail.com>
Subject:
 Video Edit Request [Time Sensitive] Thursday Session
Importance:
 High
 
Hey Dustin,
 
I am delivering a training on Thursday at noon and I think this clip will really further discussion within the training. 
 
Are you able to cut the following video to include the time stamped portions below. I ideally need this clip as soon as you are able to produce it, but Wednesday by EOD is my official cut off time. If the clip cannot be edited and embedded into the training I will be able to do without it, just hoping to bring in some more course interaction for a global webinar presentation situation. 
 
Please let me know if this is possible:
 
Requested clip portions:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=akOe5-UsQ2o&t=3s
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=akOe5-UsQ2o&t=3s
 
** The requested ordering of the clips is strategic, as long as it doesn't look wonky I had hoped to have part 1, part 3, then part 2 be the order of the clips
(Pt. 1)
 3:28 - 5:12 
Start with "Communication experts say.... 
(Pt. 3)
 
10:43- 11:34
"What do you call being impacted...
(Pt. 2) 
8:40- 8:49 
"you cannot fix a problem unless you can see it" fade to Black
 

The urgency of intersectionality | Kimberlé Crenshaw
Now more than ever, it's important to look boldly at the reality of race and gender bias -- and understand how the two can combine to create even more harm. ...
www.youtube.com

 

The urgency of intersectionality | Kimberlé Crenshaw
Now more than ever, it's important to look boldly at the reality of race and gender bias -- and understand how the two can combine to create even more harm. ...
www.youtube.com

Again, if this is not possible please let me know. 
 
Thank you,
 
Emani Richmond

Consultant

d.puehler@lcwmail.com
>
Subject:
 MIC Course Feedback
 
Hey Dustin,
 
Thank you for this smooth and informative collaboration experience. I just reviewed the MIC module and I have a few pieces of cosmetic course feedback. Once these changes are made we are ready to deliver it to the client so that’s awesome this will be an line item we can invoice for. 
 
If the feedback provided is not specific enough please let me know and I can add more details. 
 
MIC Course Feedback:
Slide 5/17
Timing is off for 'Minimization worldview'
The image on screen is slower than the script
 
Slide 7/17
DIN model (interpret should be in All Caps) when the model is introduced 
 
Slide 8/17
The image used to describe the Gen Y group is too stock image like, is there a more realistic group image that can be used here?
 
Slide 15/17
Heading 'Developing' (is cut off on screen) Intercultural Competence
 
Slide 16/17
Can we change this man that's thinking, into something that looks more genuine and introspective?
 
Thank you again!
 
Emani Richmond

To:

Cc:
 Tamara Thorpe <t.thorpe@lcwmail.com>; LAIR Gaelle (RIC-US) <gaelle.lair@richemont.com>; BONARI Jessica (RIC-US) <jessica.bonari@richemont.com>
Subject:
 [EXT] Latin American Spotlight: Content Walk through follow-up
 
Hi Rashida,
 
Thank you for the discussion on the content for the Spotlight on Latin community today
 
See below for the video links and polls included in the training:
 
Video Links:
https://www.nbcnews.com/nightly-news/video/the-new-Latino-landscape-new-hampshire-s-population-boom-120968773794
Clip from TED Talk from Daisy Auger-Dominguez
SOURCE: 
https://youtu.be/u-VMr51yiVc
 
Poll 1
: 
How much do you know about Latinx? (choose one answer per question) 
(multi-question poll, single answer)
 
People whose cultural background or heritage is Latin American prefer to identify as: Latino/a  / (b) Hispanic / (c) Latinx / (d) Chicano / (e ) Their country of origin (e.g., Dominican-American or Guatemalan) / 
(f) Any of the above
 
Hispanics are projected to account for x% of net new workers between 2020 and 2030. 
10%
55%
78%
100%
 
True
/False 80% of new U.S. businesses over the last decade were created by Hispanics.
 
What percent of the U.S. population identifies as Latino/Hispanic?
1.1% 
6.0% 
10.2% 
12.4% 
18.7% 
 
True/
False
: In the past ten years, the state with the fastest growth rate of Latino residents was California.
 
Poll 2: 
Prioritizing Latinx Challenges (single answer)
What do you see or experience most frequently within your team or organization? (choose one)
Perceived as underperforming.
Judged more rigorously than their white peers.
Perceived as lacking confidence, competence, or presence due to lack of “assertiveness.”
Perceived as lacking initiative or ambition.
Perceived as having lower communication skills.
See few Latinx represented in leadership.
Poll 3
: Call to Action (multiple answer)
In this poll, choose ALL the actions you can take to be an even more inclusive leader or colleague in teams that include Hispanic/Latin colleagues:
Appreciate the diversity within the community. Remember that Latinx colleagues have different national, linguistic, and cultural backgrounds. 
Resist immediately under-evaluating your Latinx team members when they exhibit a work or communication approach that you're not used to.
Explicitly and regularly discuss the “unwritten rules” of success at your organization with everyone. Don't assume people know or "should know." 
 Advocate for cultural diversity with regard to voices, skills, and approaches. Help ensure your Latinx colleagues aren’t asked to do all the stretching. 
 Continue to educate yourself actively on the experiences of the Latinx community.
 
We will need to work in slide 12 (of the images of the famous leaders from the community) into the post session handout and will need 1-2 business days to make that addition. 
 
We have released the November dates for the BCI, and will await final word from you folks about dates to hold for December.
 
Best,
 
Emani Richmond
(she/her/hers)
Consultant
LCW

Hi Lucy,
 
It was BEYOND a pleasure to meet you and connect over the course we will be delivering on October 10
th
. 
 
**Could you please send me your head shot you would like to use in the training?
 
Client: 
Carta
 (Link to website)
~1,200 employees, average session attendance 30-70 people
Audience: All staff
Major offices located in: NYC, Rio, San Diego
 
As mentioned on the call here’s our aggressive content timeline:
Lucy to create and send a presentation by Monday or sooner if possible
I will send the content to our design team by Tuesday
I will try to get it back by Thursday from the design team so you can review the final slides on Friday
 
Client notes on expectations for the training:
Hi Emani - Wanted to provide some general themes and expectations for this training: 
Distinction between Latine, Hispanic, and Brazilian identities
 (I'm hoping there will be some 
graphic
 representation to pair with this)
calling out 
US perspective
 in language 
addressing 
evolving terms
 (Latina/o, Latinx, Latine) 
Spotlight 
differences between Brazil and US
 
(include a nod to employment law differences, cultural context, and political relationships)
reasoning - Carta has a large Brazilian population, Carta's first international office (#3), 2nd or 3rd largest office
Unpacking stereotypes
 that might be made about these identity groups - this might be the space to hear from the culture native or where you point to the historical timeline that impacts those stereotypes
layer with 
data on why it matters 
or how it impacts workplace dynamics 
Tips/Strategies on interrupting bias 
against Latine, Hispanic and/or Brazilian identities in the workplace. Here are few examples of things that have come up
accents (underscoring the cognitive power that it takes to translate from native language to English)
asking too many questions (to bridge understanding between US and Brazilian culture)
microaggressions on time differences and seasons (reminding folks of time differences, opposite season from the northern hemisphere)
access to equitable resources (barriers traveling to the US, working on US holidays, etc) 
 
I look forward to connecting with you again once the content is finalized.
 
Hugs and kisses!
 
Emani Richmond

On Sep 29, 2023, at 16:03, Emani Richmond <e.richmond@lcwmail.com> wrote:
﻿
 
Dear Alisa & Chuck,
 
I am writing to inform you both of my decision to resign as a consultant with LCW, effective two weeks from this date.
 
The past two years and 5 months have been a rewarding and deeply immersive experience for me. I appreciate the opportunities I have been presented due to the consistent light and excellence I have brought into the organization. I deeply value the professional relationships I've been able to develop here and the ability to present my skills on multiple platforms. However, due to the severe emotional distress I have undergone through uncertainty with the 20% pay reduction, unclear guidance from leadership about the specifics around how the company will rebound from the economic uncertainty, and growing job dissatisfaction I needed to make the best choice for my health and well-being. I remain committed to the health and wellness of my past, and current LCW colleagues and if the opportunity arises for me to partner with LCW in the future I hope you all would not hesitate to reach out. 
 
Please let me know if there is any way I can assist with the transition as I have ongoing client work that is in various stages of delivery. I hope to keep in touch.
 
With compassion and gratitude,
 
Emani Richmond
(she/her/hers)

subject: 🧠 improve your memory in 10 minutes
body:
wrangle your digital subscriptions, quit over-planning, improve your memory in 10 min, and meet Simon, the OG “smartphone"
 
Issue #158 October 3, 2023 
Read in browser
 
          
TOGETHER WITH
 
    
Was this email forwarded to you by someone awesome?
You need your own — 
subscribe here for free
.
 
🎉 Happy Q4 everyone!
Start your morning with this affirmation:
 
 
Today’s checklist: 
Wrangle your digital subscriptions, keep your over-planning tendencies in check, improve your memory in 10 minutes, and meet Simon, the OG “smartphone.”
YOU DO YOU
Too many subscriptions? 
  
More and more people are feeling stuck paying for subscriptions they don’t really want. 
You suddenly remember your intentions to cancel while looking at your bank statement, lamenting paying another month of fees for a streaming service you haven’t accessed in months. You don’t have to feel stuck paying for subscriptions if you remember the acronym, S-T-U-C. 
S
Study your statements. 
Review all your bank and credit card statements carefully. A new or recurring charge may be the easiest way to learn...
That you have subscribed to something
That you’re still subscribed to something
That a company has changed the price of their subscription services 
T
Track how much you’re spending (to motivate yourself to save) 
Make a spreadsheet listing:
All the services you’re paying for 
How much you’re paying per month 
How much you’re paying per year
 
Continue reading
TOGETHER WITH FIGMA
Unlock Your Creative Potential with Mood Boards
  
 
Discover the transformative power of 
mood boards
, your secret weapon for inspiration, organization, and goal achievement.
Mood Boards for Your Professional Projects:
Marketing Campaigns:
 Craft visually stunning and cohesive marketing materials that resonate with your target audience.
Interior Design: 
Bring your vision for the perfect workspace or home to life.
Creative Projects:
 Kickstart your creative projects, whether you're an artist, writer, or designer, by visualizing your ideas in one place.
Team Collaboration:
 Foster collaboration and align your team's vision.
Mood Boards for Your Personal Growth:
Health & Fitness:
 Stay motivated on your fitness journey by creating a moodboard with your fitness goals, meal plans, and workout inspirations.
Travel Planning:
 Plan your dream vacation with a moodboard filled with destination images, activity ideas, and travel essentials.
Educational Goals: 
Stay focused on your learning goals by visualizing your academic journey.
Personal Goals: 
Turn your dreams into achievable goals by mapping them out.
Whether you're looking to level up your work projects or embarking on a personal growth journey, mood Boards are your guiding light.
 
Get started with this free mood board template
  
🔥 Pro-Tip:
 Use your 
business email
 to access hundreds of templates and invite collaborators for free!
GET MORE SH*T DONE
When good plans go bad  
It can be practical, soothing, and even pleasurable to make a perfect plan. But sometimes, the relationship between you and your plan can become a little warped. 
Let’s say your plan is perfect, but too complex. You don’t actually have time to do everything you planned to do. Or maybe your plan is too perfect. You start on the deliverables only to realize the reality will never live up to your perfect plan. Or maybe just making the plan is enough to kick off your procrastination reflex. You know exactly what you planned to do but you really don’t want to do it. 
A 
possible solution
: Spend only 10% of your time planning and 90% of your time doing the work. 
Why?
 
To avoid the productive procrastination trap known as overplanning. The rule also ensures you start executing a plan before you’ve spent too long on it. You’ll know sooner rather than later if your perfect plan is unrealistic, you know, before you get too attached to it.
TOGETHER WITH BONUSLY
Swipe This Stay Interview Template
  
 
It’s rare that you can change someone’s mind in an exit interview. 
A stay interview gives your employees a safe space to share how you can better support and develop them for the long haul
.
When you proactively identify strengths and weaknesses in your retention efforts and company culture, you can make improvements 
before
 employees leave.
The free 
Stay Interview Template
 includes:
 
👉 Directions for how to use the template.
✅ Guided questions around manager feedback, company feedback, and building connections.
💡 Tips on how to make the most of your stay interviews.
⚙️ Additional tools and resources to build resilient teams.
👉 
Get your free stay interview template
LEVEL UP
The memory game: dance edition
Again and again, 
research suggests
 the best way to exercise your memory is through general physical exercise. Even 10 vigorous minutes can do wonders for your memory retention. 
Here’s a fun way to make 10 minutes of vigorous exercise a day feel more like a memory workout: Do one 
dance
 a day. 
On day one, follow a dance tutorial video. (
Mandy Jiroux’s Youtube channel
 has plenty of short options.) 
Repeat the dance each day until you remember the steps without looking at the video. 
When you know you KNOW your first dance, start over with a new one.
IYDKNYK
Your smartphone has an older sibling 
In 1994, 13 years before the iPhone, IBM released a “personal communicator.” Its name was 
Simon
. 
The brick-like smartphone predecessor had a touchscreen, designed to be touched by a stylus, not a finger. It could check emails, send faxes, and even serve as an alarm clock. 
It hardly perfected the art of mobile personal communication, but it was one of the earliest players to prove people wanted to do more than just talk on the go.
Thanks, Simon. 
PARTNER PICKS

Take the insanity out of your inbox with

here's an icebreaker that can help with that
.

On Sep 29, 2023, at 16:03, Emani Richmond <e.richmond@lcwmail.com> wrote:
﻿
 
Dear Alisa & Chuck,
 
I am writing to inform you both of my decision to resign as a consultant with LCW, effective two weeks from this date.
 
The past two years and 5 months have been a rewarding and deeply immersive experience for me. I appreciate the opportunities I have been presented due to the consistent light and excellence I have brought into the organization. I deeply value the professional relationships I've been able to develop here and the ability to present my skills on multiple platforms. However, due to the severe emotional distress I have undergone through uncertainty with the 20% pay reduction, unclear guidance from leadership about the specifics around how the company will rebound from the economic uncertainty, and growing job dissatisfaction I needed to make the best choice for my health and well-being. I remain committed to the health and wellness of my past, and current LCW colleagues and if the opportunity arises for me to partner with LCW in the future I hope you all would not hesitate to reach out. 
 
Please let me know if there is any way I can assist with the transition as I have ongoing client work that is in various stages of delivery. I hope to keep in touch.
 
With compassion and gratitude,
 
Emani Richmond
(she/her/hers)
Consultant
LCW

Hi Ariadne,
 
Great to connect with you yesterday, and I’m looking forward to working with you. I’ve copied in Emani, the Consultant who is supporting me on this project.
 
You should be able to download the content here. If not, please let me know.
https://www.dropbox.com/scl/fi/xd01fex07dywe4qtdjmxh/SPOTLIGHT-Persons-w-Disabilities-Europe.pptx?rlkey=coqcy3mhx5ei9ibxq8bqlehfa&dl=0
 
A couple of things to keep in mind:
LCW decks and notes tend to be dense. I’ve removed some pages and notes already, and feel free to edit the speaker notes further during your prep. (This also means that the timings won’t line up exactly, as indicated in the notes)
TPOTS
 means “The Point of the Slide,” identifies the main narrative element to be emphasized if speaker notes are skipped over
I have tried to take out most of the US references in the notes, but I am certain I have missed certain elements
 
Things to look for in the review:
Imagery that seems out-of-place and/or very US-centric
Language that seems out-of-place and/or very US-centric
Fact and figures that refer only to the US
Opportunities (if any) to add Europe content
 
We will take your comments and make revisions. As I mentioned, this content was originally developed for a US audience by an interculturalist based in the US who identifies as neurodivergent. Please feel free to be as harsh as you feel is necessary with the content. 
 
Slides with regional facts (highlighted because there may be residual errors in the notes,etc.):
p. 2
 Updated
p. 5 
Updated
p. 6
 UN definition, updated (changed from ADA definition)
p. 11 
Disability history (in progress, partially updated)
 
Please let me know if you have any questions, and I will be in touch with the PA (the contract for the service) early next week.
 
 
Thank you, and have a great weekend!
 
Best,
Dan

subject: Re: Client Notes: Brazil Session (Oct 10th)
body:
Hello Lucy,
Thank you for sending these slides over. We try to have images on screen be easier for participants to read and digest, so I would encourage you to limit the text on screen only to what is most helpful for people to read during the session, and then have the rest of the text go into the speaker notes that you will read during the session.
Here is a link to the version of the Cultural program we put together for the client last year. Within these slides you will find the LCW definition of Culture, also key slides we share for steps people can take to become an ally to our focus group which are Brazilian colleagues at this time.
https://www.dropbox.com/scl/fi/flelphitqougu4vthnfw3/Carta_Understanding_Brazilian_Work_Culture-2023.pptx?rlkey=03fioaykxsp8h0verq2lxsiyn&dl=0

Shared with Dropbox
www.dropbox.com
Please let me know if you have any trouble accessing the link above. I will review the slides you sent me tomorrow afternoon but I think they should be sufficient to cover the general conversation the client wants to bring into their organization. 
Best,

 Thursday, September 28, 2023 12:55 PM
To:
 
ica@infolink.com.br
Subject:
 Client Notes: Brazil Session (Oct 10th)
 
Hi Lucy,
 
It was BEYOND a pleasure to meet you and connect over the course we will be delivering on October 10
th
. 
 
**Could you please send me your head shot you would like to use in the training?
 
Client: 
Carta
 (Link to website)
~1,200 employees, average session attendance 30-70 people
Audience: All staff
Major offices located in: NYC, Rio, San Diego
 
As mentioned on the call here’s our aggressive content timeline:
Lucy to create and send a presentation by Monday or sooner if possible
I will send the content to our design team by Tuesday
I will try to get it back by Thursday from the design team so you can review the final slides on Friday
 
Client notes on expectations for the training:
Hi Emani - Wanted to provide some general themes and expectations for this training: 
Distinction between Latine, Hispanic, and Brazilian identities
 (I'm hoping there will be some 
graphic
 representation to pair with this)
calling out 
US perspective
 in language 
addressing 
evolving terms
 (Latina/o, Latinx, Latine) 
Spotlight 
differences between Brazil and US
 
(include a nod to employment law differences, cultural context, and political relationships)
reasoning - Carta has a large Brazilian population, Carta's first international office (#3), 2nd or 3rd largest office
Unpacking stereotypes
 that might be made about these identity groups - this might be the space to hear from the culture native or where you point to the historical timeline that impacts those stereotypes
layer with 
data on why it matters 
or how it impacts workplace dynamics 
Tips/Strategies on interrupting bias 
against Latine, Hispanic and/or Brazilian identities in the workplace. Here are few examples of things that have come up
accents (underscoring the cognitive power that it takes to translate from native language to English)
asking too many questions (to bridge understanding between US and Brazilian culture)
microaggressions on time differences and seasons (reminding folks of time differences, opposite season from the northern hemisphere)
access to equitable resources (barriers traveling to the US, working on US holidays, etc) 
 
I look forward to connecting with you again once the content is finalized.
 
Hugs and kisses!
 
Emani Richmond
(she/her/hers)
Consultant
LCW

body:
Hi Consultants,
 
I hope you are well.
 
This is a reminder that we are still running our 25% discounted learning bundles through October for new AND EXISTING clients. We need your help in contacting the accounts you own and your contacts to get this message out.
 
As a reminder, the deal is as follows:
 Starting September 1 and going through October 31, we are offering a 25% discount on any new statement of work that includes our 
Talent Review Bundles
.
 The message accompanying this discount is about how we recognize that this is the time of year when Talent and Performance reviews take place, as well as when decisions are made for next year’s hiring budgets. 
 
Your ask:
 Please use the template message (attached) to communicate directly with your accounts and contacts to leverage the 25% discount as you see fit
.
 
Please, let me know if you need assistance AND once you have reached out to your clients.
 
Thank you,

Hi Lucy,
 
It was BEYOND a pleasure to meet you and connect over the course we will be delivering on October 10
th
. 
 
**Could you please send me your head shot you would like to use in the training?
 
Client: 
Carta
 (Link to website)
~1,200 employees, average session attendance 30-70 people
Audience: All staff
Major offices located in: NYC, Rio, San Diego
 
As mentioned on the call here’s our aggressive content timeline:
Lucy to create and send a presentation by Monday or sooner if possible
I will send the content to our design team by Tuesday
I will try to get it back by Thursday from the design team so you can review the final slides on Friday
 
Client notes on expectations for the training:
Hi Emani - Wanted to provide some general themes and expectations for this training: 
Distinction between Latine, Hispanic, and Brazilian identities
 (I'm hoping there will be some 
graphic
 representation to pair with this)
calling out 
US perspective
 in language 
addressing 
evolving terms
 (Latina/o, Latinx, Latine) 
Spotlight 
differences between Brazil and US
 
(include a nod to employment law differences, cultural context, and political relationships)
reasoning - Carta has a large Brazilian population, Carta's first international office (#3), 2nd or 3rd largest office
Unpacking stereotypes
 that might be made about these identity groups - this might be the space to hear from the culture native or where you point to the historical timeline that impacts those stereotypes
layer with 
data on why it matters 
or how it impacts workplace dynamics 
Tips/Strategies on interrupting bias 
against Latine, Hispanic and/or Brazilian identities in the workplace. Here are few examples of things that have come up
accents (underscoring the cognitive power that it takes to translate from native language to English)
asking too many questions (to bridge understanding between US and Brazilian culture)
microaggressions on time differences and seasons (reminding folks of time differences, opposite season from the northern hemisphere)
access to equitable resources (barriers traveling to the US, working on US holidays, etc) 
 
I look forward to connecting with you again once the content is finalized.
 
Hugs and kisses!
 
Emani Richmond

subject: Institute Insider
body:
October is jam-packed with opportunities to set perceptions about modern manufacturing careers and gain valuable workforce solutions on a grand scale by working with the Manufacturing Institute. From 
Women MAKE Award
 nominations, to our annual 
Workforce Summit,
 to celebrating 
MFG Day 
events nationwide there are many ways you and your organizations can engage. 
Scroll down for more information on opportunities below, regardless of where you are!
 
 
Program Updates
 
 
 
﻿
The Final Countdown: MFG Day 2023 – October 6
MFG Day 2023 is just days away and manufacturers across the country are geared up to inspire the next generation of creators with events happening throughout the month and beyond!
﻿Demonstrating the impact and scale of MFG Day requires an “all hands on deck” approach – everyone can play a part! 
Register
 today 
– if you are hosting an event, ensure it’s reflected in the national impact by putting it on the 
MFG Day map
. This is free and open to all event hosts and their partners. 
 
Use the resources
 – ready-to-use graphics, messages, manufacturing facts and more to help you easily get involved, show your support and spread the message.
 
Host toolkit
Marketing toolkit
12 Reasons to Consider a Career in Manufacturing
State Manufacturing Data
﻿Amplify, amplify, amplify!
 Help us takeover social media on MFG Day and throughout the month of October by using the hashtags
 
#mfgday23
 
and 
#creatorswanted
. 
 
Follow and tag
 MFG Day on 
Twitter
, 
Facebook
, 
Instagram
, and 
LinkedIn
. 
 
The Personal MFG Day Challenge
Share why you’re proud to work in or support
 #manufacturing
! Use one of the prompts below if you need help getting started. 
Be sure to include a relevant image, 
#MFGDay23
, and tag MFG Day and the Manufacturing Institute!
My favorite thing about working in mfg is… 
My inspiration for pursuing a career in mfg was… 
One thing I wish students, parents and educators knew about mfg is… 
A career field you may have never known that is important to mfg is… 
My training/education pathway into my career was… 
Thanks (insert teacher/mentor name)! You helped me excel professionally by… 
My work is important to mfg because… 
 
 
LAST CALL: 2024 Women MAKE Awards –
 
NOMINATION DEADLINE APPROACHING 
The end of the nomination period for the 2024 Women MAKE Awards is coming up on Friday, October 6. Don’t miss the opportunity to recognize women employees, colleagues and peers who exemplify leadership and mentorship in the manufacturing industry.
SUBMIT A NOMINATION TODAY
 
Be sure to check out the 
2024 Nominations Guide
 for more details on eligibility criteria, selection process, key dates, and best practices. Your company can 
click here
 to submit your nominations. Please email 
WomenMAKE@nam.org
 if you have additional questions.
Creators Wanted Twin Cities –
 
Sponsored by Union Pacific Railroad
 
 
Last month, Saint Paul College in St. Paul, Minnesota, which boasts a student body that is 65% people of color, became the 19th stop of 20 for the Creators Wanted Tour. Over three days, with 
Union Pacific
 as the lead sponsor, the stop drew more than 600 visitors, from students to educators. Meanwhile, 42,000 online signups in Minnesota helped the campaign surpass 
1.5 million nationwide
 from students and career mentors interested in modern manufacturing careers.
  
Union Pacific Executive Vice President of Marketing and Sales Kenny Rocker gave the keynote address at the 
kickoff event
, emphasizing the reward of manufacturing careers. He was joined by MI President and Executive Director Carolyn Lee, Saint Paul College President Dr. Dee Dee Peaslee, Minnesota Chamber of Commerce President and CEO Doug Loon, and Trane Technologies Vice President of Product Management Dave Molin.
 
 
The Twin Cities event is a part of Union Pacific’s overarching 
“Careers on Track”
 initiative, which aims to inspire more women and youth to pursue modern industrial careers.
 
NEXT UP - 
The pioneering Creators Wanted Tour concludes this month on Oct. 17–21 at the 
Circleville Pumpkin Show
 in Circleville, Ohio.
The Role of Culture and Employee Engagement  
Want to know what kind of company culture has the greatest impact on attracting and retaining talent? Check out the Center for Manufacturing Research’s 
newest report on company culture
 to learn how to define your company culture and engage your employees, conducted in partnership with Colonial Life.  
KEY TAKEAWAYS: 
A community culture, or “family-friendly” environment, matters to manufacturing employees.  
Manufacturing leaders can communicate their company culture through core values and benefits/policies that acknowledge the importance of personal priorities in employees’ lives (flexibility, family leave, child care support, etc.) while meeting production needs. 
Building social bonds between employees is critical with 97% of manufacturing employees staying at their companies because of their managers and co-workers.  
Employee engagement is how you can transmit your culture and generate employee buy-in. Effective methods employee engagement surveys, increased flexibility, additional training and professional development opportunities, expanded benefits and community involvement.  
SURVEY: Connecting Manufacturers to Military-Affiliated Talent 
Have thoughts about how manufacturers can better connect with military-affiliated talent? If you’re a manufacturing leader, let us know your thoughts by filling out 
this quick survey
 by 
Tuesday, Oct. 3, at 5:00 pm EST.
 If you are a Heroes MAKE America alumni, we’re also interested in 
hearing your experiences
 as you transitioned into a career in manufacturing.  
The Greatest Workforce Newsletter Ever 
Looking for a quick-hit digest that gets you the labor market data you need to make hiring decisions? Interested in discovering innovative workforce solutions and keeping up to date with the latest in the sector? Sign up for 
Workforce in Focus
, our super informative and super fun, monthly newsletter. Become a workforce leader in the know! 
 
Events & Webinars
 
 
2023 Workforce Summit 
–
 Sourcing Solutions: People, Processes & Skills 
OCT. 16 – 18
 - Struggling to attract new and talented workers? There is still opportunity to secure some of the remaining spots to attend the MI's highly anticipated annual 
Workforce Summit
 in 
Atlanta, GA
. At the Summit you and your team can access actionable information to help you strengthen your workforce strategies. Hear from a diversity of experts across industry, academia and prospective partners with innovative and proven solutions about how you can attract skilled manufacturing talent. Whether you are facing challenges attracting, training or retaining talent, the MI will connect you with the solutions to ensure the readiness of the manufacturing workforce. 
Register
 today to secure your spot! Questions? Email 
workforce@nam.org
 to learn more. 
Creating Chemistry: Inspiring NextGen Creators through Community Partnerships – Presented by BASF
OCT. 6 
– The MI is joining forces with 
MFG Day Platinum Event Sponsor BASF
 and River Parishes Community College to host the MFG Day 2023 flagship event in Gonzales, LA. 
Throughout MFG Day, over 500 middle and high school students from Ascencion Public Schools will be on the RPCC campus, getting hands-on with activities hosted by a number of local manufacturers to help them learn about modern manufacturing and the diverse, in-demand careers that exist right in their backyard. They’ll also tour RPCC’s state-of-the-art technical facilities and learn first-hand about the training and education programs created in partnership with local industry leaders where they can prepare for their future career in industry. 
Concurrently, leaders from the MI, BASF, RPCC, APS, and the State of Louisiana will share with other industry and community leaders the importance of strong community partnerships in inspiring future creators and building sustainable talent pipelines that further individual opportunity, community prosperity and a more competitive manufacturing industry. 
Learn more and register to attend 
here
. 
How Firms Would Invest a Marginal Dollar with Their Company 
OCT. 11 
– Curious how manufacturers determine where to invest their marginal dollars? We’ve got the answers. Tune in on 
Wednesday, Oct. 11, from 1-2 pm ET 
for the Center for Manufacturing Research’s 
insights webinar
 where we’ll be sharing key takeaways from our forthcoming report, 
How Firms Would Invest a Marginal Dollar with Their Company.
 Panelists include: 
Nishanth Vallabhu
, Industrial and Process Manufacturing Industry, Cognizant 
 
Daniel Kennel
, Director, Corporate Strategy & Venture, BorgWarner 
 
Elisabeth Smith
, President and CEO, Acutec Precision Aerospace 
 
Register here
 to attend.
 
Workforce Resources
DIVERSITY AND INCLUSION: September Roundtable
On Thursday, September 14, the MI held a roundtable on 
Integrating Refugees into Your Workforce: Processes, Policies, People and Programs 
featuring 
Tent
 and 
HIAS
. The discussion highlighted how resettlement agencies can work with companies as an implementing partner. Attendees heard how Tent and other non-governmental organizations can help companies effectively recruit and integrate refugees into their workforces. The roundtable featured resources to get involved from Tent and HIAS, along with best practices and ways to work through different challenges. You can view the recording 
here
 and find all our Diversity and Inclusion resources 
here
. 
RECAP: Engaging After MFG Day – High School Internships
The MI recently conducted a webinar to introduce the new 
High School Internship Toolkit for Manufacturers
, a guide to help manufacturers of all sizes develop their own high school internship program. The MI was joined by Toyota employees with extensive insights and experience implementing the program at Toyota Motor Manufacturing Texas, where the toolkit was developed. 
According to Maurice Salazar, Human Resources Development Skilled Group Leader at Toyota Motor Manufacturing Texas “we’ve put over 138 students through our high school internship program in the last 13 years…we’ve been able to hire on from our high school program into our current workforce over 58 skilled technicians. About 28% of our skilled workforce has come from our high school program.”  
Brandon Gabriel, HRD Skilled Team Leader and Maintenance Fundamental Skills Trainer at Toyota Motor Manufacturing Texas shared his personal story as a high school intern with a different company, losing his way after graduating, and a random run-in with his old high school counselor who connected him with Toyota’s AMT program. Referencing his high school internship, Brandon said “It was a phenomenal chance, a phenomenal opportunity to gain exposure to what the manufacturing world is.” Ten years later, he now trains skilled team members across the entire plant, including the high school interns. 
You can view the webinar recording 
here
. 
RECAP: Veteran Learning Series
On Tuesday, September 26th, the Heroes MAKE America program hosted a compelling employer learning session featuring John Buckley, Outreach Strategies Manager at Koch Industries. The event shed light on the undeniable value of hiring from the military community, emphasizing that it's not just a noble endeavor but also excellent business sense.  
The session highlighted key attributes that military personnel bring to the workforce, including leadership, managerial skills, agility in learning, and adaptability - qualities that translate into enhanced productivity and higher employee retention rates. 
Some of the pivotal takeaways from the event included: 
Understanding and Navigating the Culture and Communication Gap
: Bridging the gap between military culture and the civilian workplace, ensuring effective communication and integration. 
 
Cultivating a Veteran "Perimeter" with Key Resources:
 Encouraging employers to establish a robust support network for veterans, including mentorship programs and employee resource groups, fostering a sense of belonging and empowerment. 
 
Leveraging Existing Veteran Employees: 
Emphasizing the importance of utilizing current veteran employees as valuable resources. This includes tapping into their networks for referrals, reviewing job descriptions to ensure inclusivity, involving them in interview processes, and developing comprehensive onboarding strategies. 
 
Integrating Degree Equivalency Programs: 
Recognizing that military personnel often possess valuable skills and experience in lieu of traditional education. 
 
The event was recorded and can be viewed 
here
. Please reach out to 
heroes@nam.org
 if you’re interested in learning about how to get involved with the Heroes MAKE America program. 
 
The Manufacturing Institute builds, diversifies, and strengthens the manufacturing workforce for individual opportunity, community prosperity, and a competitive manufacturing industry for the future.
To learn more about the MI’s programs and ways you can support and participate, please contact 
Rachael Scheffler
, AVP of Partnerships and Development.
Visit our website
 
 
The Manufacturing Institute | 202-637-3426 |
 institute@nam.org
 | 
www.themanufacturinginstitute.org
The Manufacturing Institute
 | 
733 10th Street NW
, 
Suite 700
, 
Washington, DC 20001

On Sep 29, 2023, at 16:03, Emani Richmond <e.richmond@lcwmail.com> wrote:
﻿
 
Dear Alisa & Chuck,
 
I am writing to inform you both of my decision to resign as a consultant with LCW, effective two weeks from this date.
 
The past two years and 5 months have been a rewarding and deeply immersive experience for me. I appreciate the opportunities I have been presented due to the consistent light and excellence I have brought into the organization. I deeply value the professional relationships I've been able to develop here and the ability to present my skills on multiple platforms. However, due to the severe emotional distress I have undergone through uncertainty with the 20% pay reduction, unclear guidance from leadership about the specifics around how the company will rebound from the economic uncertainty, and growing job dissatisfaction I needed to make the best choice for my health and well-being. I remain committed to the health and wellness of my past, and current LCW colleagues and if the opportunity arises for me to partner with LCW in the future I hope you all would not hesitate to reach out. 
 
Please let me know if there is any way I can assist with the transition as I have ongoing client work that is in various stages of delivery. I hope to keep in touch.
 
With compassion and gratitude,
 
Emani Richmond

Please note that we practice work flexibility at Richemont with teams working across the globe in multiple time zones. I have sent this message at a time that is convenient for me and hope that you will read, respond to, or action this information during your own preferred working hours.  
 
From:
 Emani Richmond <e.richmond@lcwmail.com> 
Sent:
 Friday, September 22, 2023 2:47 PM
To:
 PETERS Rashida (RIC-US) <rashida.peters@richemont.com>
Cc:
 Tamara Thorpe <t.thorpe@lcwmail.com>; LAIR Gaelle (RIC-US) <gaelle.lair@richemont.com>; BONARI Jessica (RIC-US) <jessica.bonari@richemont.com>
Subject:
 [EXT] Latin American Spotlight: Content Walk through follow-up
 
Hi Rashida,
 
Thank you for the discussion on the content for the Spotlight on Latin community today
 
See below for the video links and polls included in the training:
 
Video Links:
https://www.nbcnews.com/nightly-news/video/the-new-Latino-landscape-new-hampshire-s-population-boom-120968773794
Clip from TED Talk from Daisy Auger-Dominguez
SOURCE: 
https://youtu.be/u-VMr51yiVc
 
Poll 1
: 
How much do you know about Latinx? (choose one answer per question) 
(multi-question poll, single answer)
 
People whose cultural background or heritage is Latin American prefer to identify as: Latino/a  / (b) Hispanic / (c) Latinx / (d) Chicano / (e ) Their country of origin (e.g., Dominican-American or Guatemalan) / 
(f) Any of the above
 
Hispanics are projected to account for x% of net new workers between 2020 and 2030. 
10%
55%
78%
100%
 
True
/False 80% of new U.S. businesses over the last decade were created by Hispanics.
 
What percent of the U.S. population identifies as Latino/Hispanic?
1.1% 
6.0% 
10.2% 
12.4% 
18.7% 
 
True/
False
: In the past ten years, the state with the fastest growth rate of Latino residents was California.
 
Poll 2: 
Prioritizing Latinx Challenges (single answer)
What do you see or experience most frequently within your team or organization? (choose one)
Perceived as underperforming.
Judged more rigorously than their white peers.
Perceived as lacking confidence, competence, or presence due to lack of “assertiveness.”
Perceived as lacking initiative or ambition.
Perceived as having lower communication skills.
See few Latinx represented in leadership.
Poll 3
: Call to Action (multiple answer)
In this poll, choose ALL the actions you can take to be an even more inclusive leader or colleague in teams that include Hispanic/Latin colleagues:
Appreciate the diversity within the community. Remember that Latinx colleagues have different national, linguistic, and cultural backgrounds. 
Resist immediately under-evaluating your Latinx team members when they exhibit a work or communication approach that you're not used to.
Explicitly and regularly discuss the “unwritten rules” of success at your organization with everyone. Don't assume people know or "should know." 
 Advocate for cultural diversity with regard to voices, skills, and approaches. Help ensure your Latinx colleagues aren’t asked to do all the stretching. 
 Continue to educate yourself actively on the experiences of the Latinx community.
 
We will need to work in slide 12 (of the images of the famous leaders from the community) into the post session handout and will need 1-2 business days to make that addition. 
 
We have released the November dates for the BCI, and will await final word from you folks about dates to hold for December.
 
Best,
 
Emani Richmond

Hi Ariadne,
 
Great to connect with you yesterday, and I’m looking forward to working with you. I’ve copied in Emani, the Consultant who is supporting me on this project.
 
You should be able to download the content here. If not, please let me know.
https://www.dropbox.com/scl/fi/xd01fex07dywe4qtdjmxh/SPOTLIGHT-Persons-w-Disabilities-Europe.pptx?rlkey=coqcy3mhx5ei9ibxq8bqlehfa&dl=0
 
A couple of things to keep in mind:
LCW decks and notes tend to be dense. I’ve removed some pages and notes already, and feel free to edit the speaker notes further during your prep. (This also means that the timings won’t line up exactly, as indicated in the notes)
TPOTS
 means “The Point of the Slide,” identifies the main narrative element to be emphasized if speaker notes are skipped over
I have tried to take out most of the US references in the notes, but I am certain I have missed certain elements
 
Things to look for in the review:
Imagery that seems out-of-place and/or very US-centric
Language that seems out-of-place and/or very US-centric
Fact and figures that refer only to the US
Opportunities (if any) to add Europe content
 
We will take your comments and make revisions. As I mentioned, this content was originally developed for a US audience by an interculturalist based in the US who identifies as neurodivergent. Please feel free to be as harsh as you feel is necessary with the content. 
 
Slides with regional facts (highlighted because there may be residual errors in the notes,etc.):
p. 2
 Updated
p. 5 
Updated
p. 6
 UN definition, updated (changed from ADA definition)
p. 11 
Disability history (in progress, partially updated)
 
Please let me know if you have any questions, and I will be in touch with the PA (the contract for the service) early next week.
 
 
Thank you, and have a great weekend!
 
Best,
Dan

An Update From Sharon - October 2023
Lots has happened in a busy month
Sharon Hurley Hall
Oct 2
∙
Preview
 
READ IN APP
 
Hello friends, 
What a month it’s been! Here’s an update on all the current projects. Be warned: it’s a long read!
The Audiobook
I started the month by recording the audio for the audiobook of 
I’m Tired of Racism
. At the time of writing, I’d just received the files from the sound engineer, so I’ll be checking those so all edits can be finalised. 
I’ve also been in touch with the person I hope will do the audiobook cover, and I’ve started setting up my ACX account. That means everything’s on track for a release sometime in November. 
That will officially end the production phase for this book, which will be quite something after working on it in various guises for a solid three years.
Barbados Book Launch
Kathie Daniel of 
Southpaw Grafix 
in Barbados is helping me plan the local launch of my book on October 28th. As always, I’m doing it on a shoestring, which probably means an intimate audience of no more than 70 people - good numbers for a local launch, I’m told. 
With just under a month to go at the time of writing, it’s all systems go, and making hard decisions about what’s essential and what’s simply nice to have. By the time I write the next letter, it will be over, and I’ll be able to update you on how it went. 
The Milwaukee Trip
Lea and I went to Milwaukee to attend YWCA SEW’s Circle of Women event. It was an interesting experience, with much to think about regarding what putting equality into practice really looks like. ...

Hi Lucy,
