th
. 
 
**Could you please send me your head shot you would like to use in the training?
 
Client: 
Carta
 (Link to website)
~1,200 employees, average session attendance 30-70 people
Audience: All staff
Major offices located in: NYC, Rio, San Diego
 
As mentioned on the call here’s our aggressive content timeline:
Lucy to create and send a presentation by Monday or sooner if possible
I will send the content to our design team by Tuesday
I will try to get it back by Thursday from the design team so you can review the final slides on Friday
 
Client notes on expectations for the training:
Hi Emani - Wanted to provide some general themes and expectations for this training: 
Distinction between Latine, Hispanic, and Brazilian identities
 (I'm hoping there will be some 
graphic
 representation to pair with this)
calling out 
US perspective
 in language 
addressing 
evolving terms
 (Latina/o, Latinx, Latine) 
Spotlight 
differences between Brazil and US
 
(include a nod to employment law differences, cultural context, and political relationships)
reasoning - Carta has a large Brazilian population, Carta's first international office (#3), 2nd or 3rd largest office
Unpacking stereotypes
 that might be made about these identity groups - this might be the space to hear from the culture native or where you point to the historical timeline that impacts those stereotypes
layer with 
data on why it matters 
or how it impacts workplace dynamics 
Tips/Strategies on interrupting bias 
against Latine, Hispanic and/or Brazilian identities in the workplace. Here are few examples of things that have come up
accents (underscoring the cognitive power that it takes to translate from native language to English)
asking too many questions (to bridge understanding between US and Brazilian culture)
microaggressions on time differences and seasons (reminding folks of time differences, opposite season from the northern hemisphere)
access to equitable resources (barriers traveling to the US, working on US holidays, etc) 
 
I look forward to connecting with you again once the content is finalized.
 
Hugs and kisses!
 
Emani Richmond

subject: RE: Client Notes: Brazil Session (Oct 10th)
body:
Hello Emani
 
I´m working in our presentation and will send it to you in the afternoon.
 
The scope of what you have sent me, describing their interests, is a lot larger than our 60 minutes can accommodate. I usually don´t have slides uncovered at my presentations, as my experience showed me that it leaves a feeling that the presentation was unprepared and finished missing subjects. Nevertheless, it should be your call, if you want me to have a longer material, it´s OK for me.
 
One of the subjects they pointed is the difference between the work laws in Brazil and the US. This isn´t material for a Diversity training (maybe HR?) and I have no familiarity with the subject, as I don´t know the laws in the US. I´ll mention some things like the “worker´s rights” in Brazil, but won´t write about it, OK? 
 
I´m eager for your feedback on the “tone” I´m using, so I´m sending you the first five slides, OK?
 
Thank you for your help!
 
Hugs and kisses
Lucy
PS. My friend called my attention that `hugs and kisses” is used for friends, but at the offices we say, mainly at emails, just hugs – abraços.

subject: Suffering from social exhaustion?
body:
Four tips to beat it and get back to feeling like you.
View this email in your browser.
 
Presented by CVS Health
Signs you’re suffering from social exhaustion—and 4 tips to beat it
October 1, 2023
 
After more than two years of soft pants, Zoom meetings, and virtual one-on-ones, returning to the office half- or full-time may be somewhat of a shock to the system. If you’re feeling cranky, exhausted, and in need of some alone time, you may be experiencing social exhaustion, according to psychologists. 
What is social exhaustion?
It generally refers to feeling run-down and overstimulated after spending time with others. There are a few signs that may indicate you’re falling prey to social burnout: You may feel irritable, impatient, or notice that you no longer find joy in social outings like you used to, says Camille Tenerife, a Los Angeles–based therapist. 
While social exhaustion may be the product of work—navigating coffee-pot conversations, a calendar stacked with meetings, and office happy hours—it can create ripples in all areas of your life. So as you’re getting back into the swing of your morning commute, cubicle chats, and IRL meetings, make sure you have a few therapist-approved tips to prevent those in-office days from draining your social battery.
1. Set realistic social expectations for yourself 
 
Give yourself permission to let one or more things go. Maybe you hire a babysitter to pick up your child from school, skip happy hour with your friends, or put those French lessons on hold for now.
2. Carve out time on your calendar to unwind
 
“Just as much as you block out the meetings and the one-on-ones, also block out time to decompress in your calendar if work allows you to,” says Tenerife . Use that time to take a walk, meditate, or drink a coffee. 
3. Recognize social exhaustion at work—and do one small self-care ritual
 
Let’s set the scene: It’s the middle of the workday, and you just wrapped up your fifth meeting. You’re feeling agitated, overwhelmed, and in need of some “me time.” Take a micro-break, even if it’s to splash some water on your face in the bathroom.
4. Communicate with your loved ones that you’re setting social boundaries 
 
Looking after yourself may mean pulling back from some of your relationships. To ensure no feelings are hurt along the way, therapist Cynthia Fox recommends clearly communicating your social needs to the people around you. “Say, I might not be as available as I normally am, and I ask that you have as much patience as you can with me.” 
Read the full article 
here
.
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 CONTENT FROM CVS HEALTH 
 
A Reboot for Preventive Care
 
Learn more about the historical context and current shortfalls in preventive care and take a deep dive into two promising solutions: Retail health care as an enabler of primary care services and a widening scope for pharmacists as access points for testing, vaccines and even treatment.

subject: 😏 back, back, back it up
body:
get fall cozy, save your memories, win at networking, find your next fave podcast, and make the tough decision — cider or coffee (maybe it's both!)

TOGETHER WITH BONUSLY
The Problem We're All Ignoring
  
 
Gallup’s 2023 State of the Workplace Report found that 
globally, over half of employees are considering leaving their job, and most are disengaged
.
The term "employee engagement" has become a buzzword in corporate circles, yet its true significance is often underestimated or misunderstood.
In this 
free guide
, you'll learn:
 
Why employee engagement is so hard to solve for
5 core solutions you can implement on your teams to improve engagement
The ROI of employee engagement
Address the the challenge of employee disengagement and discover solutions that can transform your company into a into winning workplace.
  
📙 
Get the free guide
FROM ANNIE CRONER, EA COACH, CEO & FOUNDER OF WHOLE ASSISTANT
How to Win at Networking
I recently went to Dallas to speak to a room of executive assistants and administrative professionals at a corporate event. I marveled at the collective knowledge in the room and basked in the encouragement and idea sharing that comes when we get out of our silos long enough to engage with other assistants who “get it”.
This got me thinking about how many times I’ve relied on (and helped) those in my network. My network has helped me find key players in my executive’s world, office space, trusted vendors and that one-of-a-kind gift that was nowhere to be found.
If you want to start expanding your network, and therefore your resources, here are some things to consider…
Start with what you're doing right.
Before delving into strategies, it's important to recognize the network you’ve already built. Think about the doorman or security personnel you encounter regularly, the cleaning crew you greet in your office building, and the vendors you interact with. These relationships are the building blocks of a robust network. Being present, acknowledging others, and building mutual respect lay the foundation for meaningful connections.
 
Continue reading

What Else To Read

What makes The Daily Upside second to none?

Their team of scholars, journalists, and investment bankers (with actual industry experience)

The best part?

PETS OF THE WEEK
 
Lucky
  
A mature lady, Lucky is a 16 year old rescue who knows exactly what she wants out of her "retirement": naps in the sun, naps on laps, chicken-based food, and naps by the radiator.
She's very vocal (probably due to hearing issues) and will absolutely let you know when she needs something or wants to say hi.
The queen of grumpy face, she has the standard tortie sass.

From:
 Emani Richmond <e.richmond@lcwmail.com> 
Sent:
 Friday, September 29, 2023 4:04 PM
To:
 Chuck Adams <c.adams@lcwmail.com>; Alisa Kolodizner <a.kolodizner@lcwmail.com>
Cc:
 Sarah Nodarse <s.nodarse@lcwmail.com>
Subject:
 Notice of Resignation 
 
Dear Alisa & Chuck,
 
I am writing to inform you both of my decision to resign as a consultant with LCW, effective two weeks from this date.
 
The past two years and 5 months have been a rewarding and deeply immersive experience for me. I appreciate the opportunities I have been presented due to the consistent light and excellence I have brought into the organization. I deeply value the professional relationships I've been able to develop here and the ability to present my skills on multiple platforms. However, due to the severe emotional distress I have undergone through uncertainty with the 20% pay reduction, unclear guidance from leadership about the specifics around how the company will rebound from the economic uncertainty, and growing job dissatisfaction I needed to make the best choice for my health and well-being. I remain committed to the health and wellness of my past, and current LCW colleagues and if the opportunity arises for me to partner with LCW in the future I hope you all would not hesitate to reach out. 
 
Please let me know if there is any way I can assist with the transition as I have ongoing client work that is in various stages of delivery. I hope to keep in touch.
 
With compassion and gratitude,
 
Emani Richmond
(she/her/hers)
Consultant
LCW

subject: LCW DEI Programming : Follow-up
body:
Hi Ann,
 
It was a pleasure to connect with you today as promised see the attached and below:
Attached is the Post IDI Debrief toolkit we discussed for staff to use to be guided though IDI next steps
Please feel free to review the attached and let me know if you have any requested changes to better adapt the document to fit CHL needs
Managing with Intercultural Competence eLearning
https://360.articulate.com/review/content/adfa8891-6408-422b-8ba6-ff24cc66d871/review
 
Since our DEI programming is shaping up to look a little different I want to ensure we are both on the same page about what our upcoming actions will be. We discussed the following:
Providing CHL with the link to the eLearning Introduction to Managing Unconscious Bias (IMUB) as a refresher on topics from last year covered
Providing the subsequent IMUB toolkit to facilitate a leader-led discussion for delivery in either Dec or Jan to keep the momentum going before the facilitated training
Offering the facilitated training: Understanding Microaggressions in ~Feb
Providing staff with the eLearning Managing with Intercultural Competence (MIC)
Lastly, offering IDI debriefs as needed for newly onboarded staff 
Billed on a per person basis as this is not reflected in our current statement of work
 
Next Steps:
By Friday of next week I will send you a November – April timeline to plan out when each activity will occur
You will also receive the finalized eLearning link to MIC by the end of next week
Ann, please send over any requested edits to the ‘Post IDI debrief’ document within the next 2 weeks
Lastly, could you please send me a window of time in February – March for us to host the facilitated 2 hour training session on Microaggressions so I can begin scheduling?
 
Thank you for the partnership!
 
Emani Richmond
(she/her/hers)
Consultant
LCW

subject: Do you have a worker shortage? Workforce Summit Oct. 16-18
body:
Struggling to attract and retain talent at your company?
If you are struggling to attract and retain talent at your company, you may want to look at this.
Workforce Summit
 
Oct. 16-18, 2023
Atlanta, GA 
REGISTER
Find innovative workforce solutions for skills, people and processes at the Manufacturing Institute 
Workforce Summit
 on 
Oct 16-18
 in 
Atlanta, GA
. 
SKILL. PEOPLE. PROCESSES 
The annual MI Workforce Summit
 connects employers, training providers and community partners with innovative solutions to address the workforce challenges of today and prepare for the opportunities of tomorrow. With sessions focused on 
expanding talent pools, using AI to upskill workers, meeting the training needs of employers, workplace flexibility, developing early career pathways
 and more, our program features innovative solutions manufacturers can bring back to their company to implement immediately. 
Participate in dynamic discussions with industry thought leaders as we explore innovative strategies for attracting, retaining and upskilling talent. 
Featured Speakers:
Natasha Pollock
, CHRO, Timken 
Bill Good
, VP Supply Chain, GE Appliances 
Major General Kris Belanger
, Commanding General of the 99th Readiness Division, U.S. Army Reserve 
Leslie Cantu
, Vice President of Administration, Toyotetsu Texas 
Eric Drake
, Technical Trainer Leadership Development, Electrolux 
Brian Cooksey
, Director Workforce Development, Shaw Industries 
… and more.
View the full agenda 
here
.
We hope to see you in Atlanta! 
The Manufacturing Institute 
Questions or Comments? 
Email the Manufacturing Institute team at 
workforce@nam.org
 for event inquiries.

th

From:
 Ann Odens <
ann@childrensheartlink.org
> 
Sent:
 Monday, September 25, 2023 12:37 PM
To:
 Emani Richmond <
e.richmond@lcwmail.com
>
Subject:
 RE: Discounted Talent Review Bundles
 
Hi Emani,
I’m also very excited for the conversations and work for our team in the coming months.
Our October all-staff meeting is next Tuesday, 10/3, 9:00-10:00am. If this is too soon, we have another monthly all-staff informal virtual gathering we call “coffee & connect” on Tuesday, 10/17, 9:00-9:30am. This pattern continues all year, 60 minute all-staff first Tuesday/month and 30 minute coffee & connect on the third Tuesday/month. The coffee & connects usually don’t have an agenda/topic, but occasionally there is a topic and I let staff know in this case so they are sure to hop on Teams.
I’m open to pushing back roll-out to late October or late November with content starting at the following all-staff if that works better to have plans in place rather than rush.
I added a few thoughts and questions in red below on planned toolkit structure. Let me know what you think is best on timing and happy to meet anytime to continue planning.
Thank you!
Ann
 
From:
 Emani Richmond <
e.richmond@lcwmail.com
> 
Sent:
 Thursday, September 21, 2023 5:50 PM
To:
 Ann Odens <
ann@childrensheartlink.org
>
Subject:
 RE: Discounted Talent Review Bundles
 
Hey Ann,
I’m really excited for the program we are bringing together for CHL. The opportunities I presented would be in addition to the scope of work we have already began for the fall on through next year. What is the date of the October All-Staff?
During the course roll out in October would be an opportunity to remind staff of the cultural/ DEI program you folks completed last year. Also this can get them thinking about what they hope to receive from this year’s engagement in preparation for the toolkit introduction session. 
Here are the 6 topic areas that the Intercultural Toolkit will address:
Introduction and how to use the toolkit
Intercultural Goal setting: What do you hope to gain and leverage during this journey?
Looking Back: Reflecting on cultural experiences to increase self-awareness
Values & Behaviors: How do they show up in my cultures and how might they show up in other cultures?
Leveraging Diversity: Pick 1-2 people on your team that you don’t know well and commit to understanding how they want to be treated. 
Cultural Literacy: Using Dimensions of Difference select 1-3 cultures to research and identify the behaviors you may see based on their designation. 
Let me think about how we will roll this out to the team specifically when they will get access to which course elements. 
 
Also, just so we are aligned on the contents of the current statement of work, CHL has currently purchased 20 seats for one of our eLearning courses titled: Managing with Intercultural Competence. My goal was to make this course available to CHL at the beginning of the engagement so staff could receive a refresher of key DEI, culture terminology, also to practice the DIN Model using the case study featured. Luckily LCW has recently went through a rebrand so you folks will be receiving a newly updated course. 
Let me think about how we will roll this out to the team and I can get back to you on specifics regarding when staff will complete each component, similar to a roadmap. 
 
Currently, the toolkit is outlined and includes the following structure:
Topic area with a supporting reading-
Step 1
Pre-work for the meeting: 
1 week prior to all-staff meeting (?), email to staff with topic, supporting reading and pre-work.
 
Team questions-
Step 2
For discussion during the monthly meeting: 
At all-staff meeting at start of month have small group discussions with guided questions, 15 minutes (?). Do we include debrief at this time or tell staff that more discussion will take place at each of their department meetings? Departments meet throughout that month can continue discussions, will you provide guided questions for department discussions during the month?
Space for reflection-
Step 3
To collect data throughout the process: 
What does data collection look like? How do we “close-out” topic for the month? Is there a way to collect individual feedback without meeting again and then provide topic wrap up? Would we do a monthly email 1 week prior to all-staff with current topic closing thoughts and return to step 1 of sharing next month topic/reading material/pre-work? Of course, no topic is ever done or closed, but to continue through monthly topics and steps, wondering how to somewhat end topic and move to next.
I will schedule some time for us to connect next week so you can receive a visual to communicate the timeline to staff, also to chart out our next steps with the roll out. 
I hope you are well, and we look forward to continuing our partnership with CHL.
 
Thank you,
Emani Richmond
(she/her/hers)
Consultant
LCW

From:
 Ann Odens <
ann@childrensheartlink.org
> 
Sent:
 Wednesday, September 20, 2023 2:54 PM
To:
 Emani Richmond <
e.richmond@lcwmail.com
>
Subject:
 RE: Discounted Talent Review Bundles
 
Hi Emani,
Thank you for sharing these opportunities. Are these part of the contract for Children’s HeartLink or would one of these options be added to our plan?
I know it’s been a while since we connected on next steps for our team and wondering if we could meet to touch base. I think we talked about kicking off trainings for the year at our October all-staff meeting, which is creeping right up!
My understanding of plans:
Kick-off at October staff meeting explaining goals, plans, timeline. Is there information and an image or video I can share with staff when sharing plans for the next 6 months?
Implement Leadership Toolkit with new topic monthly:
Part 1: LCW facilitated walk-through (How long? When? Beginning of November?) 
Part 2: Monthly CHL guided discussions at monthly team meetings. Topics and discussion questions provided by LCW. Should we introduce new topic at monthly staff meetings and have initial discussions at that time?
Intercultural Competence Toolkit:
Part 1: Monthly eLearning done individually by CHL staff. How long is each eLearning? Will we pre-select eLearning sessions for staff do each month to tie-in to monthly discussion topic? How do staff access the learning platform?
LCW consulting hours that allow CHL team to check-in with LCW quarterly to see what cultural competence questions surface. Is this check-in structured time with me and Jackie or more of open session for all staff to ask questions of an LCW consultant?
Where do we tie-in a review of their own IDI results and inform staff that this next set of training aligns with IDI work done last year?
Clearly I have many questions and not sure if my understanding of the overall process is correct. Happy to talk with you any time to keep the training moving forward.
Thank you,
Ann
Ann Odens
Director of Operations and HR
Children’s HeartLink
952.237.5510
www.childrensheartlink.org
 
 
 
 
 
From:
 Emani Richmond <
e.richmond@lcwmail.com
> 
Sent:
 Thursday, September 7, 2023 9:10 AM
To:
 Ann Odens <
ann@childrensheartlink.org
>
Subject:
 Discounted Talent Review Bundles
 
Hi Ann,
 
I hope you’re feeling alive and well. As the energy of summer simmers down and everyone’s project timelines increase I want you to know that LCW is here to assist with any of your L&D DEI + Culture needs!
 
I’m reaching out to share a special promotion LCW is running with performance evaluation season in mind. Through October, we’d like to offer you 
discounted learning bundles
 of our most popular programs – 
25%-off
 to help you close out the year with an active stance in equity. These bundles are designed to equip people managers with tools that enable sustainable high performance on diverse and multicultural teams.
 
You can view detailed course descriptions on 
our website
, but here’s a quick summary of the bundles that can help you debias the performance management process:
 
Just in Time Bundle: 
1-hour Zoom facilitation, 1 eLearning, 1 microLearning
Tools for Sustained Impact Bundle:
 2-hour Zoom facilitation, 1 eLearning, 1 microLearning, 1 Leader-Led Toolkit
 
Talent Management Bundle:
 4-hour Zoom facilitation, 2 eLearnings, 1 microLearning, 1 Leader-Led Toolkit
 
If you have any budget left to use this year, bringing one of these learning bundles to your organization could be a great opportunity to engage with a scalable, impactful solution that you can quickly deploy. I’m happy to schedule a time to discuss any interest you may have in the next few weeks.  
 
Thanks for your consideration, and I look forward to hearing from you!
 
 
Emani Richmond
(she/her/hers)
Consultant
LCW

subject: Well+Being: Plant-based eating and dating after 50
body:
Why doctors ignore our pain 
‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  
 
 
 
PUBLISHED BY
READ ONLINE
 | 
SIGN UP
 
Expert advice to help you live well every day. 
 
(Abbey Lossing for The Washington Post)
 
 
Tara Parker-Pope 
Happy Thursday! This week we’re celebrating vegetables, moving more to help brain health and thinking about dating in our golden years. Plus we’ve got our weekly “joy” snacks. But before that …
This week’s must-reads:
Even exercisers need to track their “sitting” time. 
Here’s why.
A family secret fueled his OCD. See 
what helped.
Want to cut sugar or salt from you diet?
 Six tips to get 
there.
A typo resulted in dangerous advice about water. 
Learn more about 
water intoxication.
The joy of plant-based eating
When well-known chef Daniel Humm announced in 2021 that he was changing his restaurant to a plant-based menu, the culinary community was stunned. Eleven Madison Park in New York was once named the best in the world and was famous for its mouthwatering duck and lobster dishes.
 
Chef Daniel Humm prepares plant-based dishes at Eleven Madison Park in New York. (Ye Fan)
While some restaurant reviewers mocked the choice, others celebrated the chef’s creative shift. I recently spoke to Humm about what he’s learned from the experience, how he’s changed his personal eating habits, why he doesn’t like the word “vegan” and his advice for those of us who want to focus on plant-based eating but are having trouble making the full commitment. Here’s our conversation, which has been edited for brevity and clarity.
ADVERTISEMENT
 
 
 
 
Q. 
What’s wrong with the word ‘vegan’?
A:
 
We want to stay away from the word vegan because I think it just comes with so many rules. I think it’s more beautiful to say plant-based. Creatively, we love to work with vegetables. They are full of opportunities and excitement. That’s what this has been for us. Cooking with vegetables has been really eye-opening.
Q: 
Was it hard to make the shift?
A:
 In the beginning, it was scary to leave so many things behind that we perfected and we were known for. I felt like it could be limiting to a certain degree. But today, I feel like we were limited before. For the main course, everyone expected lobster or another protein. With vegetables, there are thousands of opportunities, and before there were only about five.
 
Daniel Humm, chef and owner of Eleven Madison Park in New York, prepares carrot. (Fecks Wagtouicz)
Q: 
What’s your advice for home cooks who want to make more plant-based meals?
A:
 When choosing your ingredients, really be thoughtful about seasonality. That’s a privilege if you get access to seasonal ingredients.
Have a few go-to dishes you like to make. At home, I cook plant-based, and it really does take a little bit of rethinking. I have a beautiful clay donabe (a Japanese cooking pot) that I use to cook rice. I add steamed eggplant, beautiful herbs and onions. When you’ve done it once or twice, it becomes second nature and the easiest thing.
As a home cook, I think it’s important to take inspiration from other cuisines — Lebanese, Israeli, Moroccan, Japanese. Get a few of those cookbooks. As soon as you get into it, you won’t be able to stop because you realize how delicious it is and how good you feel on top of it.
Q:
 I think people worry that adding dips or sauces to vegetables makes them less healthful. What do you think?
A:
 
Not only do kids need dips, adults also need the dips. There is this preconceived notion that vegetables are boring. That’s why I thought it was important for a restaurant like ours to do this. I believe things can change when one of the great restaurants is saying that eating eggplant or zucchini is the highest form of dining. We do need to make vegetables exciting and magical because they are.
 
(Photo by Scott Suchman for The Washington Post; food styling by Lisa Cherkasky for The Washington Post)
The best foods to feed your gut microbiome
Your gut microbiome influences your mental health, heart risk, weight gain and sleep. Here's how to improve your gut health and make eating quality food a habit.
By Anahad O’Connor
Read more
 
 
 
It seems like a modern trend, but one-pot cooking has been happening for thousands of years
Its appeal remains the same: It saves time for the things that are most important.
By Yasmin Fahr
Read more
 
 
 
(Illustration by Emily Sabens/The Washington Post; iStock)
How to be sort of vegan — and how it would help the planet
Switching half of the world’s meat and dairy intake with plants would reduce greenhouse gas emissions and almost entirely halt deforestation, researchers say.
By Dino Grandoni
Read more
 
 
 
(Abbey Lossing for The Washington Post)
Dating in your ‘golden’ years
Tonight’s premiere of “The Golden Bachelor” on ABC has prompted discussions of dating after 50. People often think that older adults fall in love less intensely, without the giddiness and sheen of youthful infatuation. But falling in love as an older person involves the same group of neurons in our brain as it does in younger adults, researchers say.
That, however, may be where the similarity between young and older dating ends.
Dating over 50 certainly has its challenges — the pool of potential dates is smaller than in our younger years, and many older adults struggle to find connection. But relationship experts and over-50 daters say there are surprising benefits.
There’s no pressure to procreate or find the perfect future parent. Many people in the pool are divorced or widowed, bringing with them hard-won lessons about how not to behave in a relationship. And older daters tend to know what they want — and understand the dealbreakers — allowing them to be more selective.
“People at 50 know there’s a good chance that they will live another 30 years,” said Francine Russo, author of “Love After 50: How to Find It, Enjoy It, and Keep It.” “And if they’re in a relationship which is not satisfying, they think, ‘I don’t want this, I want something better for myself.’”
To learn more about dating in your golden years, read the full story:
 
(Chelsea Conrad/The Washington Post)
The new rules of dating after 50: Less pressure and more picky
The “Golden Bachelor” may learn that the brain reacts to love the same way at any age, but older adults can be more selective when choosing a partner
By Rebecca Fishbein
Read more
 
 
ABC’s ‘Golden Bachelor’ gives senior dating a rare moment in the spotlight
ABC's new 'Golden Bachelor,' Gerry Turner, is 71 and a widower. Fans and experts say he will normalize the idea of finding love later in life. 
By Annabelle Timsit and Adela Suliman
Read more
 
 
Why do doctors ignore our pain?
This week a reader asks why her doctor doesn’t pay attention to her pain. Our columnist Trisha S. Pasricha can relate. She writes:
“Patients can be made to feel ‘it’s all in their head’ and ushered away with a mental health diagnosis.
 
Others are forced to
 
plead for relief. Despite being a physician, I’ve experienced these interactions myself when I’ve been a patient.”
To learn more, read our latest Ask a Doctor column. Use our 
Ask a Doctor form
 to submit a question, and we may answer it in a future column.
 
(Washington Post illustration; iStock)
Advice
 
Why doesn’t my doctor believe I’m in pain?
If you feel like your doctor is dismissing your pain, it’s possible that biases and misconceptions about severe pain are impacting your care.
By Trisha Pasricha, MD
Read more
 
 
 
(Vanessa Saba for The Washington Post)
From heart disease to IUDs: How doctors dismiss women’s pain
Many women say doctors have dismissed their pain, and several studies confirm that gender bias routinely leads to denials of pain relief for female patients.
By Lindsey Bever
Read more
 
 
Find your joy snack!
Here are a few things that brought us joy this week.
Enjoy some of this week’s 
best photographs
 from The Washington Post. Our favorites: birds in the hand, puppy tails and Taylor Swift.
We can’t stop thinking about this weeknight vegetarian recipe: 
Puffy tacos
 with black beans.
What could be more joyful than a tree? Here’s how to 
plant one.
Scientists spotted a rare 
“dumbo” octopus
.
 The creature is named after Disney’s big-eared flying elephant.
Step outside and enjoy the Harvest Moon. (And
 
learn more
 about how it got its name)
Want to know more about “joy” snacks? Our Brain Matters columnist 
Richard Sima explains.
 
Y
ou can also 
read this story as a comic
.
Please let us know how we are doing. Email me at 
wellbeing@washpost.com
. You can also 
find us on TikTok.

subject: 3 foods behind the Costa Rican blue zone
body:
And how to enjoy them in your diet.
View this email in your browser.
 
Presented by CVS Health
3 foods in this Costa Rican blue zone diet that help residents live to 100
September 28, 2023
 
Six areas across the globe are known as 
the blue zones
, where a combination of culture, mindset, diet, and environment help their residents live longer and healthier lives than most. 
 
The residents of Nicoya, Costa Rica—known for its coastal views south of the Nicaraguan border—have routinely enjoyed three foods together for at least 6,000 years old, Dan Buettner, the Blue Zones LLC founder shares in his recent docuseries 
Live to 100
 on Netflix. 
 
“Without a doubt one of the reasons people in Nicoya are living a long time is because they are eating this diet of beans, squash, and corn,” Buettner says in the film. “They call it the three sisters.” 
 
Here are their health benefits and tips to add them to your diet:
 
1. Corn
 
In Nicoya, families have traditionally made tortillas by soaking corn kernels in  wood ash. 
 
“The traditional processing of corn boosts the nutritional value,” Buettner says in the film. 
 
The tortillas are high in complex carbohydrates, integral for maintaining energy. Corn by itself is also rich in fiber, so it will digest slowly and keep you satiated. 
 
How to eat it: 
Add corn to salsas, salads, or vegetable chili. 
 
2. Beans
 
Black beans contain antioxidants, which strengthen the immune system, Buettner says in the film. They are also a substantial source of fiber, which helps regulate blood sugar, and muscle-building protein. 
 
Buettner champions a daily dose of beans in his book, 
The Blue Zones American Kitchen: 100 Recipes to Live to 100
, and they’re featured in many of its recipes. 
 
How to eat it: 
In soups, in tacos, or by themselves.
 
3. Squash
 
Squash is rich in vitamins A, B, and C, as well as magnesium and potassium, which are critical for bone, blood, and heart health, according to the 
Cleveland Clinic
. Their antioxidants also help 
reduce oxidative stress
, which can cause cell damage and disease. 
 
 
Adding seasonal squash to your next dish can be a great way to start incorporating it into your diet. Fall varieties include butternut, acorn, and spaghetti squash. 
 
How to eat it:
 Roast them for a side dish or fill them with other vegetables and grains, like quinoa and tomatoes. 
 
Read Alexa Mikhail’s full article 
here
.

Hi Emani,
I’m also very excited for the conversations and work for our team in the coming months.
Our October all-staff meeting is next Tuesday, 10/3, 9:00-10:00am. If this is too soon, we have another monthly all-staff informal virtual gathering we call “coffee & connect” on Tuesday, 10/17, 9:00-9:30am. This pattern continues all year, 60 minute all-staff first Tuesday/month and 30 minute coffee & connect on the third Tuesday/month. The coffee & connects usually don’t have an agenda/topic, but occasionally there is a topic and I let staff know in this case so they are sure to hop on Teams.
I’m open to pushing back roll-out to late October or late November with content starting at the following all-staff if that works better to have plans in place rather than rush.
I added a few thoughts and questions in red below on planned toolkit structure. Let me know what you think is best on timing and happy to meet anytime to continue planning.
Thank you!
Ann
 
From:
 Emani Richmond <
e.richmond@lcwmail.com
> 
Sent:
 Thursday, September 21, 2023 5:50 PM
To:
 Ann Odens <
ann@childrensheartlink.org
>
Subject:
 RE: Discounted Talent Review Bundles
 
Hey Ann,
I’m really excited for the program we are bringing together for CHL. The opportunities I presented would be in addition to the scope of work we have already began for the fall on through next year. What is the date of the October All-Staff?
During the course roll out in October would be an opportunity to remind staff of the cultural/ DEI program you folks completed last year. Also this can get them thinking about what they hope to receive from this year’s engagement in preparation for the toolkit introduction session. 
Here are the 6 topic areas that the Intercultural Toolkit will address:
Introduction and how to use the toolkit
Intercultural Goal setting: What do you hope to gain and leverage during this journey?
Looking Back: Reflecting on cultural experiences to increase self-awareness
Values & Behaviors: How do they show up in my cultures and how might they show up in other cultures?
Leveraging Diversity: Pick 1-2 people on your team that you don’t know well and commit to understanding how they want to be treated. 
Cultural Literacy: Using Dimensions of Difference select 1-3 cultures to research and identify the behaviors you may see based on their designation. 
Let me think about how we will roll this out to the team specifically when they will get access to which course elements. 
 
Also, just so we are aligned on the contents of the current statement of work, CHL has currently purchased 20 seats for one of our eLearning courses titled: Managing with Intercultural Competence. My goal was to make this course available to CHL at the beginning of the engagement so staff could receive a refresher of key DEI, culture terminology, also to practice the DIN Model using the case study featured. Luckily LCW has recently went through a rebrand so you folks will be receiving a newly updated course. 
Let me think about how we will roll this out to the team and I can get back to you on specifics regarding when staff will complete each component, similar to a roadmap. 
 
Currently, the toolkit is outlined and includes the following structure:
Topic area with a supporting reading-
Step 1
Pre-work for the meeting: 
1 week prior to all-staff meeting (?), email to staff with topic, supporting reading and pre-work.
 
Team questions-
Step 2
For discussion during the monthly meeting: 
At all-staff meeting at start of month have small group discussions with guided questions, 15 minutes (?). Do we include debrief at this time or tell staff that more discussion will take place at each of their department meetings? Departments meet throughout that month can continue discussions, will you provide guided questions for department discussions during the month?
Space for reflection-
Step 3
To collect data throughout the process: 
What does data collection look like? How do we “close-out” topic for the month? Is there a way to collect individual feedback without meeting again and then provide topic wrap up? Would we do a monthly email 1 week prior to all-staff with current topic closing thoughts and return to step 1 of sharing next month topic/reading material/pre-work? Of course, no topic is ever done or closed, but to continue through monthly topics and steps, wondering how to somewhat end topic and move to next.
I will schedule some time for us to connect next week so you can receive a visual to communicate the timeline to staff, also to chart out our next steps with the roll out. 
I hope you are well, and we look forward to continuing our partnership with CHL.
 
Thank you,
Emani Richmond
(she/her/hers)
Consultant
LCW

From:
 Ann Odens <
ann@childrensheartlink.org
> 
Sent:
 Wednesday, September 20, 2023 2:54 PM
To:
 Emani Richmond <
e.richmond@lcwmail.com
>
Subject:
 RE: Discounted Talent Review Bundles
 
Hi Emani,
Thank you for sharing these opportunities. Are these part of the contract for Children’s HeartLink or would one of these options be added to our plan?
I know it’s been a while since we connected on next steps for our team and wondering if we could meet to touch base. I think we talked about kicking off trainings for the year at our October all-staff meeting, which is creeping right up!
My understanding of plans:
Kick-off at October staff meeting explaining goals, plans, timeline. Is there information and an image or video I can share with staff when sharing plans for the next 6 months?
Implement Leadership Toolkit with new topic monthly:
Part 1: LCW facilitated walk-through (How long? When? Beginning of November?) 
Part 2: Monthly CHL guided discussions at monthly team meetings. Topics and discussion questions provided by LCW. Should we introduce new topic at monthly staff meetings and have initial discussions at that time?
Intercultural Competence Toolkit:
Part 1: Monthly eLearning done individually by CHL staff. How long is each eLearning? Will we pre-select eLearning sessions for staff do each month to tie-in to monthly discussion topic? How do staff access the learning platform?
LCW consulting hours that allow CHL team to check-in with LCW quarterly to see what cultural competence questions surface. Is this check-in structured time with me and Jackie or more of open session for all staff to ask questions of an LCW consultant?
Where do we tie-in a review of their own IDI results and inform staff that this next set of training aligns with IDI work done last year?
Clearly I have many questions and not sure if my understanding of the overall process is correct. Happy to talk with you any time to keep the training moving forward.
Thank you,
Ann
Ann Odens
Director of Operations and HR
Children’s HeartLink
952.237.5510
www.childrensheartlink.org
 
 
 
 
 
From:
 Emani Richmond <
e.richmond@lcwmail.com
> 
Sent:
 Thursday, September 7, 2023 9:10 AM
To:
 Ann Odens <
ann@childrensheartlink.org
>
Subject:
 Discounted Talent Review Bundles
 
Hi Ann,
 
I hope you’re feeling alive and well. As the energy of summer simmers down and everyone’s project timelines increase I want you to know that LCW is here to assist with any of your L&D DEI + Culture needs!
 
I’m reaching out to share a special promotion LCW is running with performance evaluation season in mind. Through October, we’d like to offer you 
discounted learning bundles
 of our most popular programs – 
25%-off
 to help you close out the year with an active stance in equity. These bundles are designed to equip people managers with tools that enable sustainable high performance on diverse and multicultural teams.
 
You can view detailed course descriptions on 
our website
, but here’s a quick summary of the bundles that can help you debias the performance management process:
 
Just in Time Bundle: 
1-hour Zoom facilitation, 1 eLearning, 1 microLearning
Tools for Sustained Impact Bundle:
 2-hour Zoom facilitation, 1 eLearning, 1 microLearning, 1 Leader-Led Toolkit
 
Talent Management Bundle:
 4-hour Zoom facilitation, 2 eLearnings, 1 microLearning, 1 Leader-Led Toolkit
 
If you have any budget left to use this year, bringing one of these learning bundles to your organization could be a great opportunity to engage with a scalable, impactful solution that you can quickly deploy. I’m happy to schedule a time to discuss any interest you may have in the next few weeks.  
 
Thanks for your consideration, and I look forward to hearing from you!
 
 
Emani Richmond

Consultant

body:
Beijos e abraços!
Enviado do meu iPhone
Início da mensagem encaminhada:
De:
 Lucy Linhares <ica@infolink.com.br>
Data:
 28 de setembro de 2023 16:04:56 BRT
Para:
 Emani Richmond <e.richmond@lcwmail.com>
Assunto:
 
Re: Client Notes: Brazil Session (Oct 10th)
﻿Hey dear
I also enjoyed our talk very much!
Here is the pic
<image1.jpeg>
Enviado do meu iPhone
Em 28 de set. de 2023, à(s) 12:55, Emani Richmond <e.richmond@lcwmail.com> escreveu:
﻿
 
Hi Lucy,
 
It was BEYOND a pleasure to meet you and connect over the course we will be delivering on October 10
th
. 
 
**Could you please send me your head shot you would like to use in the training?
 
Client: 
Carta
 (Link to website)
~1,200 employees, average session attendance 30-70 people
Audience: All staff
Major offices located in: NYC, Rio, San Diego
 
As mentioned on the call here’s our aggressive content timeline:
Lucy to create and send a presentation by Monday or sooner if possible
I will send the content to our design team by Tuesday
I will try to get it back by Thursday from the design team so you can review the final slides on Friday
 
Client notes on expectations for the training:
Hi Emani - Wanted to provide some general themes and expectations for this training: 
Distinction between Latine, Hispanic, and Brazilian identities
 (I'm hoping there will be some 
graphic
 representation to pair with this)
calling out 
US perspective
 in language 
addressing 
evolving terms
 (Latina/o, Latinx, Latine) 
Spotlight 
differences between Brazil and US
 
(include a nod to employment law differences, cultural context, and political relationships)
reasoning - Carta has a large Brazilian population, Carta's first international office (#3), 2nd or 3rd largest office
Unpacking stereotypes
 that might be made about these identity groups - this might be the space to hear from the culture native or where you point to the historical timeline that impacts those stereotypes
layer with 
data on why it matters 
or how it impacts workplace dynamics 
Tips/Strategies on interrupting bias 
against Latine, Hispanic and/or Brazilian identities in the workplace. Here are few examples of things that have come up
accents (underscoring the cognitive power that it takes to translate from native language to English)
asking too many questions (to bridge understanding between US and Brazilian culture)
microaggressions on time differences and seasons (reminding folks of time differences, opposite season from the northern hemisphere)
access to equitable resources (barriers traveling to the US, working on US holidays, etc) 
 
I look forward to connecting with you again once the content is finalized.
 
Hugs and kisses!
 
Emani Richmond
(she/her/hers)
Consultant
LCW
